National AI Strategy - Dashboard

Early access – For Analysis & Visualization

Expert Reports Analysis

Summaries of expert reports organized by strategic pillar.

Research & Talent

27 of 30 reports addressed this pillar

Executive Summary
Common Themes

Multiple reports emphasize the critical importance of attracting, developing, and retaining world-class AI talent to maintain Canada’s competitive edge. Many reports stress that long-term, sustained funding for leading research institutions (e.g., MILA, CIFAR, Amii, Vector) is vital both for supporting fundamental research and for translating breakthroughs into commercial applications [3,4,8,19,20]. Several experts also note that improved inter-sector coordination—integrating academia, industry, government, and defence—is essential for creating a robust innovation ecosystem, minimizing talent leakage, and fostering rapid knowledge transfer [2,13,14,16,29]. Furthermore, a recurrent theme is the need for reforming immigration policies and establishing fast-track programs to attract international AI researchers and senior leadership talent, which will bolster Canada’s research and industrial capabilities [3,11,12,24,28].

Unique Perspectives

Some reports offer particularly innovative ideas that stand apart. For example, one report highlights the need for rigorous, evidence‐based research into AI trust and safety, including international initiatives such as joint model testing and red-teaming to build public trust in AI systems [1]. Another unique perspective is the call for the creation of a national AI research monitoring agency to track emerging trends and ensure that Canada’s research remains ethically and globally competitive [18]. Additionally, there is a distinctive proposal to develop specialized training initiatives—such as AI Fast-Follow Facilities and Indigenous AI education programs—to address current skills gaps and build a more diverse talent pipeline for the future [22,29].

Individual Expert Reports
[1] Joelle Pineau Report - Building safe AI systems and public trust in AI.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report highlights the need to accelerate research into AI trust and safety by continuing to fund initiatives such as CAISI. It stresses that rigorous, evidence‐based research must be undertaken before deploying new AI solutions and recommends leveraging international partnerships—through activities such as joint model testing and red-teaming—to improve understanding of AI safety risks. While not primarily focused on broader talent issues, the report implies that maintaining a competitive edge in research for safe AI systems is linked to attracting and retaining skilled researchers committed to ethical practices.

[2] James Neufeld Report - AI Task Force.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report highlights Canada’s considerable AI talent but stresses that retaining and developing this talent is critical for national sovereignty and economic independence. It warns of the leakage of top public-sector expertise to foreign companies and calls for stronger pathways between government, academia, and domestic industry. The report argues that Canada must build conditions that not only attract but also retain AI talent by ensuring that expertise gained in public service remains within Canadian institutions, thereby fostering a sustainable cycle of knowledge circulation and innovation.

[3] Patrick Pichette Report - AI Strategy Task Force - final.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the importance of building and retaining a competitive AI research talent pool. It highlights Canada’s existing world‐class research strengths, particularly through institutions like CIFAR, MILA, Amii, and the universities in Toronto, Waterloo, Montreal, and Edmonton, and calls for increased investment in education and research to further nurture this talent.

A key recommendation is to halt the current brain drain by reforming immigration policies such as the TN visa program and launching head‐hunting initiatives to attract top international AI/CS talent, thereby ensuring Canada remains globally competitive and ethically grounded in its research efforts.

[4] AWAITING CONFIRMATION FROM DMO - Scaling Canadian Global Champions_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report recognizes that robust, world‐class research and strong leadership talent are essential for Canada’s AI future. It emphasizes the need to sustain a pipeline of cutting-edge AI research through guaranteed long-term funding for national AI institutes (e.g., Vector, MILA, Amii) and integration with commercialization pipelines. It also notes a shortage in experienced, senior leadership talent required for scaling, and recommends measures such as a Canadian Fastrack Leadership Talent Program which includes fast-track immigration, repatriation support, and competitive salary top-ups to attract and retain seasoned professionals.

[6] Ajay Agrawal Report - October 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

While there is no dedicated section solely on research and talent, the report implies that achieving its ambitious AI-driven transformations will depend on integrating high‐quality human expertise with advanced AI systems. It emphasizes that system-level redesigns in sectors such as healthcare, education, defence, natural resource management, and homelessness require not just technological solutions but also the leadership of skilled professionals who can drive process reinvention and innovation. This suggests an underlying need for attracting and retaining talent that can work collaboratively across institutions to build and deploy these complex AI frameworks.

[7] Alex LaPlante Report - AI_Task_Force_Recommendations.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report opens by acknowledging Canada’s established world‐class AI research base—highlighting the Pan‐Canadian AI Strategy led by institutions such as CIFAR, Amii, Mila, and Vector—and notes that research excellence has been a magnet for top global talent. However, it focuses less on expanding new research directions and more on leveraging existing strengths to transition from research to practical, wide‐scale adoption. In this context, the document implies that sustaining the research edge includes building on the current institutional framework rather than proposing new, detailed initiatives for research coordination or talent retention.

[8] Arvind Gupta Report - AI Strategy Task Force Recommendations - Arvind Gupta.docx ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes strengthening Canada’s research edge in AI through substantial and sustained investments in foundational institutions. Recommendations include continued support for Canada’s three AI institutes and CIFAR chairs, the creation of a competitive multi-disciplinary tri-council program for fundamental AI research, and expanded research compute facilities. There is also a call for a new Canada-AI chairs program to attract and retain top-tier AI researchers, along with initiatives to review funding criteria and promote multi-disciplinary research that integrates ethical, responsible, and transparent AI practices.

[9] Ben Bergen Report - 2025-11-01 - CCI's 2025 AI Task Force Submission.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report briefly acknowledges Canada’s history of AI innovation and the role of education and skilled immigration in addressing talent needs. However, it does not provide an in‐depth roadmap for retaining or expanding Canada’s research edge. Instead, it hints that nurturing talent is part of the broader scaling strategy, without detailed recommendations for deeper coordination or ethically grounded research conditions.

[10] Cari Covent Report - AI Strategy Task Force Accelerating Adoption FinalOctober31- Covent.pdf ↑ Back to top

Although the report’s primary focus is on accelerating AI adoption, it indirectly addresses the need to bridge Canada’s world-class AI research with real-world applications. It emphasizes mission-driven initiatives that pair federal funding with academic expertise and public‐private partnerships, suggesting that identifying and scaling high-impact, research-informed solutions is key to maintaining a globally competitive and ethically grounded AI landscape.

[11] Dan Debow Report - AI Task Force Response.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report touches on attracting and retaining top AI talent, highlighting the need for rapid immigration pathways such as a 'Discovery Visa' to bring in the world’s best scientists and engineers. It also notes that while Canada has long led in AI research, there is a shift needed toward leveraging that research in commercial settings. Furthermore, for government projects, the report recommends building small, elite teams of AI specialists with competitive, performance-based compensation to ensure technical leadership and innovation.

[12] Diane Gutiw Report - Canadian AI Strategy Task Force2025-10-31 FINAL.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the need to bridge the gap between pure AI research and its commercial applications by creating a streamlined innovation pipeline. It highlights that Canada’s research ecosystem is fragmented by misaligned funding streams, regulatory inconsistencies, and restrictive work permit policies, all of which affect the attraction, development, and retention of high-tech talent. Key recommendations include overhauling funding structures to support both research and its operational costs, and establishing clear IP frameworks to protect and share innovations across academia, industry, and public sectors.

Additionally, specific actions are proposed to simplify immigration policies and integrate subsidized entry‐level roles and AI internships. These measures aim to ensure that Canada not only attracts top AI researchers and talent but also retains them by linking research to marketable opportunities and clear career pathways.

[13] Gail Murphy Report - Submission for October 2025 Sprint of the Federal AI Task Force.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the need to maintain and enhance Canada’s global AI research edge by focusing on key areas of strength. It recommends channeling efforts and funding into selected domains (such as health, robotics, and scientific discovery) where Canada has distinctive advantages, and establishing a coordinating cross-sector council made up of academia, industry, and government. Collaboration is seen as essential for creating a dynamic environment that fosters research excellence and drives economic benefits. In addition, the report calls for expanding support for fundamental research through increased funding for research chairs, additional AI institutes, and mechanisms such as industrial-based PhD programs to attract, develop, and retain top talent in AI.

[14] Ian Rae - AI Task Force Recommendations 7 pages.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report touches on AI talent through recommendations to set up comprehensive talent development and retention programmes. It calls for funding and initiatives that translate academic strengths into applied innovation and practical skills, emphasizing hands‐on education and training hubs that connect research with industry needs, including retraining and upskilling the existing workforce. These initiatives are framed as critical to ensuring that Canada not only attracts but also retains top AI talent across research, the public sector and industry.

[15] Ian Rae - AI Task Force submission with appendix.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the need to attract, develop, and retain top AI talent by establishing targeted programs that bridge research excellence with applied innovation. It recommends setting up specialized talent development and retention initiatives, including hands‐on education, research translation funding, and partnerships with colleges and trade schools. These efforts are seen as critical to ensuring that Canada’s AI research edge is not only maintained but also aligned with national strategic needs.

[?] Louis T├кtu Report - Can AI Strategy Task Force - Louis Tetu - Nov 1st 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report acknowledges that Canada’s strength in AI has traditionally been in research and innovation and emphasizes the need to shift towards industrialization without losing its research edge. It calls for expanding and retaining top AI talent across research, industry, and the public sector by aligning training and immigration programs with national competitiveness goals, and by embedding AI expertise within government operations.

[17] Marc Etienne Ouimette Report - Cardinal_Policy_AI_Task Force_FINAL.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the importance of building and retaining top AI talent by linking AI infrastructure investments with human capacity development. It calls for initiatives such as the Canadian Compute Innovation Initiative (CCII) to recruit expert systems engineers, developer-platform specialists, and operations teams from both academia and industry, including secondments from leading commercial CSPs. In addition, it proposes creating specialized training programs — such as an LLM school and AI change management courses — that address the current gaps between frontier AI research and applied model production, ensuring that Canada’s research talent can drive both innovation and practical deployment.

[18] Mary Wells Report - AI Task force Memo MWells.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report touches on research and talent by emphasizing the need to support impartial, published research into AI risks and mitigation methods. It recommends establishing a national AI research monitoring agency to track trends and initiatives, ensuring that research remains globally competitive and ethically grounded. Additionally, the report suggests leveraging academic expertise through initiatives such as building a public-good large language model, which would bridge foundational research with practical deployment.

[19] Michael Bowling Report - AI Strategy Task Force Report.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report centers on the importance of research and talent in AI, emphasizing that Canada’s competitive edge rests on attracting, training, and retaining world-class researchers. It details the success of the AI Chairs program, which has been pivotal in recruiting top talent from global institutions to Canadian universities. Key recommendations include continuing and expanding the AI Chairs program through additional 5‐year renewals (with a goal of up to a 40% increase in chair positions) and doubling per-chair research funding to boost research output and trainee supervision capacity. It also stresses that retaining talent involves long-term funding stability and addressing barriers such as immigration hurdles that delay the arrival of international students and researchers.

[20] Michael Serbinis - Research & Talent_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report centers on ensuring that Canada retains and grows its AI research edge by focusing on strategic breakthrough domains, including AI in health and scientific discovery, advanced AI capabilities (such as reasoning, robotics, and complex systems), and AI governance and safety. It emphasizes the need for sustained multi-year funding for top national labs and institutes (such as MILA, Vector, and Amii) alongside initiatives like mission-driven AI Grand Challenges that integrate research with commercialization pathways. The report recommends making deliberate choices on where to compete, collaborate, and defer in order to consolidate Canada’s strengths and to invest in sovereign compute infrastructure and trusted data environments. It also highlights the importance of balancing fundamental and applied research to ensure that breakthroughs transition effectively into real-world impact while retaining academic freedom.

[21] Michael Serbinis Report - Commercialization_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report touches on the need to better connect Canada’s strong AI research capabilities with commercialization efforts to retain and develop top talent. It recommends evolving the objectives of National AI Research Institutes to include commercialization KPIs (such as patents, spin‐outs, and industry-collaborated projects) and establishing roles like Founders-in-Residence and Commercialization Fellows to bridge academic research with market applications. Additionally, initiatives such as a Canadian Champions Year Program are suggested to retain top graduates, thereby helping to keep talent within Canada.

[22] Natiea Vinson - Indigenous AI Education and Skills.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report does not directly address strategies to retain or grow Canada’s AI research edge or to coordinate research across academia, industry, government, and defence. However, it does hint at a future talent pipeline through its emphasis on early Indigenous AI education and skills development, suggesting that culturally relevant training programs could eventually build a cadre of Indigenous AI leaders. Overall, while Indigenous youth interest is noted, there is no explicit discussion of research competitiveness or ethical grounding at the research ecosystem level.

[23] Olivier Blais Report - Ministerial memo for AI adoption across industries and government.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report briefly acknowledges that Canada’s research ecosystem is world‐class, but it does not delve deeply into strategies for retaining and growing Canada’s AI research edge or detailing mechanisms for enhanced coordination among academia, industry, government, and defence. There is little discussion on attracting or retaining top AI talent or on conditions necessary to keep Canadian AI research globally competitive and ethically grounded.

[24] Sam Ramadori - AI Strategy Task Force Submission - 251101.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report touches on research and talent through its recommendation to create a fast track immigration program for leading AI and quantum computing scientists. This is aimed at attracting elite talent to bolster Canada’s domestic capabilities in frontier and dual-use AI. It also hints at leveraging Canada’s world-leading AI research ecosystem by forging international coalitions that pool research, compute resources, and talent, thus reinforcing the nation’s competitive edge and ethical grounding in AI.

[25] Sarah Ryan Report - AI Strategy Taskforce Report Sarah Ryan 2025-10-05.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report briefly recommends that the federal government support research into the impact of AI on work. It calls for developing reliable data and research to understand AI’s effects on employment, including issues such as job displacement, bias, discrimination, surveillance, privacy, and workplace safety. While the focus is not on advancing Canada’s AI research edge per se, there is a clear call for evidence-based insights to inform AI-related regulations and policy decisions that affect workers.

[26] Shelly Bruce Report - AI Taskforce Submission_Security_SBruce_31 October 2025_amendment.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report underscores Canada’s strength in world‐leading AI research and cybersecurity, noting that these assets should be further leveraged to address emerging AI security challenges. It highlights the need to integrate classified and unclassified AI security research, foster coordinated initiatives (such as through CAISSI and partnerships with institutions like CIFAR), and match leading academics with skilled researchers to address specific AI security challenges. This approach aims to ensure that Canada retains a competitive edge while adopting ethical and technically robust practices in AI development.

[28] Adam Keating Report - AI Task Force Report_ Commercialization (Keating).pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the need for Canada to establish a clear, bold 2030 vision that acts as a north star for building its AI research edge. It recommends measures to attract, develop, and retain world‐class talent by improving immigration pathways for top AI researchers and entrepreneurs, reinforcing a national build culture, and fostering deeper collaboration across academia, industry, government, and defence. The document highlights the importance of setting measurable goals and creating a supportive ecosystem—one that not only fuels cutting‐edge research but also encourages ethical practices and rapid innovation.

[29] Garth Gibson - AI Strategy Task Force Memo.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report highlights the critical need to bolster Canada’s AI research and talent pool by enhancing coordination among academia, industry, government, and defense. It emphasizes leveraging existing strengths such as the Pan-Canadian AI Strategy and the world-class researchers (e.g., Hinton, Bengio, Sutton) to attract and retain top talent. The report also stresses the importance of developing human infrastructure, particularly in nurturing AI software and data engineers, who are currently in short supply. It recommends initiatives like the AI Fast-Follow Facility to upskill domestic talent, ensuring that researchers and practitioners remain globally competitive while adhering to ethical standards.

Adoption Across Industry & Governments

27 of 30 reports addressed this pillar

Executive Summary
Common Themes

Multiple reports emphasize the need for government-led initiatives to drive AI adoption, highlighting the importance of transparent, accountable, and streamlined procurement processes that favor domestic solutions. Many experts advocate for the government to act as an early adopter or 'client zero' by piloting AI applications within public services, modernizing legacy IT systems, and using public registries and monitoring tools to build trust [1,2,7,11,12,21,28]. Additionally, there is a strong call for cross-sector collaborations and targeted, sector-specific incentives to translate research breakthroughs into practical applications across critical industries such as healthcare, agriculture, energy, and transportation, thereby bridging the gap between innovation and real-world deployment [3,5,8,10,18,23].

Unique Perspectives

One report uniquely proposes exporting Canada’s government-led digital transformation model internationally to set benchmarks and promote global best practices in AI adoption [3]. Another distinctive perspective focuses on the AI adoption challenges faced by Indigenous governments and remote communities, emphasizing the need for culturally appropriate frameworks and improved connectivity to ensure equitable participation in the digital economy [22]. Additionally, an innovative recommendation involves establishing a national network of AI adoption hubs designed to bridge the gap between academic research and SME implementation, thereby accelerating the transition from laboratory innovation to commercial and public-sector solutions [8].

Individual Expert Reports
[1] Joelle Pineau Report - Building safe AI systems and public trust in AI.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report touches upon government adoption of AI by recommending the launch of public registries to provide transparency about AI tools used in government operations and by issuing clear directives on their application. This move is expected to build public trust by demonstrating how AI is used responsibly in support of administrative decisions. It also calls for regular public consultations, ensuring that both industry and civil society are engaged in the evolution of the national AI strategy, which in turn can support responsible adoption in public services.

[2] James Neufeld Report - AI Task Force.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report criticizes current government procurement practices that favor foreign suppliers over domestic companies, undermining the potential for impactful AI adoption within Canada. It argues that Canada’s public sector, particularly the procurement arm, must shift its approach from a reliance on innovation grants to actively buying and supporting homegrown AI solutions. This change is seen as essential for ensuring that sectors with high AI potential can benefit from local capabilities and that Canadian values and technological expertise are embedded within government projects.

[3] Patrick Pichette Report - AI Strategy Task Force - final.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report underlines the transformative potential of AI adoption across federal services and industry. It recommends a bold, government‐led transformation of federal bureaucracies by deploying AI technologies—especially foundation model services—to deliver faster and more efficient public services and to modernize legacy IT systems.

Additionally, it identifies a significant opportunity to export the digital transformation model to other governments and large institutions worldwide, thereby both scaling nationwide application and setting measurable benchmarks for AI adoption success.

[4] AWAITING CONFIRMATION FROM DMO - Scaling Canadian Global Champions_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report highlights that Canada’s industrial and governmental adoption of AI is hindered by a lack of domestic anchor contracts. Both the private and public sectors are currently less willing to procure emerging technologies from Canadian scaleups, which forces these companies to secure their first enterprise contracts in the US. It recommends the launch of a Canadian Federal Digital Transformation Program to modernize government procurement practices, the implementation of a 'Buy Canadian First' mandate, and the creation of a national registry of AI projects to stimulate early adoption and establish clear performance indicators.

[5] AWAITING DMO CONFIRMATION - Sonia Sennik Memo 1 [Adoption Across Industry and Governments] - Oct 31 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report centers on the critical need to accelerate AI adoption across Canadian industry and government, highlighting that the nation currently lags its G7 peers in digital intensity. It recommends focusing AI initiatives on productivity-driven use cases where practical tools can ramp up output and reduce costs. The report underscores the value of structured, cohort-based programs such as CDL’s Putting AI to Work, which guide organizations through selecting high-ROI AI solutions, implementing them with clear playbooks, and building internal capabilities for continuous adoption. Case studies, including implementations in IT and finance, illustrate how targeted AI deployment can lead to significant improvements in efficiency, cost savings, and overall productivity.

[6] Ajay Agrawal Report - October 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report advocates for transforming traditional public service delivery by using AI to re-engineer and coordinate systems across key sectors. It calls for the government to play a central role in overseeing system-level solutions, thereby mitigating coordination risk and ensuring the rapid deployment of AI applications in healthcare, education, natural resources management, defence, and homelessness. The emphasis on performance‐based, evidence‐driven experiments and regulatory sandboxes illustrates a framework whereby public institutions and industry collaboratively drive the adoption of AI in meaningful ways.

[7] Alex LaPlante Report - AI_Task_Force_Recommendations.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes that, despite Canada’s strong research leadership, actual AI adoption across industry and government still lags behind global peers. It calls for a pragmatic, safety‐and‐accountability‐driven strategy that turns research breakthroughs into impactful, production-ready solutions. Key recommendations include developing a National AI Adoption Playbook and establishing a coordinated learning network to guide organizations in managing change, data readiness, vendor selection, privacy, security, and other adoption challenges. This framework is intended to lower barriers and ensure measurable production deployments that drive productivity gains.

[8] Arvind Gupta Report - AI Strategy Task Force Recommendations - Arvind Gupta.docx ↑ Back to top

To accelerate impactful AI adoption in both industry and government, the report recommends creating a national network of AI adoption hubs that bridge academic research and SME implementation. A new Canadian government procurement program modeled on the SBIR and STTR initiatives is proposed to facilitate the transition of academic research into viable startups and practical AI solutions, with a focus on dual-use technologies that serve both civilian and defense needs. These measures are intended to lower barriers and drive coordinated engagement across sectors, ensuring that AI benefits are broadly distributed.

[9] Ben Bergen Report - 2025-11-01 - CCI's 2025 AI Task Force Submission.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the need to accelerate AI adoption both in government and across industries. It highlights that public procurement of AI solutions and targeted incentives can create anchor markets, particularly in sectors such as healthcare, education, agriculture, and transportation. The report also notes that current adoption rates among Canadian SMEs are low compared to peer nations and calls for government support in addressing barriers to adoption while measuring success through increased integration of AI technologies.

[10] Cari Covent Report - AI Strategy Task Force Accelerating Adoption FinalOctober31- Covent.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report stresses the importance of accelerating AI adoption across key sectors such as healthcare, agriculture, energy, transportation, and manufacturing. It calls for the launch of targeted 'AI Mission Canada' programs that bring together government, industry, and academia to sponsor and scale pilot projects in these areas. Recommendations include sector-specific incentives like tax credits, innovation grants, and establishing shared data and innovation platforms to address barriers and drive measurable performance improvements.

[11] Dan Debow Report - AI Task Force Response.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report advises that government adoption of AI is crucial to demonstrating value and spurring broader industry uptake. It recommends that government agencies, starting with departments like the CRA and IRCC, pilot AI initiatives to improve service delivery, reduce wait times, and cut costs. Transparency measures such as a dedicated website to track project progress are suggested to build public trust and accountability. Enhanced incentives and streamlined procurement processes are also proposed to help government agencies become early adopters of AI technology.

[12] Diane Gutiw Report - Canadian AI Strategy Task Force2025-10-31 FINAL.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report identifies a critical role for government in accelerating the adoption of AI by shifting from a risk-averse purchaser to an active 'client zero' partner. It recommends that the public sector adopt accelerated procurement pathways and partner with industry to validate and stimulate domestic demand for homegrown AI solutions. This would involve creating a pan-Canadian evaluation and procurement pathway that quickly assesses the safety, effectiveness, and equity of AI products while favoring Canadian-made innovations.

The proposed approach is designed to break down existing silos by enabling more dynamic interactions between government, industry, and academia. Removing traditional procurement limitations is seen as essential to encourage both the responsible uptake of AI technologies across sectors and the establishment of a unified market for Canadian AI solutions.

[13] Gail Murphy Report - Submission for October 2025 Sprint of the Federal AI Task Force.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report identifies high-potential application areas—including AI for health, AI for robotics, and AI for scientific discovery—as critical sectors that can drive impactful adoption of AI in Canada. It outlines how targeted initiatives in these areas, supported by specialized research funding and national summits, can stimulate industry uptake and position Canada as a global leader. While the primary focus is on enhancing research and talent, the recommended cross-sector collaborations and focused missions are designed to create a bridge toward broader and responsible AI adoption in both industry and government.

[14] Ian Rae - AI Task Force Recommendations 7 pages.pdf ↑ Back to top

While the report’s primary focus is on establishing sovereign infrastructure, it does highlight the need for modernizing government IT and digital services. In its call for a dramatic renovation of government IT foundations, there is an implicit push for the adoption of agile digital practices that can serve as a model for broader responsible AI uptake across both industry and government. However, specific frameworks or targeted measures for broad-based AI adoption across various sectors are not deeply discussed.

[15] Ian Rae - AI Task Force submission with appendix.pdf ↑ Back to top

While the report’s primary focus is on infrastructure and sovereignty, it touches on government and industry adoption indirectly. It calls for modernizing government IT and digital service delivery as a way to lead by example, and it emphasizes the importance of equitable access to computing resources and high-speed connectivity for startups, SMEs, and researchers. These measures are intended to overcome barriers to AI adoption by ensuring that critical digital services and high-quality infrastructure are available nationwide.

[?] Louis T├кtu Report - Can AI Strategy Task Force - Louis Tetu - Nov 1st 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report recommends a rapid, coordinated effort to drive AI adoption across both industry and government. It urges the creation of conditions that incentivize businesses and public institutions to deploy AI by removing barriers, establishing regulatory alignment, and implementing standards that facilitate integration. A particular focus is placed on using a repeatable, interoperable AI stack that can deliver measurable productivity gains and transformative efficiency in government workflows.

[17] Marc Etienne Ouimette Report - Cardinal_Policy_AI_Task Force_FINAL.pdf ↑ Back to top

Adoption across industry and government is a key focus of the report. It recommends a shift from chasing frontier breakthroughs to accelerating the diffusion of AI across the economy. The strategy includes targeted support for specific sectors by using an AIAI-based sector-selection formula to identify priority industries, and developing industry-specific AI adoption plans (IAI-APs) with clear roadmaps, pre-approved solutions, and pilot projects. Public sector reference deployments are also advised as proof of concept to build trust and demonstrate the practical utility of AI solutions in improving productivity and public service delivery.

[18] Mary Wells Report - AI Task force Memo MWells.pdf ↑ Back to top

For AI adoption across industry and governments, the report advocates for accelerating AI integration through sector-specific training and deployment partnerships. It highlights the importance of coordinated initiatives involving government, academia, and the private and non-profit sectors to build tailored talent pipelines and practical deployment strategies in fields like healthcare, energy, agriculture, and manufacturing. The integration of safety and trust standards into procurement and funding incentives is also recommended to reduce barriers and ensure responsible uptake.

[20] Michael Serbinis - Research & Talent_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

While the primary focus of the report is on research and talent, there are strong recommendations to bridge the gap between research breakthroughs and real-world application. The report calls for integrating public and private research by directing public AI funding to multi-sector, mission-driven intermediaries that can translate scientific discovery into commercial and public-sector solutions. Additionally, it advocates using federal policy instruments and funding transfers to set national AI adoption goals in critical sectors such as health, defence, and public services, thereby creating predictable domestic demand for Canadian AI.

[21] Michael Serbinis Report - Commercialization_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the importance of government adoption to drive impactful AI uptake. It recommends establishing mandatory pilot-to-procurement pathways in sectors such as health, justice, and grid management to ensure that Canada acts as the first reference customer for its own AI solutions. Complementary measures include implementing a robust ‘Buy Canadian First’ policy and digital transformation programs aimed at modernizing governmental operations while prioritizing Canadian-owned AI companies. Such initiatives aim to create measurable demand and encourage meaningful engagement with AI across public services.

[22] Natiea Vinson - Indigenous AI Education and Skills.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report highlights significant barriers to AI adoption among Indigenous governments and organizations, particularly in remote and rural communities. Key obstacles include inadequate connectivity, insufficient technical support, and systemic digital inequality that hinder engagement with AI tools. In consultations, Indigenous entities expressed substantial interest in AI along with concerns over privacy, security, and lack of foundational understanding. These challenges indicate that impactful AI adoption can only be achieved by addressing infrastructure gaps and by establishing culturally appropriate frameworks for digital transformation.

[23] Olivier Blais Report - Ministerial memo for AI adoption across industries and government.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes a significant adoption gap in AI across Canadian industries and public institutions, noting that despite the promise of transformative productivity and improved public services, only 12% of firms actively use AI at a significant scale. To address this, it recommends establishing clear leadership within each federal department and major public agencies, supported by designated Chief AI Officers and a national coordination mechanism to align strategies across sectors. This coordinated approach is seen as essential to overcome fragmented efforts and to turn policy ambition into concrete, scalable action in both industry and government.

[24] Sam Ramadori - AI Strategy Task Force Submission - 251101.pdf ↑ Back to top

The submission highlights Canada’s chronic underperformance in technology adoption, noting that outdated procurement models and a risk-averse culture have hindered the uptake of innovative AI solutions in both government and industry. It recommends a broad-based technology adoption movement aimed at shaking up procurement processes and fostering a cultural shift within both the public and private sectors to accelerate the responsible uptake of AI.

[25] Sarah Ryan Report - AI Strategy Taskforce Report Sarah Ryan 2025-10-05.pdf ↑ Back to top

There are limited direct references to AI adoption across industry and government; however, the report does note that building trust is key to AI adoption. It emphasizes that any deployment of AI in public sector and workplace settings must be accompanied by transparent and ethical practices—inclusive governance, public procurement standards, and controls over algorithmic decision‐making—to ensure that the technology is both effective and acceptable to users.

[26] Shelly Bruce Report - AI Taskforce Submission_Security_SBruce_31 October 2025_amendment.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report recommends adopting a risk-based approach to improve cybersecurity across government and industry by leveraging AI. It advises the federal government to incentivize medium and large organizations to onboard Canadian AI-enabled cybersecurity solutions, while also supporting the smallest and most vulnerable organizations (including small businesses, municipalities, and Indigenous communities) through open-source AI-enabled cyber assistants. These measures aim to accelerate the responsible uptake of AI tools that enhance security and resilience.

[28] Adam Keating Report - AI Task Force Report_ Commercialization (Keating).pdf ↑ Back to top

For adoption across industry and government, the report calls for reforms in procurement and a “Buy Canadian” policy to eliminate waste and promote domestic solutions. It advocates for releasing government service level agreements (SLAs) and accountability dashboards to track spending and performance, thereby creating transparency and stimulating trust in government-led AI projects. In doing so, it aims to signal the country’s commitment to responsible AI uptake and ensure that both public and private sectors are aligned in leveraging AI solutions for economic growth.

[29] Garth Gibson - AI Strategy Task Force Memo.pdf ↑ Back to top

Although the report primarily focuses on infrastructure and research, it notes that the ultimate economic benefits of AI are driven by business uptake and real-world applications. It acknowledges that Canadian businesses are lagging behind their international counterparts in AI adoption, and that government support is essential to accelerate progress. Emphasis is placed on ensuring that new AI data centres and computing capacities are structured to support domestic enterprises and that a portion of this capacity is reserved for local use, thereby fostering broader and more responsible AI adoption across industry and governments.

Commercialization of AI

21 of 30 reports addressed this pillar

Executive Summary
Common Themes

Multiple experts emphasize the importance of bridging the gap between AI research and commercialization. Several reports highlight that Canada’s strength in early-stage research is undermined by barriers in scaling innovations domestically, resulting in lost economic opportunities and diminished global competitiveness. This theme is evident in the call for stronger linkages between academic research, industry applications, and commercialization pathways through initiatives such as centralized funding, incubation hubs, and the integration of research with market-driven outcomes [2,3,4,7,8,9,12,13,20,21,29]. Additionally, many experts stress the need to retain domestic ownership of intellectual property and data to ensure economic and data sovereignty while mitigating risks associated with foreign takeovers [2,3,7,8,9,15,16,29].

A second recurrent recommendation centers on reforming the funding and regulatory environment to support the growth of Canadian AI companies. This includes modernizing tax incentives (such as revising SR&ED, capital gains treatment, and other fiscal measures) and aligning financial mechanisms to ensure that research funding translates into commercially viable ventures [4,7,11,28]. The need for a coherent and streamlined policy mix that connects research outputs with commercialization outcomes is a recurring sentiment across many reports, underscoring a shared vision for transforming Canada’s AI innovation ecosystem [12,20,21].

Unique Perspectives

One report stands out by proposing the designation of a national champion for AI, specifically recommending that Canada declare Cohere as its lead national large language model champion. This approach, backed by multi-year revenue contracts in civil and defense sectors, is intended to secure data sovereignty while reinventing federal services, representing a bold and focused strategy to advance commercialization [3].

Another innovative perspective is presented by Marc Etienne Ouimette, who suggests the development of a commercially viable, energy-backed infrastructure platform through a joint venture model termed the Strategic Adoption Cluster (SAC). This model integrates long-term off-take agreements, domestic compute capabilities, sovereign loan guarantees, and power purchase agreements to directly link research and compute investments with market opportunities and ensure robust commercialization channels [17]. Additionally, Sam Ramadori's proposal of establishing a Canadian 'In-Q-Tel' model to strategically fund and fast-track dual-use AI technologies offers a novel approach to bridge the 'valley of death' between innovation and procurement [24].

Individual Expert Reports
[2] James Neufeld Report - AI Task Force.pdf ↑ Back to top

Commercialization is addressed through the observation that while Canadian AI companies such as samdesk excel on the international stage, they struggle to secure government contracts and commercial opportunities at home. The report underscores that Canada is missing out on a significant economic windfall by not commercializing domestic AI innovations effectively. It calls for policies that improve the connection between research and commercialization, ensuring that innovative AI technologies developed in Canada can be successfully scaled and exported while retaining economic sovereignty.

[3] Patrick Pichette Report - AI Strategy Task Force - final.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report calls for a strong link between AI research and commercialization by declaring a national champion. It recommends that Canada declare Cohere as its lead national large language model (LLM) champion, supported with significant multi‐year revenue contracts in both civil and defence sectors as a way to ensure data sovereignty and to reinvent federal services.

It also advocates for the coupling of private sector capital and government initiatives—such as reforming pension fund investments—to create a vibrant ecosystem where research outcomes are rapidly transformed into commercially competitive and globally scalable products, thereby securing economic sovereignty for Canada.

[4] AWAITING CONFIRMATION FROM DMO - Scaling Canadian Global Champions_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

Commercialization challenges are discussed in terms of connecting breakthrough research with viable, scalable business ventures. The report points out that while Canada excels in early-stage funding, there is a significant drop-off in later-stage capital and commercialization support. To address this, it recommends modernizing business incentives such as SR&ED to better tie R&D spending to domestic commercial activities, enhancing reimbursement rates, and aligning tax incentives (including capital gains policies and QSBS-like measures) to support AI firms in scaling and maintaining ownership of intellectual property.

[6] Ajay Agrawal Report - October 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report does not provide a specific focus on the commercialization of AI. While it outlines ambitious public sector ‘moonshot’ projects and highlights the use of performance‐based funding, there is no clear discussion on how to grow globally competitive AI companies or on policies regarding IP ownership and broader market commercialization.

[7] Alex LaPlante Report - AI_Task_Force_Recommendations.pdf ↑ Back to top

Within its discussion on strengthening the innovation ecosystem, the report recommends measures designed to support the commercialization of AI. It calls for making Canada the easiest place to build with AI by bundling sovereign compute, cloud credits, and other supports, while modernizing IP and data policies to ensure startups, scale-ups, and research institutions retain ownership and revenue onshore. The report also stresses the need to refresh tax incentives and optimize the venture capital stack to encourage private investment and bridge the gap between research and commercialization.

[8] Arvind Gupta Report - AI Strategy Task Force Recommendations - Arvind Gupta.docx ↑ Back to top

On the commercialization front, the report suggests measures to support the growth of globally competitive AI companies while retaining Canadian economic sovereignty. It recommends exploring commercialization voucher programs to defray initial costs, addressing regulatory inconsistencies across provinces to reduce overhead, and establishing dedicated funding streams and post-secondary incubation hubs that connect research innovations with market needs. These steps are meant to foster an environment in which academic achievements can efficiently transition to commercially viable products and services.

[9] Ben Bergen Report - 2025-11-01 - CCI's 2025 AI Task Force Submission.pdf ↑ Back to top

Commercialization is addressed as a key missing link in Canada’s current AI strategy. The report stresses that Canada must enable homegrown firms to grow into global players by ensuring they retain ownership of intellectual property and data assets. It calls for reforms in tax and regulatory frameworks and better integration of AI research with commercialization efforts so that Canada can build and commercialize the intangible assets that underpin global economic leadership in AI.

[11] Dan Debow Report - AI Task Force Response.pdf ↑ Back to top

To support the commercialization of AI, the report stresses the importance of creating an economic environment that makes it easy and profitable to build AI-powered companies. It recommends removing friction through tax incentives such as deferred capital gains taxes and increased capital gains exemptions for founders and early employees. Additionally, there is a call to consolidate and simplify existing grant and funding programs (such as SR&ED and IRAP) to support market-based, commercially driven innovation and ensure that research investments translate into viable business outcomes.

[12] Diane Gutiw Report - Canadian AI Strategy Task Force2025-10-31 FINAL.pdf ↑ Back to top

To advance the commercialization of AI, the report proposes linking robust research outputs with downstream, market-ready applications. It underscores the need for a centralized funding portal and a unified investment pool that brings together public sector funds, research grants, and industry investments. This centralization aims to address the current fragmentation in funding and ensure that innovations do not stall at the startup phase due to inconsistent and slow grant-based systems.

Emphasis is also placed on creating clearer IP ownership structures and encouraging partnerships that allow domestic companies to retain economic sovereignty over their innovations. By fostering early connections between academia and industry, and bridging research with strategic business cases, the report outlines a framework where commercialization is accelerated and Canadian companies are better positioned to grow in global markets.

[13] Gail Murphy Report - Submission for October 2025 Sprint of the Federal AI Task Force.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report underscores the importance of connecting breakthrough AI research with industrial and commercial opportunities. It advocates for the establishment of internationally recognized, pre-competitive industrial research and development centers modeled on examples like Imec and Fraunhofer. These centers are intended to serve as incubators where academic excellence translates into innovative solutions, spawns spin‐offs, and supports new company formation while retaining Canadian ownership and intellectual property. The report also highlights supporting mechanisms such as industrial-based PhD programs and dedicated industrial-science positions to ease the transition from research to commercialization.

[14] Ian Rae - AI Task Force Recommendations 7 pages.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report does not directly address the commercialization of AI. There is no detailed discussion on measures to grow globally competitive AI companies, retain intellectual property, or modify the Canadian business environment specifically to unlock AI commercialization.

[15] Ian Rae - AI Task Force submission with appendix.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report discusses commercialization in the context of maintaining Canadian control over key AI assets and intellectual property. It recommends creating a business-friendly regulatory environment that connects cutting-edge AI research with commercial application while ensuring that foreign investments and capital are subject to transparent governance requirements. The emphasis is on protecting Canadian data and IP even as AI companies expand and compete on the global stage.

[?] Louis T├кtu Report - Can AI Strategy Task Force - Louis Tetu - Nov 1st 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

Commercialization is seen as the natural consequence of successfully industrializing AI at home. The report underscores the need for policies that promote the retention of ownership and intellectual property, enabling Canadian AI companies to scale and compete internationally. By linking AI research and innovation with a robust commercialization framework, the strategy aims to support homegrown champions in exporting Canadian-developed technologies and driving global competitiveness.

[17] Marc Etienne Ouimette Report - Cardinal_Policy_AI_Task Force_FINAL.pdf ↑ Back to top

For the commercialization pillar, the report outlines the creation of a commercially viable, energy-backed infrastructure platform through a joint venture model known as the Strategic Adoption Cluster (SAC). It stresses the need for long-term off-take agreements with anchor tenants, integration of domestic compute capabilities with CSP offerings, and structured financial mechanisms that include sovereign loan guarantees and power purchase agreements. These measures are designed to link domestic research and compute investments with market opportunities that protect intellectual property and ensure economic sovereignty.

[18] Mary Wells Report - AI Task force Memo MWells.pdf ↑ Back to top

While the report does not focus exclusively on commercialization, it includes elements that support moving AI innovations from research to market. Initiatives such as the creation of a national problem lab and an AI marketplace are proposed to catalyze Canadian AI development and to connect innovative projects with market opportunities. The development of a public-good AI model and tech stack is also seen as a step toward fostering commercial innovation while maintaining national sovereignty and ensuring ethical practices.

[19] Michael Bowling Report - AI Strategy Task Force Report.pdf ↑ Back to top

Although the report primarily focuses on research and talent, it addresses commercialization indirectly by highlighting the need to prevent the leakage of Canadian-trained researchers to overseas firms. It underscores that breakthrough research—such as that conducted in focused research organizations (FROs)—can serve as a seedbed for startups and spin-off companies. Ensuring that Canada retains its leading researchers is fundamental to linking cutting-edge AI research with commercialization opportunities, thereby maintaining economic sovereignty and global competitiveness.

[20] Michael Serbinis - Research & Talent_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report underscores the importance of linking AI research directly to commercialization by embedding commercialization talent within academic institutions. It recommends placing IP advisors and founders-in-residence in universities to accelerate spinouts before intellectual property or talent migrates abroad. There is also an emphasis on shifting from a grants-only funding model to one that supports SMEs in securing real customers and revenue, as well as encouraging the government to act as a first purchaser of promising Canadian AI research outputs in order to reinforce domestic commercialization channels.

[21] Michael Serbinis Report - Commercialization_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The core focus of the report is on enhancing the early-stage commercialization of Canadian AI innovations. It proposes a 4X increase in the creation of early-stage seed companies by tying fundamental research funding to quantifiable commercialization outcomes—such as spin-outs, patent filings, and industry-partnered projects. Key recommendations include evolving National AI Institutes to integrate commercialization targets and creating a nationally scaled 'research-to-seed' factory modeled on the successful Creative Destruction Lab. The report also advocates for dedicated proof-of-concept funds and challenge programs to foster market-ready solutions.

[24] Sam Ramadori - AI Strategy Task Force Submission - 251101.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report underscores the challenge of translating Canada’s pioneering AI research into domestically commercialized, scalable companies. It critiques existing models such as the IDEaS program for creating a 'valley of death' between innovation and procurement. To address this, the report recommends establishing a Canadian 'In-Q-Tel' model that strategically funds and fast-tracks Canadian companies developing dual-use AI technologies, thereby directly connecting research outputs with commercialization pathways.

[28] Adam Keating Report - AI Task Force Report_ Commercialization (Keating).pdf ↑ Back to top

The report outlines significant changes to tax policies and funding structures in order to spur commercialization of AI. This includes eliminating capital gains disincentives for founders and employees of small businesses, reforming existing tax rules (such as the CCPC criteria) to better suit the current global investment landscape, and even proposing reforms to programs like SR&ED and I‐RAP so that R&D funding decisions are more closely tied to commercial success. These measures are aimed at enabling Canadian AI companies to remain competitive globally while retaining ownership and intellectual property within the country.

[29] Garth Gibson - AI Strategy Task Force Memo.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report underscores the necessity of bridging the gap between AI research and its commercialization, stressing that a vibrant ecosystem requires mechanisms that connect breakthrough research with the creation of globally competitive businesses. It suggests that initiatives like national-scale purchases and dedicated AI compute facilities could lower entry barriers for startups and SMEs. By facilitating immediate deployment and tailored configurations—whether through international Neoclouds or emerging Canadian platforms—the strategy aims to help companies retain ownership of intellectual property and stimulate the commercialization process.

Scaling Champions & Investment

24 of 30 reports addressed this pillar

Executive Summary
Common Themes

Multiple experts emphasize the need to nurture and scale domestic AI champions through coordinated investments, regulatory reforms, and enhanced government support. Many reports call for reforming business incentives, streamlining procurement processes, and establishing dedicated funds (e.g., Canadian Prosperity Fund, National Compute Infrastructure Fund) to ensure that promising domestic AI firms have access to both early-stage and growth-stage capital [2,3,7,9,11,13,14,15,21,28]. They also highlight the importance of building a supportive ecosystem through public–private partnerships, infrastructural investments (such as cloud and data centre build-outs), and strategic alignment between academia, government, and industry to facilitate sustainable scaling and competitive global positioning [4,8,12,17,29].

Another common theme is the critical role of government leadership in creating a stable and enabling business environment. Several reports stress the need for structural changes—such as modernizing tax policies, reforming pension fund and procurement rules, and creating innovation programs with agile funding mechanisms—to counteract the risk of domestic AI innovations being acquired by foreign entities and to reinforce the retention of talent and intellectual property within Canada [3,9,11,21,24]. This multi-pronged approach is seen as essential for bridging the gap between breakthrough research and sustainable commercial growth, ensuring that Canada’s AI champions remain rooted domestically while competing on the global stage [2,7,16,20].

Unique Perspectives

One report proposes a uniquely narrow focus on the defence sector by naming and supporting a national AI defence champion to integrate Canadian values into mission-critical applications, thereby leveraging a strategic niche for global market leadership [2]. Another distinctive idea is the establishment of high-calibre, pre-competitive industrial R&D centers that bring together world-class academic and industry talent to serve as a magnet for both domestic and foreign investments, a targeted recommendation aimed at consolidating Canada’s competitive edge [13].

Additionally, a report offers an innovative perspective by advocating for the creation of a dedicated Indigenous Digital Ecosystem Fund to support Indigenous-led digital transformation. This approach focuses on community-based technical support and capacity building rather than purely commercial scaling, thereby expanding the ecosystem to include underrepresented groups and ensuring inclusive growth in the AI sector [22].

Individual Expert Reports
[2] James Neufeld Report - AI Task Force.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report recommends a strategic focus on scaling domestic AI champions by identifying and promoting national leaders, especially in the defence sector. It suggests that naming and actively supporting a national AI defence champion could not only foster market leadership abroad but also integrate Canadian values into mission-critical applications. Additionally, the report emphasizes enhanced engagement between tech leaders and government decision-makers through structured roundtables and working sessions, aiming to shift the culture from reactive procurement to proactive investment in homegrown innovation.

[3] Patrick Pichette Report - AI Strategy Task Force - final.pdf ↑ Back to top

Building strong, scalable national champions is a central theme in the report. It recommends not only overcapitalizing promising companies like Cohere early on to fuel rapid international growth but also reforming business incentives to ensure that domestic champions can scale sustainably while remaining rooted in Canada.

To attract investment, the report advises structural changes such as reforming pension fund investment rules and streamlining procurement processes to eliminate bureaucratic delays, thereby creating an environment modeled on the successful U.S. venture and startup ecosystems where capital, talent, and government support work in sync.

[4] AWAITING CONFIRMATION FROM DMO - Scaling Canadian Global Champions_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The core focus of the report is on scaling Canadian global AI champions and attracting sufficient investment. It identifies a series of barriers including a deficit of late-stage domestic capital, lack of anchor customer contracts from both the public and private sectors, and insufficiently experienced leadership. It proposes a national '1-10-100' strategy with clearly stated targets for AI centacorns, decacorns, and unicorns to transform Canada’s tech sector. Central recommendations include the creation of a Canadian Prosperity Fund to stimulate late-stage growth, the establishment of governance structures like a Canadian 10x Council, and the implementation of strategic procurement and talent acquisition policies to support domestic scale-ups.

[6] Ajay Agrawal Report - October 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

Though the report’s core focus is on deploying AI to achieve dramatic improvements in public service delivery, it touches on scaling by recommending significant, milestone-based funding for its five moonshots. It underscores the need for rapid, performance-driven experiments and regulatory flexibility to accelerate outcomes. However, there is little emphasis on nurturing private-sector champions or establishing business incentives specifically designed to attract domestic investment in scaling AI ventures.

[7] Alex LaPlante Report - AI_Task_Force_Recommendations.pdf ↑ Back to top

For scaling AI champions and attracting investment, the report underscores the importance of establishing a supportive business environment that enables sustainable scaling of AI ventures. It recommends streamlining incentives such as transparent subsidies and tax credits that are accessible to firms of all sizes, thereby leveling the playing field for new entrants against established players. Additionally, it advocates for policies that bundle funding, procurement opportunities, and immigration fast-tracks to foster the growth of globally competitive AI companies rooted in Canada.

[8] Arvind Gupta Report - AI Strategy Task Force Recommendations - Arvind Gupta.docx ↑ Back to top

Although not extensively detailed, the report addresses scaling industrial champions and attracting investment by advocating for an AI-inspired industrial-innovation strategy. It calls on ISED to identify strategic sectors for targeted, application-oriented research with a clear governance framework to ensure stakeholder alignment. Additionally, recommendations such as a government procurement program and regulatory harmonization are seen as ways to create an ecosystem where strong AI ventures can scale domestically while competing effectively on a global stage.

[9] Ben Bergen Report - 2025-11-01 - CCI's 2025 AI Task Force Submission.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report identifies a critical scale-up problem where innovative Canadian firms are too often acquired by foreign entities, thereby losing spillover benefits. To scale champions, it recommends creating an enabling environment that ensures access to talent, capital, customers, and flexible regulatory frameworks. Specific measures include revamping tax policies, expanding funding channels such as IRAP and leveraging resources from the Business Development Bank of Canada, as well as using public sector adoption as a validation and growth platform for AI-driven innovations.

[10] Cari Covent Report - AI Strategy Task Force Accelerating Adoption FinalOctober31- Covent.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report underscores the need for strong government leadership to scale successful AI initiatives and attract investment. It recommends setting ambitious adoption targets within federal departments and creating a centralized AI Operating Environment to facilitate rapid scaling of proven solutions. Additionally, a federal‑provincial AI adoption compact and a Competitive Innovation Fund are proposed to foster a competitive environment, reward early successes, and create a sustainable ecosystem for Canadian AI champions.

[11] Dan Debow Report - AI Task Force Response.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes entrepreneurial urgency and the need to support scaling champions within the Canadian AI ecosystem. It calls for reforms to government incentives to ensure that Canadian AI companies can access risk capital and retain talent while staying rooted in Canada. Specific proposals include reforming tax rules and easing regulatory burdens to keep the entrepreneurial momentum high. The aim is to create a competitive business environment that not only nurtures emerging AI ventures but also helps them scale successfully on the global stage.

[12] Diane Gutiw Report - Canadian AI Strategy Task Force2025-10-31 FINAL.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report calls for enhancing Canada’s capacity to scale AI ventures and develop stronger industrial champions. It recommends establishing a supportive ecosystem where both domestic and foreign investments are attracted under clear guardrails that protect Canadian IP, talent, and innovation value. Key actions include the promotion of joint investments in focused projects—such as digital twin cities and AI-accelerated drug discovery—which can generate significant economic impact.

Additionally, the report emphasizes the role of public–private partnerships in providing fast procurement pathways and acting as an initial client for AI innovations. By moving funding away from fragmented, grant-based systems and toward a cohesive model that aligns incentives across stakeholders, Canada can create a landscape where its AI champions not only scale sustainably but also maintain deep roots domestically.

[13] Gail Murphy Report - Submission for October 2025 Sprint of the Federal AI Task Force.pdf ↑ Back to top

To scale Canada’s AI champions and attract investment, the report proposes the creation of high-caliber, pre-competitive industrial R&D centers that coalesce world-class academic and industrial talent. These centers would not only consolidate Canada’s expertise but also provide a training ground for highly skilled personnel, thus reinforcing the nation’s competitive edge on the global stage. By showcasing success in targeted domains, these initiatives aim to encourage domestic industrial leadership and serve as a magnet for both domestic and foreign investments in AI innovation.

[14] Ian Rae - AI Task Force Recommendations 7 pages.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report emphasizes the importance of scaling Canadian champions by advocating for a build‐out of sovereign infrastructure that underpins national AI leadership. Key recommendations include the establishment of national cloud and data campus hubs, the creation of a National Compute Infrastructure Fund to provide long-term, low-cost capital for domestic players, and incentives for regional data centre development. These measures aim to empower Canadian-controlled, AI-ready service providers to scale and compete in global markets while remaining rooted in Canada.

[15] Ian Rae - AI Task Force submission with appendix.pdf ↑ Back to top

To scale AI champions and attract investment, the report advises the establishment of a national Compute Infrastructure Fund and other capital incentives that support domestic, AI-ready data centers. It stresses the importance of federal procurement and acting as an anchor tenant to mitigate financial risks and encourage private capital participation. Additionally, there is a call for strategic partnerships—including those with foreign investors under strict governance—to help build and scale industrial champions in the AI domain.

[?] Louis T├кtu Report - Can AI Strategy Task Force - Louis Tetu - Nov 1st 2025.pdf ↑ Back to top

The strategy highlights the importance of nurturing domestic AI champions and attracting both domestic and foreign investment. It calls for aligning policy, regulation, and funding to empower AI companies to scale sustainably while remaining rooted in Canada. Emphasis is placed on supporting business incentives, expanding the AI talent pipeline, and learning from international best practices to secure a strong competitive position in the global tech landscape.

[17] Marc Etienne Ouimette Report - Cardinal_Policy_AI_Task Force_FINAL.pdf ↑ Back to top

Scaling champions and attracting investment is addressed through proposals to build large-scale, investable infrastructure that can serve as a national asset. The SAC is presented as a hybrid public–private venture that not only secures sovereign compute capacity but also creates a scalable commercial platform. The report highlights the importance of attracting institutional investors—such as pension funds and infrastructure banks—through robust governance, long-term renewable energy contracts, and structured financial instruments that reduce risk and encourage private-sector participation. It also underscores the need for the government to enhance its negotiation capacity and technical expertise to secure more favorable investment conditions and global partnerships.

[18] Mary Wells Report - AI Task force Memo MWells.pdf ↑ Back to top

To scale AI champions and attract investment, the report recommends mechanisms that support rapid innovation and sustainable scaling, such as the creation of regulatory sandboxes and a national problem lab. These initiatives are designed to offer a safe zone for testing new ideas, while also integrating trust and safety standards into the procurement processes of government entities. By promoting a "buy Canadian" approach in critical sectors and providing subsidies and incentives to SMEs, the report aims to strengthen domestic AI leadership and secure investment.

[19] Michael Bowling Report - AI Strategy Task Force Report.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report outlines a strategy to scale up Canada’s AI champions through both an expanded AI Chairs program and the establishment of focused research organizations. By increasing the number of chairs by around 40% and boosting funding levels, Canada can enhance its talent factory and produce more world-class researchers. The proposal to create FROs at existing AI Institutes (Vector, Mila, and Amii) aims to foster ambitious, high-impact research teams that can undertake breakthrough projects, provide a platform for sustained innovation, and indirectly attract further domestic and foreign investment by demonstrating Canada’s ability to produce transformative AI advancements.

[20] Michael Serbinis - Research & Talent_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

Although not the central focus of the memo, the report touches on scaling champions by emphasizing that Canada’s research and talent base is the foundation for developing globally competitive companies. It recommends ensuring that breakthroughs remain rooted in Canada through mechanisms that support the translation of academic innovations into commercial ventures. The report suggests that coordinated initiatives—such as acting as the first customer for domestic innovations and embedding commercialization talent into research settings—can help create a robust ecosystem from which national champions can emerge.

[21] Michael Serbinis Report - Commercialization_ A Memo for the Canadian AI Taskforce v1.0.pdf ↑ Back to top

The report provides recommendations aimed at supporting the scaling of AI champions and attracting investment. It suggests modernizing funding mechanisms by upgrading programs like SR&ED and Scale AI to ensure that growing companies retain their IP, headquarters, and critical talent in Canada. In support of scaling, proposed measures include the creation of significant domestic funds—a $2B AI Growth Fund for early-stage rounds and a $5B Canadian Prosperity Fund for later stage scale-ups—to secure follow-on capital and prevent foreign acquisition of Canadian innovations. These steps are intended to build a robust ecosystem where domestic champions can grow and compete globally.

[22] Natiea Vinson - Indigenous AI Education and Skills.pdf ↑ Back to top

Although the report does not directly address strategies for scaling industrial champions or attracting large-scale investment in AI companies, it does recommend the creation of a dedicated national funding mechanism to support Indigenous-led digital transformation. This includes establishing an "Indigenous Digital Ecosystem Fund" and a permanent federal–provincial funding stream to bolster AI literacy and workforce training. These initiatives are aimed at creating stable, long-term funding for community-based technical support and capacity building rather than fostering commercially competitive AI champions per se.

[23] Olivier Blais Report - Ministerial memo for AI adoption across industries and government.pdf ↑ Back to top

The roadmap for scaling AI capability builds on existing innovation programs like SCALE AI. The report calls for these programs to evolve with faster funding rounds, lighter application processes, and a stronger focus on modernizing digital infrastructure as the foundation for scalable AI initiatives. It also suggests that performance-based incentives linked to the successful modernization and ongoing AI adoption should be implemented to ensure that scaled projects translate into sustained impact, thereby nurturing domestic champions while maintaining alignment with global best practices.

[24] Sam Ramadori - AI Strategy Task Force Submission - 251101.pdf ↑ Back to top

Recognizing that Canada’s AI champions often fail to scale domestically, the submission emphasizes the need to bridge the gap between groundbreaking research and sustainable business growth. It recommends modernizing defence procurement to better support small, agile, and low-cost AI ventures, and suggests the creation of investment mechanisms—such as a dedicated strategic investment fund—to ensure Canadian innovators can remain competitive both at home and in global markets.

[28] Adam Keating Report - AI Task Force Report_ Commercialization (Keating).pdf ↑ Back to top

Scaling up AI champions and attracting investment is addressed by urging reforms to business incentives and venture funding frameworks. The report stresses the need to create a supportive environment where startup ecosystems can flourish—calling for aggressive tax reforms, the removal of bureaucratic impediments, and the formation of partnerships between entrepreneurs, industry experts, and policy makers. It also points to the importance of establishing a strong network of domestic AI champions and leveraging both domestic and foreign capital to ensure that Canadian companies can compete with global counterparts while remaining firmly rooted in Canada.

[29] Garth Gibson - AI Strategy Task Force Memo.pdf ↑ Back to top

To scale up Canadian AI champions and attract investment, the report recommends efforts to build larger and more competitive AI industrial players. It identifies the importance of advancing data centre capacities—from currently modest 100 MW facilities towards a staged buildout that could eventually approach gigawatt-scale capacity—all while ensuring that domestic businesses have protected access to compute resources. In addition, it encourages the creation of supportive measures, such as streamlined permitting, incentives for energy efficiency, and dynamic partnership models (including with Indigenous organizations), to foster an environment where domestic companies can scale sustainably and compete globally.

Safe AI Systems & Public Trust

26 of 30 reports addressed this pillar

Executive Summary
Common Themes

Multiple experts emphasize the need for robust frameworks to build safe AI systems that inspire public trust. These frameworks include establishing evidence‐based infrastructures for risk measurement, transparent reporting platforms, independent audits, and certification or trust marks that verify ethical, secure, and accountable AI deployments [1,7,10,11,23]. Many reports advocate for balancing the imperatives of safety and innovation; for instance, several proposals call for risk‐based regulation, innovation sandboxes, and a proportional approach to safety measures in high‐risk sectors such as healthcare, finance, and public services [1,6,12,21].

A second common theme is sovereignty and governance. Several reports underline the importance of data governance—in the form of data or sovereign trusts—and secure infrastructure that supports national control over critical AI resources [3,14,15,16,17]. In addition, a number of experts stress public engagement and educational initiatives, including public awareness campaigns and direct citizen involvement, to demystify AI applications and build enduring public confidence [7,13,27].

Unique Perspectives

Some reports offer innovative ideas that stand out from the broader consensus. For example, one report introduces the concept of a 'sovereign switch' to enable direct regulatory control over networks, compute facilities, and data residency, thereby ensuring national oversight and enhancing public trust in AI systems [16].
