5. Do not invent content - only summarize what is actually in the report

OUTPUT FORMAT (respond with valid JSON only):
{
  "P1": "Summary for Research and Talent...",
  "P2": "Summary for Adoption...",
  "P3": "Summary for Commercialization...",
  "P4": "Summary for Scaling Champions...",
  "P5": "Summary for Building Safe AI...",
  "P6": "Summary for Education and Skills...",
  "P7": "Summary for Infrastructure...",
  "P8": "Summary for Security..."
}

Processing Details

The LLM processes each expert report individually and:

  • Extracts the full text from PDF or DOCX files
  • Analyzes the content against all 8 strategic pillars
  • Generates focused summaries for each relevant pillar
  • Returns empty strings for pillars not addressed in the report

Each pillar includes focus questions to guide the analysis and ensure comprehensive coverage of the strategic areas.

Public Survey Analysis

Analysis of public consultation responses by question and pillar.

Responses Per Question

Total Questions

26

Total Responses

64,637

Question Number Question Text Response Count
Question 1 How does Canada retain and grow its AI research edge? What are the promising areas that Canada should lean in on, where it can lead the world? 3,764
Question 2 How can Canada strengthen coordination across academia, industry, government and defence to accelerate impactful AI research? 3,391
Question 3 What conditions are needed to ensure Canadian AI research remains globally competitive and ethically grounded? 3,636
Question 4 What efforts are needed to attract, develop and retain top AI talent across research, industry and the public sector? 3,226
Question 5 Where is the greatest potential for impactful AI adoption in Canada? How can we ensure those sectors with the greatest opportunity can take advantage? 3,129
Question 6 What are the key barriers to AI adoption, and how can government and industry work together to accelerate responsible uptake? 3,215
Question 7 How will we know if Canada is meaningfully engaging with and adopting AI? What are the best measures of success? 2,923
Question 8 What needs to be put in place so Canada can grow globally competitive AI companies while retaining ownership, IP and economic sovereignty? 2,629
Question 9 What changes to the Canadian business enabling environment are needed to unlock AI commercialization? 2,300
Question 10 How can Canada better connect AI research with commercialization to meet strategic business needs? 2,250
Question 11 How does Canada get to more and stronger AI industrial champions? What supports would make our champions own the podium? 2,164
Question 12 What changes to Canada’s landscape of business incentives would accelerate sustainable scaling of AI ventures? 2,025
Question 13 How can we best support AI companies to remain rooted in Canada while growing strength in global markets? 2,081
Question 14 What lessons can we learn from countries that are successful at investment attraction in AI and tech, both from domestic sources and from foreign capital? 2,177
Question 15 How can Canada build public trust in AI technologies while addressing the risks they present? What are the most important things to do to build confidence? 2,773
Question 16 What frameworks, standards, regulations and norms are needed to ensure AI products in Canada are trustworthy and responsibly deployed? 2,507
Question 17 How can Canada proactively engage citizens and businesses to promote responsible AI use and trust in its governance? Who is best placed to lead which efforts that fuel trust? 2,424
Question 18 What skills are required for a modern, digital economy, and how can Canada best support their development and deployment in the workforce? 2,218
Question 19 How can we enhance AI literacy in Canada, including awareness of AI’s limitations and biases? 2,439
Question 20 What can Canada do to ensure equitable access to AI literacy across regions, demographics and socioeconomic groups? 2,162
Question 21 Which infrastructure gaps (compute, data, connectivity) are holding back AI innovation in Canada, and what is stopping Canadian firms from building sovereign infrastructure to address them? 1,981
Question 22 How can we ensure equitable access to AI infrastructure across regions, sectors and users (researchers, start-ups, SMEs)? 1,745
Question 23 How much sovereign AI compute capacity will we need for our security and growth, and in what formats? 1,674
Question 24 What are the emerging security risks associated with AI, and how can Canada proactively mitigate future threats? 2,195
Question 25 How can Canada strengthen cybersecurity and safeguard critical infrastructure, data and models in the age of AI? 1,870
Question 26 Where can AI better position Canada’s protection and defence? What will be required to have a strong AI defensive posture? 1,739

Research and Talent - Pillar Overview

This view aggregates intents across all questions in this pillar, providing a higher-level perspective on the themes.

Questions in Pillar

4

Main Pillar Themes Across Question Intents

6

Total Responses

14,029

Public Survey Analysis

Comprehensive analysis of ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar

Key Themes
View example

Across the responses, a few central themes stand out. First, there is a strong emphasis on the need to attract, retain, and develop top AI talent through competitive compensation, educational initiatives, and a supportive ecosystem that links academia, industry, and public policy. Respondents repeatedly call for investments in talent pipelines—from scholarships and fellowships to immigration policy adjustments—as well as the creation of innovative research environments that bridge fundamental science and commercialization. Additionally, the need to build robust and secure infrastructure, including domestic compute capacity and data commons, aligns with the broader goal of ensuring economic growth and technological sovereignty. These themes are echoed in responses from intents such as 'Economic Growth, Talent & Commercialization' and 'Talent, immigration & workforce'.

Example Response:

"Canada can grow its AI research edge by encouraging and investing in higher education institutions keeping and attracting researchers and students. Investing in innovation and academia-industry collaboration through well established and mutually beneficial programs. Providing spaces and incentives for the culture to grow and expand."

Main Concerns
View example

Respondents express significant concerns about the risk dimensions of rapid AI advancement. Many are worried about the ethical, environmental, and social implications of AI, emphasizing the potential for unchecked development to result in societal harm. For instance, there is alarm over data sovereignty, the misuse of private computing resources, and the environmental footprint of AI technologies, as well as fears that a lack of robust regulation could leave Canadian interests vulnerable. In parallel, some voices remain skeptical about the overall value of accelerating AI research, indicating that without proper regulatory oversight and safety measures, the dangers could outweigh the benefits. These concerns are reflected in categories like 'AI Skepticism, Environmental & Social Harm Concerns' and 'Skepticism and opposition to AI; calls to slow, regulate, or halt'.

Example Response:

"Everyone is rushing to get more AI without real discussion on the value of it. As of currently, it is a massive resource hog that is environmentally unethical and has little practical value. The big tech giants taut it as a massive boon, but it is clearly feeding the user base incorrect, misleading, and misinformed information- it does so with such unchecked confidence. The massive shift of ai use to social media is going to be both a societal and ecological disaster. The US is already stealing water from Canada's great lakes and with this growth in AI investment and the subsequence increase in water use the great lakes are going to dry up."

Notable Patterns
View example

A notable pattern across the responses is the interplay between competitive ambition and ethical caution. Many respondents highlight that while Canada should aggressively invest in its AI talent and infrastructure to remain globally competitive, it must do so without compromising ethical standards or academic independence. There is also a clear interconnection between calls for sovereign resources (such as in 'Sovereign Compute & Data Infrastructure' and 'Sovereign AI infrastructure & data sovereignty') and the imperative of responsible governance, as seen in the emphasis on transparent and accountable frameworks. Moreover, despite some dissenting voices that are outright skeptical about further AI investments, the majority frame their arguments around creating an ecosystem that is at once innovative, sustainable, and ethically defensible.

Example Response:

"12. Ethical competitiveness starts with integrating governance frameworks like ISO/IEC 27001 and 42001 at the research level. Canada must require explainability, fairness testing, and model auditing as part of all federally supported AI projects. Investments should be made in trustworthy AI tooling and regulatory tech to reduce risk at scale. To stay globally competitive, Canada must ensure research teams have secure, scalable compute (e.g., via Sovereign AI Compute Strategy) and access to high-quality datasets that reflect diverse Canadian contexts."

Public Survey Analysis - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Analyze and synthesize patterns across all survey intent categories for this pillar

About This Analysis

This section provides a comprehensive analysis of ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar. The analysis synthesizes patterns, themes, and concerns across all survey responses that were classified into various intent categories.

Analysis Components

  • Key Themes: Main topics and patterns that emerge across survey responses in this pillar
  • Main Concerns: Primary worries, challenges, or issues raised by respondents
  • Notable Patterns: Interesting trends, unique perspectives, or significant patterns observed in the responses

LLM Query Used

Your task is to analyze the survey responses and provide a comprehensive summary across three dimensions:

1. KEY THEMES: Identify the 3-5 most prominent themes or topics that emerge across all survey responses in this pillar. What are respondents most focused on? What patterns appear across multiple questions? (1-2 paragraphs)

2. MAIN CONCERNS: What are the primary concerns, challenges, or issues raised by respondents? What problems or risks do they highlight? What are they worried about or critical of? (1-2 paragraphs)

3. NOTABLE PATTERNS: Identify any interesting patterns, relationships, or insights that emerge from the data. Are there surprising connections between different intents? Do certain themes appear more frequently than expected? Are there any notable gaps or underrepresented perspectives? (1-2 paragraphs)

IMPORTANT:
- Be specific and cite examples where possible
- Reference specific intent categories by name when relevant
- Focus on substantive insights, not superficial observations
- Maintain the tone and sentiment of the responses (don't sanitize negative feedback)
- Keep each section to 1-2 paragraphs

Additionally, for each dimension, identify ONE intent category and its example response that best illustrates that dimension. Provide the intent name exactly as it appears above.

Respond in JSON format:
{
  "key_themes": "Your analysis here...",
  "main_concerns": "Your analysis here...",
  "notable_patterns": "Your analysis here...",
  "example_key_themes_intent": "Intent Name Here",
  "example_main_concerns_intent": "Intent Name Here",
  "example_notable_patterns_intent": "Intent Name Here"
}

Data Source

This analysis is based on survey responses that were classified into intent categories using an LLM-based classification system. The summary synthesizes insights across all classified responses within this pillar.

Pillar-Level Theme Distribution

These high-level themes capture the main topics across all questions by grouping all intents in this pillar.

Sentiment Analysis
