Pillar-Level Theme Distribution - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Group question-level intents into higher-level pillar themes

About Pillar-Level Themes

Pillar-level themes are created by grouping similar question-level intents across all questions in a pillar. This provides a higher-level view of the main topics being discussed across the pillar.

The LLM analyzes all question-level intents and their descriptions, then creates broader thematic categories that capture the essence of multiple related intents.

LLM Query Used

Please analyze these intents and create 4-6 pillar-level intent categories that:
- Capture the overarching themes across all questions in this pillar
- Are distinct and meaningful
- Cover the breadth of topics in the question-level intents
- Are named clearly and concisely
- **Each pillar intent MUST map to at least 2 different question-level intents** (if a theme only appears in one question, it's too specific for a pillar-level category)
- **PRESERVE THE TONE AND SENTIMENT** of the question-level intents:
  * If question intents express skepticism, opposition, or concerns → pillar intent should reflect that negative/cautious tone
  * If question intents are supportive or positive → pillar intent should reflect that positive tone
  * If question intents are neutral/descriptive → pillar intent should be neutral
  * Do NOT sanitize or neutralize negative sentiments - keep them explicit

Respond in JSON format:
{{
    "pillar_intents": [
        {{
            "name": "Pillar Intent Name",
            "description": "Clear description of what this pillar-level intent represents"
        }},
        ...
    ],
    "mapping": {{
        "Pillar Intent Name": ["Question Intent 1 name only", "Question Intent 2 name only", ...],
        ...
    }}
}}

IMPORTANT: 
- Each question-level intent should map to at least one pillar-level intent
- A question-level intent can map to multiple pillar-level intents if appropriate
- Ensure all question-level intents are included in the mapping
- **Each pillar intent must map to at least 2 question-level intents** - if you find a theme that only appears in one question, either:
  1. Broaden the category to include related intents from other questions, OR
  2. Map that single intent to a broader existing category, OR
  3. If it truly doesn't fit anywhere, it will be automatically added to "Other"
- CRITICAL: Match the tone/sentiment of grouped intents - don't make negative intents sound positive or vice versa!

Question 5

Where is the greatest potential for impactful AI adoption in Canada? How can we ensure those sectors with the greatest opportunity can take advantage?

Total Responses

3,129

Unique Intents

6

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Skepticism, risks & regulation Critical views on AI, including concerns about hype, job losses, privacy, environmental impact, bias, hallucinations, and calls for slow-downs, bans, or stringent regulation. 1,529 48.9%

"There is no potential for impactful AI adoption in Canada. Any adoption of AI for whatever reason is inadvisable. The drawbacks of this insidious technology are so substantial that the only sensible adoption strategy for AI is to not adopt it."

"Before AI is adopted in any of these industries, it's vital to engage in cost-benefit analysis comparing other technological and social options. AI has such a high energy cost, its use needs to be worth the use. As a simple example, spellcheck is an algorhithmic function that is being replaced by AI in some contexts. AI is much less accurate and uses more energy as well: a double loss. What is the need that is being met by adding AI? Thoughtless addition of technology will not bring long-term benefits."

"The greatest potential for AI adoption in Canada is by companies and entities that specialize in surveillance, misinformation, and general immiseration of the populace. It will be put to great use by spammers, scammers, those who want an easy way to inflame tensions via false information, who want to bury citizens under the tyranny of digitized bureaucracy, and imitate your mother's voice to beg for money."
Health care & life sciences AI adoption in healthcare and life sciences, including diagnostics, imaging, drug discovery, population health, elder/care support, and healthcare operations to reduce wait times and improve outcomes. 1,225 39.1%

"Absolutely healthcare. Killing two birds with one stone here – we have growing dismay around healthcare in Canada, due in part to purposeful destruction, misuse of funds and push for privatization, particularly in conservative provinces. Canadiens are unified and wanting better healthcare and most universal healthcare. I have experienced a lifetime of having to use my masters in health science to advocate for myself for various conditions and many are not in the position to do so. AI has significant potential to empower Canadians, lead to significantly more accurate and timely diagnoses, and more accurate plans for treatment. It can help professionals to stay up-to-date rather than patients having to bring research from different parts of the world to educate overworked Canadian medical professionals."

"Two of Canada’s most chronically underfunded but high-impact sectors are healthcare and education. In healthcare, AI can help reduce backlogs, improve diagnostics, and keep Canadians healthier longer (directly boosting productivity and GDP). In education, AI can transform learning at every level: supporting K–12, strengthening post-secondary research and teaching, and enabling rapid upskilling and reskilling as the economy shifts. To ensure adoption, government should pair funding for sector-specific AI pilots with guaranteed compute access, modernized procurement rules, and training programs that help institutions and workers adopt tools quickly. By focusing on health and education, Canada can demonstrate clear public value while building global leadership in AI."

"Because AI has the potential to disrupt, to cause unemployment and unintended consequences, we should define ''impact'' to include societal benefit, and not just economic benefit. For example, non-profit areas such as public health care can benefit significantly from AI. Let's use AI to benefit our society, and not just to make people rich, which is very short-sighted. If unemployment increases as a result of 'impactful AI adoption', fewer people will be participating in and supporting our economy. AI also has an environmental impact, directly and indirectly, and these impacts also need to be factored in. AI that has a high short-term economic benefit, but a high negative impact on the environment and society, for example, should not be supported."
Public sector & governance AI to transform government services, procurement, data governance, privacy protections, open data and sovereign compute, and to support equitable public service delivery (including libraries and education) while managing risk and accountability. 848 27.1%

"Canada’s institutional strength gives it a major advantage in integrating AI across its public and private sectors. The country’s governance framework, regulatory reliability, and digital infrastructure make it easier than most nations to embed AI into daily operations—from public services to industry and research. But to truly capture this opportunity, Canadians must learn to use AI as an extension of their own intelligence, not as a replacement for it. The real potential lies in helping people understand how to harness AI to refine their thinking, process information critically, and apply insights across limitless fields. When citizens learn to leverage AI to amplify—not outsource—their expertise, productivity and creativity rise in tandem. Moreover, in a labor-intensive economy where efficiency challenges persist, AI adoption can alleviate the cost burden of routine or repetitive work, allowing human effort to focus on higher-order tasks. Canada’s future competitiveness depends on cultivating this human-AI synergy: strong institutions, informed citizens, and a workforce that uses technology as a tool for wisdom rather than substitution."

"The federal government needs to lead the way. It can start by analysing every single department, and role with AI and looking for ways to automate. Reduce headcount while improving service where possible and let the public know you're doing so. If people could get answers to questions using AI chatbots and AI powered knowledge bases 24/7 and if government service times for all departments that interface with the public were cut dramatically, meaning using AI to improve customer service became a priority, it would impact almost every Canadian positively."

"As the CEO of Milton Public Library, serving the Town of Milton I am responding to highlight the essential role of public libraries in Canada's AI strategy. Public libraries are trusted, democratic institutions, uniquely positioned to democratize AI literacy and ensure equitable AI adoption amongst all Canadians. We need to ensure all patrons understand AI and how to utilize the tools effectively. It is important that we bridge the digital divide and democratize access. Libraries are trusted institutions, that are committed to privacy protection, intellectual freedom, neutral spaces and are consistently ranked among most trusted institutions."
High-potential sectors (Agriculture, Energy, Manufacturing, Construction, Natural Resources, Logistics) Sectors with large data availability and strong societal/productivity needs where AI can yield clear efficiency gains (agriculture, energy/climate, mining/resource sectors, construction, manufacturing, logistics, public services). 842 26.9%

"Canada’s greatest AI adoption potential lies in sectors that combine economic impact with societal benefit—health care, agriculture, and natural resources. AI can improve diagnostics, optimize crop yields, and enhance sustainability in energy and mining. To ensure these sectors capitalize, we need accessible infrastructure, sector-specific data ecosystems, and funding models that de-risk adoption for smaller players. Partnerships between research institutions and industry, supported by clear regulatory guidance, will accelerate responsible deployment and deliver measurable value."

"Canada’s greatest AI potential lies in healthcare, agriculture, construction, and financial services, where efficiency gains and innovation can drive national competitiveness. To unlock this, Canada must ensure SME access to compute and expertise, foster cross-sector testbeds, and provide targeted incentives and regulatory clarity. Scaling proven use cases—like medical diagnostics, crop optimization, or financial forecasting—into broader adoption will maximize societal and economic impact."

"Canada's greatest AI potential is in sectors vital to national resilience: Physical Sovereignty (agriculture, construction), Human Sovereignty (health care), and Economic Sovereignty (supply chains). AI can optimize crop yields, design resilient infrastructure, accelerate drug discovery, and build shock‐proof supply chains. Unlocking this potential requires a 'National Digital Proving Ground'—a sovereign AI commons with secure compute and curated public datasets—and mission-oriented Grand Challenges that leverage Canada’s unique geographic and resource strengths."
Foundational AI infrastructure & enablement Investments in horizontal AI infrastructure and enablement (sovereign compute, data trusts, data interoperability, open platforms, pilots, procurement frameworks) to empower all sectors to adopt AI responsibly. 635 20.3%

"The potential is economy-wide across health care, construction, agriculture, finance and insurance, energy, transportation, and small and mid-sized businesses. Abroad, privacy posture shapes adoption: Korea enforces strict privacy with broad deployment; Japan is similar with more flexibility; China prioritises state interests and localisation, trading off privacy. To help high-opportunity sectors move quickly and responsibly, Canada should: • Set default Canadian residency and jurisdiction for publicly funded or sensitive workloads. • Build evidence by design: data maps, consent, model/version/testing, inference logs. • Use standard contracts; Canada-hosted compute with logging and customer-controlled keys. • Provide fixed-fee assurance for smaller organisations; enforce controls (access, backups, monitoring). • Require technology errors and omissions and cyber/privacy insurance to fund response, regulatory engagement, restoration, and loss recovery."

"Conditions for Competitive & Ethical Canadian AI 1) Infrastructure National compute fabric + secure data trusts Open model/evaluation commons; standardized APIs Procurement fast lanes for mission pilots (health, climate, defence) 2) Talent Joint appointments & rotations (acad ↔ industry ↔ public/defence) Skills pipelines (MLOps, safety, compliance), founder pathways Stable, multi-year funding tied to clear KPIs 3) Governance & Ethics Standards-first (ISO/IEC, NIST, ITSG-33/PBMM) Independent ethics/safety boards; COI & publication rights (brief review only) Risk-tiered controls, red-teaming, secure deployment (SBOM, audit logs) 4) Impact Alignment Mission portfolios with outcome KPIs (wait-times, emissions, resilience, productivity) Regional clusters (labs + SMEs + integrators) Public dashboards for progress, safety incidents, and adoption Bottom line: Build shared infrastructure, rotate talent, enforce independent governance, and fund toward measurable public and economic outcomes."

"The greatest potential is not in a single, government-selected vertical like healthcare or agriculture. While important, this top-down “industrial strategy” has historically failed. The real opportunity lies in a horizontal strategy: making Canada the world’s premier provider of the foundational ingredient of AI—secure, sustainable, and cost-effective compute power. By leading in compute, Canada creates a rising tide that lifts all sectors simultaneously. How to Ensure Broad Advantage: Massive Scale for Broad Access: A single government-subsidized facility will always be too small and bureaucratic. The Grand Bargain—attracting multiple hyperscale AI data centers—creates a competitive domestic compute market. This drives down costs and ensures access not only for startups but also for legacy industries like construction, manufacturing, and natural resources that need AI to modernize. A Platform for Sector-Specific Innovation: With abundant, world-class infrastructure, Canadian companies in every field can build their own AI models. Banks can advance forecasting, agriculture can optimize yields, and healthcare can leverage unique Canadian data securely. The government’s role is not to build these tools, but to ensure the platform exists on Canadian soil. Accelerated Adoption Through Proximity: Hosting global AI leaders in Canada creates a “centre of gravity” effect. Their platforms, expertise, and partner ecosystems will embed directly into our economy, giving Canadian SMEs easier access to world-class capabilities without relying on distant hubs like Silicon Valley. Conclusion: The best way to maximize AI adoption across sectors is not by picking winners but by winning the infrastructure race. If Canada becomes the global leader in compute, every industry gains the foundation to win in its own application domain."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 96 3.1%

"Focusing on innovation and understanding the KNOWLEDGE ECONOMY more broadly. It is not just about AI. It's about innovation and knowledge transference in a competitive industry. In order for Canada to be competitive, we actually have to foster competition here and move away from a monopoly or oligopoly driven economy. Be attractive to companies by being willing to invest money and help them sustain a base in Canada. Take the subsidies out of fossil fuels and the energy sector and invest in knowledge—move away from being a resource-focused nation only and focus on the next sector. Extraction is a dying dinosaur industry."

"The greatest potential for impactful AI adoption in Canada lies in sectors where innovation-driven SMEs can thrive and compete globally. These include software development, entertainment (film, television, and gaming), creative industries, digital media, clean technology, biotechnology, and professional services. These sectors naturally foster entrepreneurial ecosystems, have lower barriers to entry, and reward rapid innovation over established market power, making them ideal for AI-enabled transformation and growth."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive
44.1%
1,379
neutral
17.0%
531
negative
39.0%
1,220

Question 6

What are the key barriers to AI adoption, and how can government and industry work together to accelerate responsible uptake?

Total Responses

3,215

Unique Intents

8

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Skepticism and Opposition to AI Adoption Responses that advocate against accelerating AI uptake, express distrust or rejection of AI as a beneficial technology, or call for restrictive, cautious, or halted adoption due to ethical, environmental, or social concerns. 1,603 49.9%

"AI adoption is not a net good, it's essentially a scam being pushed on Canadians by people who are over-leveraged in tech. There is no value to Canadians from widespread adoption of AI."

"AI is a huge bubble, and the government should not take steps to accelerate uptake of AI. AI is a funny little tool to use for personal use, but has very limited needs-based usages for the average Canadian. While it can be used in positive ways (ie making things more accessible for those living with disabilities), any steps the government takes to encourage its uptake at the enterprise level will almost exclusively be used to drive unemployment (via automation) to the benefit of shareholders and detriment of Canadians. This is not something the country needs more of. If AI starts replacing working people in the economy, they should be taxed like a working person in the economy. The copyright act should also be updated to specifically speak to IP rights in AI systems. An AI should not be available for commercial purchase unless it has been certified by a regulatory body that the AI itself, and 100% of its training data was acquired by either license, or was already in the public domain. In other words, no for-profit entity operating in Canada should be able to sell access to a system that was built using stolen intellectual property."

"AI is a dead-end technology at best, and the world's greatest technology hoax at worst. Generative models and their creators have repeatedly shown that they have no regard for the rules of law, copyright, ethics, creativity, or the environment. AI researchers have mostly all agreed that the current approach to large language models has reached its limit. Without a significant lateral breakthrough, this technology will not improve beyond confidently lying whenever asked a question. Banks and economists worldwide are quickly coming to the realization that the AI industry as a whole is a bubble. It has not delivered on any of its promises, and only grows as a consequence of circular investment between the leading AI companies. The US especially has heavily bet on AI, with 40% of their GDP being tied up in AI companies who, so far, have shown no benefit to society and generated no return on investment. When the bubble bursts, Canada should be economically self-sufficient to weather that storm, not tie us further to the sinking ship."
Strategic Focus and Value Proposition This category emphasizes the need for a strategic approach to AI adoption, focusing on demonstrating clear, practical benefits and real-world use cases, distinguishing AI hype from proven value, and prioritizing Canadian-owned infrastructure, talent, and IP to avoid foreign dominance and foster domestic growth. 1,095 34.1%

"Key barriers to AI adoption include high compute/data costs, talent shortages outside hubs, weak lab-to-market pathways, trust/regulatory uncertainty, procurement biases toward foreign vendors, and fragmented rules across provinces that create red tape and slow scaling. Government can expand sovereign green compute, harmonize interprovincial standards, support secure data trusts, and adopt “AI First” procurement to back Canadian solutions. Industry should co-fund pilots and testbeds with academia. Through clusters like SCALE AI and cross-province consortia, Canada can cut barriers, align regulation, and accelerate responsible AI adoption nationwide."

"Today, the biggest barrier is lack of understanding and coordinated planning. AI adoption is often haphazard, with leadership moving one way and employees another, and few organizations have a real strategy. Government and industry can address this by funding training, playbooks, and sector-specific adoption roadmaps that align leadership and workforce. Looking ahead, the next major barrier will be compute and infrastructure access. As demand grows, SMEs and even large institutions will face scarcity and costs. To prepare, Canada should invest now in sovereign compute capacity and create grant programs to ensure broad access, so adoption doesn’t stall once strategy gaps are solved."

"American tech companies have convinced investors that LLMs are the only form of AI where in my view it is the least useful. The Government of Canada should push back on the use of LLMs and encourage Canadian companies to adopt a wider range of AI products. Google, Facebook and Amazon made their money using discriminative AI to target ads not generative AI to make cheap ad copy."
Privacy, Intellectual Property, and Data Governance Intentions and concerns related to data privacy, data sovereignty, data sharing, and IP/copyright issues; calls for governance that protects creators and citizens, as well as standards and accountable deployment. 986 30.7%

"Key barriers to AI adoption include unclear IP ownership, high implementation costs, limited access to quality data, and liability concerns—issues that disproportionately affect SMEs. Government and industry can accelerate uptake by co-investing in shared infrastructure, creating sector-specific data trusts, and offering targeted incentives. Most importantly, Canada should lead in defining clear rules on AI-generated content and IP rights, ensuring businesses know what they can own and protect. Coupled with harmonized regulations and workforce training, this clarity will build trust and drive responsible adoption."

"One barrier that is key in my industry, the arts, is copyright. AI is often trained without permission on the work of other artists, which is theft. This leads to uninspired, recycled work that will continue to spiral downward, circling the drain in endless rehashes of things we have seen before."

"The key barrier to AI adoption is a crisis of trust, rooted in three core challenges: 1. The Liability Gap. For Small to Medium-Sized Enterprises (SMEs), the legal and financial risk of deploying a black-box AI is an insurmountable barrier. A single catastrophic failure could be an extinction-level event. 2. The Data Sovereignty Dilemma. Businesses are rightly hesitant to feed their most sensitive proprietary data into AI systems controlled by foreign entities, risking IP theft and competitive disadvantage. 3. The Black Box Problem. A lack of transparency in how AI systems make decisions erodes public trust and makes accountability impossible, creating a chilling effect on adoption in critical sectors like healthcare and justice. To accelerate responsible uptake, government and industry must forge a new "Covenant of Verifiability." The government's role is to provide a "National Digital Proving Ground"—a sovereign, sandboxed environment with access to anonymized public datasets. Within this trusted space, SMEs can safely test, validate, and benchmark AI solutions against government-defined standards for safety, fairness, and performance before deploying them in the wild. Industry's role is to build on this "Glass Box" platform. The government can incentivize this by offering "Safe Harbor" provisions, providing liability protection for companies whose AI systems have been rigorously certified within the national proving ground. This model transforms the relationship from one of adversarial regulation to collaborative hardening. It de-risks innovation for SMEs, protects data sovereignty, and builds public trust through a shared, transparent, and verifiable process."
Economic Impact and Workforce Transformation Concerns about job loss, wage stagnation, and the need for workforce transformation, upskilling, and social protections; emphasizes that adoption should be tied to real productivity gains and worker support. 839 26.1%

"Many workers, especially in smaller businesses or those with lower literacy, lack the skills to use AI tools confidently. Adult literacy and digital upskilling programs are crucial for widening access. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) often struggle with the cost of adopting AI, including buying technology, training staff, or accessing expertise. Companies need access to good data while respecting privacy and security rules. Government and industry can partner to fund training, especially adult literacy and AI upskilling, to ensure workers and managers gain the skills they need. Develop clear standards and guidelines for AI safety, liability, and transparency, so organizations feel secure adopting new tools.Encourage partnership pilot projects that help industries test AI uses in real-world settings and scale up what works."

"Responsible uptake should involve mitigation strategies for job replacements. Currently, companies are trying to replace entry-level tasks like data management with AI tools, but this in turn reduces opportunities for recent graduates to enter the workforce. The Canadian government should enact labour policy that ensures its population is able to start their careers without the threat of AI replacement, in order to prevent future economic crises of large-scale unemployment and lack of career development. Until the AI bubble ‘bursts,’ we recommend implementing quotas for large companies that would mandate a certain proportion of hiring new graduates to ensure this AI uptake issue does not evolve into a long-term economic problem."

"There need to be more skilled migrants coming to Canada who understand computer science and AI. This is not just for the companies here that build AI, but for all companies that want to leverage or adopt AI to increase their productivity. Software engineers with AI development knowledge can be deployed to many industries and build bespoke AI solutions that help solve productivity problems for each domain."
Infrastructure, Data, and Financial Accessibility This category addresses the practical and financial barriers to AI adoption, including the need for robust computing infrastructure, sustainable energy, quality data access, and financial support (especially for SMEs) to overcome cost barriers. 734 22.8%

"I think the biggest barriers are a mix of liability uncertainty, lack of trust, and the simple fact that small and mid-sized enterprises don’t have the capital or expertise to deploy AI responsibly. Government and industry should work together to de-risk adoption: things like shared infrastructure, tax credits for AI adoption, and standardized frameworks for liability and risk would go a long way. To me, the opportunity is less about building flashy demos and more about creating the conditions—funding, rules, and trust—that make everyday companies confident enough to integrate AI into their operations."

"Key barriers to AI adoption include high costs of infrastructure, limited access for small and medium enterprises, uncertainty over liability, and public mistrust due to ethical risks. Government and industry can address these by sharing compute and data resources, offering incentives that lower adoption costs, and setting clear, fair liability frameworks. Education and upskilling are essential so people feel empowered, not replaced. Most importantly, policies must prioritize responsible use—guarding against bias, misuse, and harm—so adoption reflects both wisdom and compassion. When justice, transparency, and service guide innovation, barriers become opportunities for collective flourishing."

"Build 5 National UBER Massive Data centers that CANADIAN CITIZENs ONLY entrepreneurs, individuals and researchers can access Atlantic Canada, Quebec, Ontario, Alberta and BC. Leave the rest to the private sector. They will take care of it."
Technical Limitations and Reliability Doubts Critique of AI's current technological capabilities, including hallucinations, inaccuracies, and unreliable outputs 625 19.4%

"One key barrier is that generative AI still "hallucinates". Companies are learning not to trust AI models with independent authority; see for example Air Canada being held liable for what their customer service AI mistakenly offered to a customer. Another key barrier is that AI companies do not typically take legal responsibility for the correctness of their models' output, which means that a high‐skilled human (engineer, lawyer, doctor, etc) is needed to approve AI-generated work. It is often more difficult to properly check for errors than to do the work oneself; when humans work in a purely overseeing capacity, our attention tends to drift, and skills atrophy. This is why partially-self-driving cars are more dangerous than fully-human-driven cars, for example. Also, the government should not make an explicit goal of accelerating AI uptake. The government's goal should be to increase productivity; AI uptake may be a means to that end, but some applications may be counterproductive."

"The biggest barrier is the fact that AI still makes too many errors and is too unreliable for most uses. It works best in the sciences, where it can generate ideas that can then be checked. The second biggest barrier is the responsibility gap, where both our legal system and internal methods within companies of measuring performance cannot account for the relationship between workers and AI."

"Silicon Valley’s “Replacing Engineers With LLMs” Story Is A Lie If you believe the New York Times or other outlets that simply copy and paste whatever Dario Amodei says, you’d think that the reason that software engineers are having trouble finding work is because their jobs are being replaced by AI. This grotesque, abusive, manipulative and offensive lie has been propagated throughout the entire business and tech media without anybody sitting down and asking whether it’s true, or even getting a good understanding of what it is that LLMs can actually do with code. Members of the media, I am begging you, stop doing this. I get it, every **** is willing to give a quote saying that “coding is dead,” and that every executive is willing to burp out some nonsense about replacing all of their engineers, but I am **** begging you to either use these things yourself, or speak to people that do. However, most of the advancements in programming languages, technique, and craft in the last 40 years have been designing safer and better ways of tying these blocks together to create larger and larger programs with more complexity and functionality. Humans use these advancements to arrange these blocks in logical abstraction layers, so we can fit an understanding of the layers' interconnections in our heads as we work, diving into blocks temporarily as needed. This is where the AIs fall down. The amount of context required to hold the interconnections between these blocks quickly grows beyond the AIs’ effective short term memory (in practice, much smaller than its advertised context window size), and the AIs lack the ability to reason about the abstractions as we do. This leads to real-word code that's illogically layered, hard to understand, debug, and maintain."
Environmental and Resource Concerns Responses highlighting the environmental footprint of AI infrastructure (data centers, energy and water use, cooling requirements) and broader ecological risks as barriers to uptake. 557 17.3%

"The key barriers to AI adoption are that it requires massive amounts of energy and fresh drinking water for its data centres. The idea that you would adopt this strategy when there are indigenous communities all over Canada that still do not have clean drinking water is unconscionable."

"AI adoption also depends on resources such as energy-heavy data centres and water usage. Figure out how to power these data centres with renewables. Solar or Wind. The faster this is done, the safer our planet will be. AI is useless if we have no planet left."

"Let's start with the ecosystem supports. Suppose we establish rules that every AI venture be properly and publicly costed with full ecosystem costs included - water, electricity, and the opportunity costs of not having water and electricity available for alternative projects. That would be perceived as a barrier by many, yet it seems to me to be simply a prime example of responsible regulation."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 78 2.4%

"public AI literacy is a majour impediment, ensuring that a diversity of Canadians can participate in the dialog on AI, means enablking and empowering them to participate. This starts with education."

"We have one type of school. It is a time-based school which does not fit many (most) learners. Here is a different model that we must adopt: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-MTRxRO5SRA&t=1s"

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive
18.4%
591
neutral
15.0%

negative
66.6%
2,142

Question 7

How will we know if Canada is meaningfully engaging with and adopting AI? What are the best measures of success?

Total Responses

2,923

Unique Intents

7

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Adoption & Measurement Focuses on how to measure meaningful adoption and impact of AI, including metrics from pilot to production, time-to-value, sector-specific improvements, productivity, and dashboards that track progress over time. 1,481 50.7%

"I think we’ll know Canada is truly engaging with AI when it goes beyond experiments and pilots and starts to show up in core workflows. Success should be measured by whether AI tools are integrated into how hospitals deliver care, how mid-sized businesses run their supply chains, and how governments provide services. The metrics I’d watch are adoption rates in high-value sectors, productivity improvements, and whether those gains are widely distributed across the economy. If AI becomes something only a handful of big firms leverage, we’ve missed the point."

"Success is measured by adoption depth: from pilot projects (experimentation) to enterprise-wide use (integration) to productivity and competitiveness gains (transformation). Indicators include AI-driven GDP growth, sector-specific benchmarks (e.g., reduced wait times in healthcare, yield gains in agriculture), SME adoption rates, talent retention, and global ranking in responsible AI research and commercialization."

"Use the TTHW metric: 'Time to Hello World'. The benefit of this metric is it is verifiable but also flexible, and aligned to real user adoption. In each sector, have industry associations set a series of 'baseline use cases' incorporating common business processes or tasks with related test and verification data sets. Ensure that AI/LLM tools are incorporated in the business processes or tasks. Next, perform monitored tests with sample users to see how quickly they can successfully accomplish each baseline use case to the verified standard. This is called 'getting to Hello World'. If the time it takes is 15 minutes or less, the test passes. If it hovers around 6 or 7 minutes, it's probably excellent adoption. You will have proven, in a verifiable industry-specific way, that motivated users are a few minutes away from performing their tasks, using AI. But if users are unable to get a TTHW of < 15 minutes, the industry association needs to figure out how to improve the results/adoption."
Public Good & Social Outcomes Emphasizes outcomes that improve well-being, equity, health, education, environment, culture, and trust—measured by real-life benefits to Canadians rather than sheer deployment numbers. 1,137 38.9%

"Canada is meaningfully engaging with AI when: • Public-sector deployments are transparent, auditable, and aligned with civic values • Citizens understand and shape AI systems through education and feedback channels • Research funding prioritizes safety, ethics, and open science • Talent is retained across academia, industry, and government • Environmental and social impact disclosures are standard practice • AI tools demonstrably improve public services, healthcare, and climate resilience • Regulatory frameworks are enforced and evolve with technology Success is measured by public trust, civic impact, ethical benchmarks, and long-term resilience—not just commercial growth."

"I believe the metric that Canada is succeeding (meaningly engaging and adopting AI) will be when adoption is ethical, trusted, and widespread. A key measure is whether creators’ rights, consent, control, and fair pay, are respected. True progress means Canadians see AI strengthening industries without exploitation."

"I believe real success in AI will come when it becomes a normal part of how young people learn, think, and create. Seeing students design their own AI projects—using the technology for social good rather than competition—would be a turning point for Canada. The goal should not only be to outpace others but to build a collective, ethical culture of innovation. AI should be a community tool that enhances collaboration, problem-solving, and creativity across society. To make that possible, we need strong legal and ethical foundations: clear AI and copyright laws that protect creators’ data and ideas, and education that teaches respect for intellectual and digital integrity from an early age. The next generation should grow up seeing AI not as a threat or shortcut, but as a shared instrument for building a fairer, more intelligent, and more connected world."
Skepticism / Anti-AI Represents responses that are opposed to AI adoption or hold the view that AI should be halted, regulated stringently, or avoided due to harms (environment, jobs, misinformation, ethics). 987 33.8%

"The best measure of success is complete abandonment of AI."

"No to AI. As technology cannot be held accountable for its decisions, it should never be in a position to make decisions that impact real people. No to AI."

"We will know if we are meaningfully engaging with AI the moment we legislate it into nonexistence. Keep Canada AI Slop Free!"
Regulation, Governance & Safety The presence of rules, governance frameworks, safety, transparency, accountability, and protecting citizens’ rights in AI deployment, including data protection and auditability. 753 25.8%

"The best measure of success would be the development of a comprehensive regulatory framework, not metrics on adoption."

"We’ll know Canada is serious about AI when it’s used fairly and safely in everyday life, not just in big experiments. Success means protecting people’s rights, keeping jobs safe, and stopping things like deepfakes and misinformation. The private sector should be free to innovate quickly, especially to build tools that detect AI in sound and video, so we can stay ahead of misuse."

"How many women have had deepfakes photos or videos of themselves released on the internet? How many men are using AI chatbots to denigrate and deride women? How many people of colour don't show up accurately or face bias in image-based AI programs? How many immigrants are targeted by harmful AI algorithms? How well paid are the staff at the data centres? How is my data protected from sale and how can the Canadian government guarantee that? How much energy do these data centres consume and how are you mitigating that? These are the only benchmarks that matter to me. If you cannot create safeguards for the people using the tech and instead adopt it blindly as is, the engagement will never be meaningful or successful for everyone."
Research & Talent Development Emphasizing AI research, talent retention, and building a robust Canadian AI ecosystem 362 12.4%

"Success: We will have a population that is more fluent in AI ethics as a result of education and critical thinking. When we have Canadian researchers that are paid for grant writing and proposals. It is huge work and polytechnics and college expect this to be done on top of your workload. Only once you get the grant will they buy you out. Universities give up front reduced workloads to account for proposals etc. When we understand that we are losing existing IP due to many factors - and we find ways to attract/retain Canadians with aggressive funding. Private sector should have open grants available from government. Like the Canada Arts Council, have the Canada AI council. Any domain can apply."

"Success would be best measured by the health of our computer sciences sector; we need to attracting new talent; retaining talent; and encouraging up and coming students to join the field. LLM based AI is just one very small portion of a much broader field, and laser focusing on this singular aspect of the field will be disastrous in the long term; as it would be for any field where resources are not spread out adequately across all levels and aspects."

"We need to measure AI *critical* literacy--in other words the level of understanding of the broad human, social, political, and economic impacts of AI in society. We can measure this through: -The number of university courses offering critical analysis of AI -the number of students enrolled in such courses -the amount of TriCouncil funding devoted to critical AI -The number of university researchers engaged in studying critical AI or AI impacts (including negative impacts) -The number of student-focussed events and clubs focussed on critical aspects of AI -the proportion of submissions to, and participants in, government consultations and parliamentary committee hearings from academics and other civil society organizations (versus industry and government participants)"
Sovereignty & Domestic Capability Focuses on Canadian control over AI infrastructure, compute, data sovereignty, and domestic capability—emphasizing sovereignty, Canadian platforms, and data staying in Canada. 182 6.2%

"Success should not be measured by vanity metrics like the number of startups or papers published. These track activity, not outcomes, and too often signal value that ultimately accrues outside Canada. The real test is whether we are creating and retaining economic value here. Key Measures of Success: Headquarter Retention Rate: The most important metric. What share of Canadian-founded AI firms that raise Series B/C rounds remain headquartered here five years later? Retention shows systemic health; flight signals failure. Domestic Late-Stage Venture Capital: The volume of $50M+ rounds led by Canadian institutional investors, especially pension funds, into Canadian-domiciled firms. This measures our ability to fund winners ourselves rather than relying on U.S. capital that pulls companies south. Private Sector Infrastructure Investment: Annual capital expenditure by global and domestic firms into AI-grade data centers and compute facilities on Canadian soil. This reflects our attractiveness as a true global AI platform. Growth in High-Value Decision-Making Jobs: Not just junior roles, but VPs of Engineering, Chief Product Officers, and other senior leadership positions located in Canada. These roles determine where the corporate “brain” of AI resides. National Productivity Growth: The ultimate proof. Meaningful adoption will show up as measurable productivity gains in non-tech sectors like manufacturing, agriculture, logistics, and resources. Conclusion: Canada will know it is winning when our AI ecosystem retains its headquarters, funds its own scale-ups, builds its own infrastructure, creates senior leadership jobs, and drives measurable productivity growth across the economy. Anything less means we are subsidizing R&D for others."

"Track adoption of Canadian-built, sovereignty-focused AI infrastructure across government, healthcare, and business. If federal agencies and provinces are running AI on Canadian infrastructure with Canadian data staying in Canada, that's meaningful engagement. If they're still defaulting to US cloud providers and foreign AI platforms, we're not really adopting, we're just consuming someone else's AI. Also, small business and solo developer access. If AI tools are only accessible to corporations with massive budgets, adoption isn't meaningful. Success means a small business in Saskatoon or a solo dev in Halifax can access and deploy AI without requiring a data center budget or giving up data sovereignty to foreign platforms."

"If Canada can think of this for the long term and not the short term in eco sustainablity. Proper planning on where to put the server farms that don't impeede or full out destroy our clean drinking water and not on indigenous owned land like the pipeline. Though I highly doubt our current government officials will care."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 73 2.5%

"When other countries look to us for leadership and guidance"

"The measure of success would be the change in narrative of the media and how other countries start to view Canada as a place which is investing in and using meaningful AI to make the country better."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

1,174

Commercialization of AI - Pillar Overview

This view aggregates intents across all questions in this pillar, providing a higher-level perspective on the themes.

Questions in Pillar

3

Main Pillar Themes Across Question Intents

6

Total Responses

7,184

Public Survey Analysis

Comprehensive analysis of ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar

Key Themes
View example

Across the responses, several key themes emerge. First, there is a strong focus on building a resilient ecosystem through public funding, capital, and domestic growth, where respondents emphasize the need for structured incentives, grants, and investor tax credits to support Canadian AI companies. Many participants stress the importance of government involvement not only as a funder but also as a strategic connector, ensuring that capital flows remain within Canada and that commercialization initiatives are tightly linked to national priorities. A second theme is the emphasis on sovereignty, intellectual property (IP) retention, and data governance. Respondents call for clear policies and frameworks that ensure Canadian ownership of critical AI technologies, with explicit mechanisms to prevent IP flight to foreign powers. Finally, there is a notable emphasis on nurturing local talent and fostering an innovation ecosystem where research meets practical commercialization, highlighting a need for better alignment between academic research and market needs.

Example Response:

"Create a federal investor tax credit so Canadians fund Canadian AI companies at scale, with matching public dollars tied to keeping IP and headquarters in Canada. Push Canadian pension funds to allocate more money at home, not just as a recommendation but as an action, so long-term Canadian capital builds Canadian companies. Prioritize Canadian AI in government buying so companies get revenue and proof points here first. Lock in ownership and IP. Require Canadian IP holding entities for funded projects, clear IP rules in university-SME deals where the company keeps commercial rights, and clawbacks if IP is moved offshore. Fund sovereign compute and storage in Canada, enforce data residency for critical sectors, and set practical security standards that companies can meet. Help companies scale globally without selling out by streamlining visas, expanding SR&ED and commercialization credits, and co-investing with Canadian institutions so founders can raise growth capital while retaining control."

Main Concerns
View example

Respondents express primary concerns around the risks associated with losing control over domestic AI innovations, including fears of IP transfer and foreign dominance. There is apprehension that without clear policies and incentives, valuable Canadian AI assets could be exploited by external entities, weakening national competitiveness. Additionally, many responses highlight ethical and regulatory uncertainties surrounding AI commercialization. A significant number of contributors, as seen in the 'Skepticism / Opposition to AI' and 'Anti-AI / Caution & Ban' intents, underline issues such as data misuse, energy inefficiency, and potential negative societal impacts including privacy infringements and cultural degradation. These concerns point to a need for a balanced approach that protects public interests without stifling innovation.

Example Response:

"When we use generative AI, we consent to the appropriation of our intellectual property by data scrapers. We stuff the pockets of oligarchs with even more money. We abet the acceleration of a social media environment that everyone admits is making life worse. We accept the further degradation of an already degraded educational system. We agree that we would rather deplete our natural resources than make our own art or think our own thoughts. We dig ourselves deeper into crises that have been made worse by technology, from the erosion of electoral democracy to the intensification of climate change. We condone platforms that not only urge children to commit suicide, they instruct them on how to tie the noose."

Notable Patterns
View example

One interesting pattern is the convergence of themes across seemingly divergent intent categories. For example, while some responses emphasize aggressive financial support and domestic growth (as seen in 'Public Funding, Capital and Domestic Growth' and 'Capital, Incentives & Financing'), others make a strong case for respecting Canadian sovereignty and maintaining stringent IP protection (as seen in 'Sovereignty, IP and Data Retention' and 'IP, data sovereignty, and domestic ownership'). This convergence reflects a broader consensus that economic strength in the AI domain must be coupled with robust regulatory safeguards. Additionally, there appears to be a dichotomy in public sentiment: on one hand, calls for proactive commercial strategies and industry-government collaborations, and on the other, deep-seated skepticism and caution regarding AI’s societal impacts. This contrast underscores the complexity of public opinion and the need to address multiple stakeholder interests in policy design.

Example Response:

"Canada should hard-wire a sovereign commercialization pipeline that takes ideas from lab to market under Canadian control. Government’s role: (1) fund and operate mission-driven field labs (life sciences, energy, defence, justice) co-led by a university PI and a Canadian prime contractor, with shared datasets, on-shore compute, and clear “path-to-procurement” gates; (2) expand an SBIR-style program with outcome-based contracts that move winners into production in ministries, hospitals, utilities, and defence. Tie all public support to IP residency (Canadian HoldCo for model weights, datasets, patents) with global revenue captured via non-exclusive licences, not IP transfer. Reform tech-transfer so spin-outs get founder-friendly equity and standardized sovereign licences. Stand up sector data trusts and a registry of Canadian LLMs/SLMs and fine-tuned vertical models hosted on Canadian servers, plus compute credits so startups can build here, not on U.S. clouds. Require open standards, model cards, auditable pipelines, and PIPEDA-plus clauses to de-risk adoption; pair this with a safety/privacy certification that unlocks insurance and liability safe harbours for early deployments. To bridge research and adoption at scale, Canada should also develop a shared sovereign application layer—a standardized, privacy-preserving interface where researchers, businesses, and governments can access, test, and deploy multiple models securely under Canadian jurisdiction. This layer would serve as the missing bridge between innovation and commercialization, ensuring Canadian discoveries move from lab to market without exposing data or IP to foreign systems, transforming research excellence into lasting national advantage."

Public Survey Analysis - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Analyze and synthesize patterns across all survey intent categories for this pillar

About This Analysis

This section provides a comprehensive analysis of ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar. The analysis synthesizes patterns, themes, and concerns across all survey responses that were classified into various intent categories.

Analysis Components

  • Key Themes: Main topics and patterns that emerge across survey responses in this pillar
  • Main Concerns: Primary worries, challenges, or issues raised by respondents
  • Notable Patterns: Interesting trends, unique perspectives, or significant patterns observed in the responses

LLM Query Used

Your task is to analyze the survey responses and provide a comprehensive summary across three dimensions:

1. KEY THEMES: Identify the 3-5 most prominent themes or topics that emerge across all survey responses in this pillar. What are respondents most focused on? What patterns appear across multiple questions? (1-2 paragraphs)

2. MAIN CONCERNS: What are the primary concerns, challenges, or issues raised by respondents? What problems or risks do they highlight? What are they worried about or critical of? (1-2 paragraphs)

3. NOTABLE PATTERNS: Identify any interesting patterns, relationships, or insights that emerge from the data. Are there surprising connections between different intents? Do certain themes appear more frequently than expected? Are there any notable gaps or underrepresented perspectives? (1-2 paragraphs)

IMPORTANT:
- Be specific and cite examples where possible
- Reference specific intent categories by name when relevant
- Focus on substantive insights, not superficial observations
- Maintain the tone and sentiment of the responses (don't sanitize negative feedback)
- Keep each section to 1-2 paragraphs

Additionally, for each dimension, identify ONE intent category and its example response that best illustrates that dimension. Provide the intent name exactly as it appears above.

Respond in JSON format:
{
  "key_themes": "Your analysis here...",
  "main_concerns": "Your analysis here...",
  "notable_patterns": "Your analysis here...",
  "example_key_themes_intent": "Intent Name Here",
  "example_main_concerns_intent": "Intent Name Here",
  "example_notable_patterns_intent": "Intent Name Here"
}

Data Source

This analysis is based on survey responses that were classified into intent categories using an LLM-based classification system. The summary synthesizes insights across all classified responses within this pillar.

These high-level themes capture the main topics across all questions by grouping all intents in this pillar.

Pillar-Level Theme Distribution - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Group question-level intents into higher-level pillar themes

About Pillar-Level Themes

Pillar-level themes are created by grouping similar question-level intents across all questions in a pillar. This provides a higher-level view of the main topics being discussed across the pillar.

The LLM analyzes all question-level intents and their descriptions, then creates broader thematic categories that capture the essence of multiple related intents.

LLM Query Used

Please analyze these intents and create 4-6 pillar-level intent categories that:
- Capture the overarching themes across all questions in this pillar
- Are distinct and meaningful
- Cover the breadth of topics in the question-level intents
- Are named clearly and concisely
- **Each pillar intent MUST map to at least 2 different question-level intents** (if a theme only appears in one question, it's too specific for a pillar-level category)
- **PRESERVE THE TONE AND SENTIMENT** of the question-level intents:
  * If question intents express skepticism, opposition, or concerns → pillar intent should reflect that negative/cautious tone
  * If question intents are supportive or positive → pillar intent should reflect that positive tone
  * If question intents are neutral/descriptive → pillar intent should be neutral
  * Do NOT sanitize or neutralize negative sentiments - keep them explicit

Respond in JSON format:
{{
    "pillar_intents": [
        {{
            "name": "Pillar Intent Name",
            "description": "Clear description of what this pillar-level intent represents"
        }},
        ...
    ],
    "mapping": {{
        "Pillar Intent Name": ["Question Intent 1 name only", "Question Intent 2 name only", ...],
        ...
    }}
}}

IMPORTANT: 
- Each question-level intent should map to at least one pillar-level intent
- A question-level intent can map to multiple pillar-level intents if appropriate
- Ensure all question-level intents are included in the mapping
- **Each pillar intent must map to at least 2 question-level intents** - if you find a theme that only appears in one question, either:
  1. Broaden the category to include related intents from other questions, OR
  2. Map that single intent to a broader existing category, OR
  3. If it truly doesn't fit anywhere, it will be automatically added to "Other"
- CRITICAL: Match the tone/sentiment of grouped intents - don't make negative intents sound positive or vice versa!

Question 8

What needs to be put in place so Canada can grow globally competitive AI companies while retaining ownership, IP and economic sovereignty?

Total Responses

2,629

Unique Intents

6

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Sovereignty, IP and Data Retention Policies and mechanisms to keep core IP, data and critical infrastructure under Canadian control, including data residency, governance, and ownership safeguards (e.g., sovereign compute, IP retention, golden shares, and sovereignty by design) accessible to startups across provinces and sectors. 1,300 49.4%

"Canada must strengthen its IP retention strategies by providing funding incentives tied to domestic ownership and use of Canadian-made models and datasets. A national AI IP registry, similar to a patent office for algorithms and fine-tuned models, could help safeguard innovations. Foreign investment should be encouraged under frameworks that preserve Canadian board control and IP licensing rights. Strategic use of the Sovereign AI Compute Strategy can ensure Canadian companies have competitive infrastructure without depending on foreign cloud monopolies. Sovereignty should also include data residency and model transparency safeguards for high-risk AI applications."

"I think Canada needs to create conditions where AI companies can scale here without immediately selling out to foreign buyers. That means access to domestic growth capital, policies that help protect Canadian IP, and safeguards so we don’t hollow out our most promising firms. Foreign investment should still play a role, but I think we need clear structures where ownership and core intellectual property remain anchored in Canada. Otherwise, we’ll end up being the R&D lab for someone else’s economy."

"Pour bâtir des entreprises d’IA concurrentielles tout en préservant la souveraineté économique, le Canada doit reconnaître la culture comme pilier de sa stratégie industrielle. Le secteur culturel développe des corpus de données, outils et usages originaux — véritables actifs immatériels nationaux — qui assurent l’ancrage local de la propriété intellectuelle. L’accès à une infrastructure de calcul souveraine pour les créateurs, chercheurs et OBNL culturels permettrait de produire des modèles reflétant la diversité linguistique et culturelle canadienne, un avantage compétitif mondial. Investir dans des “communs numériques” culturels, gouvernés par les pairs et hébergés au Canada, favorise l’indépendance face aux géants du cloud et stimule l’innovation responsable. C’est une stratégie de croissance qui conjugue compétitivité économique et souveraineté culturelle."
Regulation, Ethics and IP Protection Robust regulation and ethics frameworks governing AI, including privacy protections, consent for training data, copyright enforcement, and safeguards against misuse and misinformation. 1,134 43.1%

"A governance framework that provides guidance, structure and security. Look at the EU AI Act as an example. Not to copy but to use and leverage as we create our own act. A piece of work companies can leverage and use (value-add) in a constructive way as they pursue innovation in a safe and secure/compliant way."

"Ban AI from training on copyrighted material and disallow it from operating in Canada unless copyrighted material is removed from its database."

"Une differenciation au niveau de l'approche prise autour de l'IA au Canada. Une IA responsable, pensée dans un contexte de bienveillance. De l'IA pour le bien commun, le bien être d'une société et non sa ruine."
Skepticism / Opposition to AI Caution or outright opposition to AI, including concerns about environmental impact, IP theft, job displacement, and the erosion of social and cultural fabric. 898 34.2%

"When we use generative AI, we consent to the appropriation of our intellectual property by data scrapers. We stuff the pockets of oligarchs with even more money. We abet the acceleration of a social media environment that everyone admits is making life worse. We accept the further degradation of an already degraded educational system. We agree that we would rather deplete our natural resources than make our own art or think our own thoughts. We dig ourselves deeper into crises that have been made worse by technology, from the erosion of electoral democracy to the intensification of climate change. We condone platforms that not only urge children to commit suicide, they instruct them on how to tie the noose."

"AI is not actually profitable. Not in any way that matters. If it were, it wouldn't need to be forced into everything and sold as desperately as it has been. It is a fad, and a dangerous one at that. There's no benefit in investing AI that wouldn't be better served and gain better yield than if that investment went to people instead."

"Today’s AI and respecting IP & copyright are mutually exclusive. AI is not possible without a massive and wide scale violation of IP and copyright. Anyone who says different is selling something. Disney and other large corporations are currently suing the main creators of commercial AI over this right now and if they win (and the mouse always wins) AI will immediately collapse. Stop ignoring reality because of some fools errand to chase this trend."
Public Funding, Capital and Domestic Growth Public funding and policy tools to attract and grow AI firms domestically, including patient capital, procurement boosts, tax incentives, and mechanisms to keep IP and jobs in Canada while scaling globally. 881 33.5%

"Create a federal investor tax credit so Canadians fund Canadian AI companies at scale, with matching public dollars tied to keeping IP and headquarters in Canada. Push Canadian pension funds to allocate more money at home, not just as a recommendation but as an action, so long-term Canadian capital builds Canadian companies. Prioritize Canadian AI in government buying so companies get revenue and proof points here first. Lock in ownership and IP. Require Canadian IP holding entities for funded projects, clear IP rules in university-SME deals where the company keeps commercial rights, and clawbacks if IP is moved offshore. Fund sovereign compute and storage in Canada, enforce data residency for critical sectors, and set practical security standards that companies can meet. Help companies scale globally without selling out by streamlining visas, expanding SR&ED and commercialization credits, and co-investing with Canadian institutions so founders can raise growth capital while retaining control."

"Canada should establish a national AI innovation fund dedicated to scaling Canadian AI startups globally. To retain ownership and IP, implement incentives for companies to keep core research, talent, and intellectual property within Canada—such as tax breaks, grants for local patent filing, and support for Canadian founders. Strategic alliances with Canadian universities, export accelerators, and a strong legal framework for IP protection will preserve our economic sovereignty while welcoming international investment that aligns with Canadian values."

"I think Canada needs to use its vast oil and natural gas reserves as well as its other critical resources to fund an investment arm that can invest in these types of upstarts and attract global talent. How cool would it be if LNG and oil from the oil sands could be sold to other countries and with those profits, new AI funding could be made available to companies. I think that that is a great start but we need to ensure that we are keeping homegrown talent and homegrown businesses at the forefront and giving them access to resources, not regulating them, and letting them flourish in our economy and on the backs of profits that we make ourselves."
Talent and Innovation Ecosystem Creating supportive environments for AI research, education, and talent development 417 15.9%

"Investments in technology and government partnerships in R&D and with technology leaders in Canada. Also standards and policies regarding the adoption of AI in Canada would be necessary. AI should be part of every educational curiculum. We need to develop AI engineers, AI policy makers, AI infrastructure experts, AI developers, etc. We already have some leaders in technology in Canada. We should leverage and expand those to include AI R&D. I worry that AI will turn our kids into "The Anxious Generation" if not regulated or used properly. It is important that we educate our children now and that AI become a key component of education at all levels. Canada is in an excellent position to become a leader in it appropriate use and an example for the rest of the world."

"Promote better relationships with leading AI academics. More interns, more lablets in campus, more AI investment in our universities, more long-term collaboration between academia and industry"

"anada is already a global leader in AI research and AI ethics — admired for combining cutting-edge innovation with human-centered values. Our opportunity now is to export that leadership: not just through technology, but through education, governance, and real-world success stories that prove ethical AI drives prosperity. We can lead by example — as the world’s trusted guide in responsible and inclusive AI adoption. Our strength lies in three assets: A reputation for ethical governance, A multicultural perspective that understands the global South, and A bilingual education ecosystem capable of translating complex ideas across languages and cultures. By exporting AI education, governance playbooks, and literacy frameworks, Canada can occupy a unique role between Silicon Valley’s speed and Europe’s regulation — a bridge nation for responsible innovation. Partnerships with the OECD, UNESCO, and Commonwealth nations could formalize this leadership lane. Just as a Canadian flag on a backpack once told the world, “You can trust me,” a Canadian flag on AI education and innovation should mean the same — trust, balance, and integrity. When the world sees Canada’s mark on an AI initiative, they should know it was built responsibly and built to last. Our natural advantage extends beyond research. With vast clean energy and natural resources, Canada can combine AI, robotics, and renewable power to make resource development safe, efficient, and sustainable. If we play this decade wisely, AI can help Canadians achieve prosperity on par with the world’s most advanced nations — not through extraction, but through stewardship, intelligence, and trust."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 118 4.5%

"we need to generate more Green energy, if we have cheep energy for all Canadians we will be able to justify running models"

"Actual free Healthcare for all. Minimum wage actually being able to provide for a single income family of five (5) like it did for our grandfather's. Housing crisis corrected For ALL. Universal Basic Income for ALL Canadians and Permanent Residents. Free or truly affordable education for all WHO WISH IT. In Every Corner of S.T.E.A.M. Food Crisis CORRECTED FOR ALL. Ensuring Canadians feel safe in this land that many served and died to protect."

"- encourage companies to work on areas in the world that are not using a lot of AI - use the government to work on trade/business agreements that assist those countries that are emerging economically and need investment and assistance to continue to grow but allow private and public companies to do the work inside the countries"
Economic Security and Sovereignty Safeguards 1 0.0% No examples available

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.
