Pillar-Level Theme Distribution - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Group question-level intents into higher-level pillar themes

About Pillar-Level Themes

Pillar-level themes are created by grouping similar question-level intents across all questions in a pillar. This provides a higher-level view of the main topics being discussed across the pillar.

The LLM analyzes all question-level intents and their descriptions, then creates broader thematic categories that capture the essence of multiple related intents.

LLM Query Used

Please analyze these intents and create 4-6 pillar-level intent categories that:
- Capture the overarching themes across all questions in this pillar
- Are distinct and meaningful
- Cover the breadth of topics in the question-level intents
- Are named clearly and concisely
- **Each pillar intent MUST map to at least 2 different question-level intents** (if a theme only appears in one question, it's too specific for a pillar-level category)
- **PRESERVE THE TONE AND SENTIMENT** of the question-level intents:
  * If question intents express skepticism, opposition, or concerns → pillar intent should reflect that negative/cautious tone
  * If question intents are supportive or positive → pillar intent should reflect that positive tone
  * If question intents are neutral/descriptive → pillar intent should be neutral
  * Do NOT sanitize or neutralize negative sentiments - keep them explicit

Respond in JSON format:
{{
    "pillar_intents": [
        {{
            "name": "Pillar Intent Name",
            "description": "Clear description of what this pillar-level intent represents"
        }},
        ...
    ],
    "mapping": {{
        "Pillar Intent Name": ["Question Intent 1 name only", "Question Intent 2 name only", ...],
        ...
    }}
}}

IMPORTANT: 
- Each question-level intent should map to at least one pillar-level intent
- A question-level intent can map to multiple pillar-level intents if appropriate
- Ensure all question-level intents are included in the mapping
- **Each pillar intent must map to at least 2 question-level intents** - if you find a theme that only appears in one question, either:
  1. Broaden the category to include related intents from other questions, OR
  2. Map that single intent to a broader existing category, OR
  3. If it truly doesn't fit anywhere, it will be automatically added to "Other"
- CRITICAL: Match the tone/sentiment of grouped intents - don't make negative intents sound positive or vice versa!

Question 11

How does Canada get to more and stronger AI industrial champions? What supports would make our champions own the podium?

Total Responses

2,164

Unique Intents

7

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Anti-AI / Skepticism & Opposition A broad set of responses expressing opposition to AI, concern about bubbles, environmental and ethical harms, or calls to restrain or ban AI technologies and government promotion of AI. 877 40.5%

"I am against AI in principle and in practice. "AI" usage has been shown to affect the way people use their brain. https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ Data centers use an inordinate amount of energy and water and other necessary natural resources. https://andthewest.stanford.edu/2025/thirsty-for-power-and-water-ai-crunching-data-centers-sprout-across-the-west/ I also object vehemently the fact that training "AI" requires the theft of text, visual, and audio art, as well as people's identity and personhood. "AI" is currently used for observation and extraction of personal information, encroaching in the basic right to individual privacy. I cannot in good conscience support anything related to the current iteration of "AI.""

"Canada should make AI illegal."

"It’s a podium built on theft, does it matter who owns it? It’ll be thieves either way."
AI Champions Policy & Growth Supports Advocacy for a coherent national policy and targeted supports (including patient capital, mentorship, and stage-based programs) to grow Canadian AI industrial champions and enable them to scale domestically and internationally. 852 39.4%

"I think Canada needs to deliberately grow a handful of AI companies into true industrial champions, not just a long tail of small startups. The supports that matter are mentorship, consistent federal program handoffs so firms don’t get stuck between funding stages, and tailored tools for early-, mid-, and late-stage growth. If we want companies to “own the podium,” we need to back them through the messy middle stage when scaling is hardest, not just seed and research phases."

"Canada can build stronger AI champions by addressing barriers at every growth stage. Early-stage startups need accessible seed funding, incubators, and mentorship networks linking founders with experienced scale-up leaders. Mid-stage firms require scale-up capital (BDC, pension funds, export financing) and help navigating global markets, alongside AI-First procurement to secure anchor domestic customers. Late-stage firms need patient capital, tailored trade support, and protections."

"Scaling is a red herring. What we need instead is a pluralistic network of smaller, decentralized projects/systems/R&D/solutions. It's the 21st century. 'Scaling' is the solution from the 20th century, which produces almost nothing but toxic results anymore."
Talent, Education & Workforce Development Policies and programs to grow Canadian AI talent through affordable education, training, mentorship, and workforce development across all growth stages. 486 22.5%

"Ensure critical AI literacy in education so upcoming talent has a clear understanding of the limitations, opportunities, risks and open questions. Stand up for diverse talent that empowers more people from more communities to pursue AI as a field of study and work - e.g. through targeted mentorship schemes, recognition of achievements, and other initiatives that can level the academic and corporate playing fields. Incentives for small businesses that demonstrate responsible behaviour."

"All efforts need to be made across the entire education system to overcome hesitancy and accelerate AI educational uptake immediately. And while there are provincial incentives for AI upskilling, the process is convoluted and extremely difficult to navigate. Simple, clear, and well financed supports need to be made available to reskilling across all aspects of the economy. And efforts need to be made to create industry-specific experts."

"This question presents the success of AI solely through the lens of "industrial champions" competing for market dominance, neglecting the crucial role that communities play in building sustainable and responsible enterprises. A purely industry-focused approach risks undermining public trust. True champions arise when community needs drive innovation and neurodivergent voices influence priorities. Canada can cultivate stronger AI champions by investing in diverse human capital, especially neurodivergent talent whose cognitive strengths can drive innovation. Companies should prioritize neuroinclusive hiring practices, using AI tools to minimize bias and effectively match skills. Essential supports include accessible computing infrastructure, research funding, talent pipelines, and government procurement that validate Canadian solutions. However, true champions must also foster inclusive cultures and build social capital through community partnerships, recognizing that industrial success relies on human and social capital, not just computing power. Communities must co-create innovation with industry rather than merely consume it. Companies that involve neurodivergent and disability communities in the co-design process can develop trustworthy products that address genuine needs. The government should incentivize community partnerships and fund non-profit-led AI initiatives that enhance social capital. The spotlight should shine on companies that balance competitive success with meaningful social impact, understanding that innovation thriving alongside community well-being creates the sustainable competitive advantage that sets global leaders apart."
Ethical Development & Trust Building Responses that advocate for AI development but with a strong emphasis on responsibility, robust regulation, ethical guidelines, IP protection, environmental sustainability, transparency, and a focus on building public trust and beneficial, human-centric applications over pure profit or unbridled scale. 458 21.2%

"Like I said earlier, Canada’s future AI champions won’t win because they’re the biggest — they’ll win because they’re the most trusted. Our global edge is ethical credibility: transparent systems, privacy standards, and human-centered design. That trust is what foreign markets will pay for. What needs to change: 1. Make trust a competitive advantage: Fund safety, evaluation, and privacy as core R&D, not red tape. Require model cards, bias testing, and reproducibility for any public funding — and let companies market that compliance globally. Maybe even create a “Trusted AI Canada” certification that signals transparency and reliability to export markets. 2. Government as first, trusted customer: Launch sector “pilot-to-production” sandboxes in health, finance, and public service. Reward companies that meet safety and audit benchmarks with real contracts, not just press releases. 3. Capital that scales without leaking control: Co-investment growth fund tied to Canadian IP, board majority, and ethical standards. 4. Build founders who can scale responsibly: Pair growth-stage founders with operators skilled in regulated industries (health, finance, gov). Don't just keep giving money to companies or billionaire founders like Shopify who already have money. 5. Fund women-led and diverse AI leadership programs — trust starts with who builds the tech. If Canada becomes the place where AI is safe, explainable, and human-centered by default, we won’t just grow champions — we’ll own the global trust market for AI."

"A well regulated environment (including environmental regulation) where AI was developed and operating from a position of trust, transparency, accountability, and moral clarity."

"Mentorship is important; but we're in unchartered waters, here. Talk to the experts about what are the best ways forward - and that doesn't just mean technologically - but ethically as well. You need to include ethicists in your decision-making process to be assured that you don't invest heavily in products/services that eventually produce deleterious results. Again, you literally have one of the world's best AI ethicists in your backyard (DiCarlo). Talk to people like him BEFORE you simply jump in with both feet."
Intellectual Property, Data Sovereignty & Sovereign Compute A focus on keeping core IP, data, and control within Canada, and on building sovereign compute and data infrastructure to support domestic champions. 242 11.2%

"Canada needs to back sovereign-by-design AI firms that keep data, IP, and value in Canada. Fund access to Canadian-owned compute, link research to procurement, and align NRC, ISED, BDC, and EDC into a unified Sovereign Scale-Up Track. Provide export credit and TSX incentives while protecting IP and inference under Canadian law. When we fund, scale, and buy from our own ecosystem, Canada’s AI champions will define global standards for privacy and trusted innovation."

"A requirement to keep Canadian data in Canada, and privacy law that made that meaningful"

"From CIPPIC's perspective, this question's framing—using metaphors of "industrial champions" and "owning the podium"—points to a fundamental flaw in Canada's AI strategy. It suggests the goal is to "win" an unwinnable, US-dominated "arms race" for the biggest, most resource-intensive general-purpose AI. The “bigger-is-better” model is economically unsustainable considering the vast sums to invest, rewarding only the largest incumbents. Durable champions emerge when growth is conditional on assurance: provenance, audits, portability, and enforceable Canadian jurisdiction. If Canada makes trustworthy AI the lowest-friction path to market, the firms that master it will lead at home and compete globally. Reward verifiable trust over raw scale. Prioritize domain-specific, auditable, energy-/data-efficient systems built on legally sourced, provenance-tracked data; enforce privacy/IP law evenly across incumbents and startups. Sovereignty through enforceable governance. Require Canadian jurisdiction and redress, portability/deletion and purpose limits, and Indigenous-led data governance (OCAP®/CARE) where relevant; use data residency selectively where it materially reduces risk. Stage-tailored supports—earned, not automatic. Give priority access to funding, compute, and procurement to teams that retain core IP in a Canadian entity, adopt risk-tiered governance with independent evaluation, commit to interoperability/open interfaces, and meet higher-assurance tiers that unlock expedited transitions across federal programs."
Public Procurement & Anchor Demand Strategies that leverage government purchases as anchor customers to validate, de-risk, and scale Canadian AI solutions, with a focus on domestic procurement and export readiness. 190 8.8%

"Use government as an anchor customer: outcome-based, multi-year contracts that turn pilots into scaled deployments. Create “scale lanes” in procurement: pre-qualification, fast security reviews, and production pathways out of sandboxes. Stand up national AI co-validation labs: shared test data, evaluation, certification, and export-ready compliance. Pair capital with customers: co-invest/match funds unlocked by signed domestic/foreign contracts. Build a champion mentorship network: serial founders, ex-C-suite, and domain experts embedded with firms for 6–12 months. Smooth program handoffs: a single front door with automatic graduation from early- to mid- to late-stage supports. Guarantee affordable compute/connectivity: reserved national capacity and predictable credits for scaling workloads. Strategic hiring help: clearance pipelines and salary top-ups for critical technical/GTMs; streamlined visas for specialist roles."

""Buy Canadian" Procurement: Government becomes an anchor customer for Canadian-developed AI in defence, health, and secure data services, giving champions a validated global reference. Trade Commissioner Service: Dedicated support to help champions secure international contracts and navigate foreign regulatory environments."

"I'm not sure what stronger champion than the PM of the country, to the extent that he created a new cabinet role specifically for AI boosterism. But if we want to use the American example I guess massive defence contracts with limited-to-zero public accountability"
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 184 8.5%

"More fundamental research. If we want to make machine that think, we first need to understand how humans think. If we want to use AI/machines for diagnosis, we first first understand how diseases work, especially inside people who are not male, white, and cisgender. If we want to use AI/machines to find exoplanets, black holes, gravastars, neutrinos, exotic matter, or dark matter/dark energy, we need a deeper understanding of how physic works to understand the possibilities of what the Universe can show us. If we want to grow food better and faster with AI/machines, we need to understand how plants interact with the soil, the microorganisms in the soil, fungi, other plants, water, minerals, weather, how to modify plants (genetically or otherwise) for more yield, more pest resistance, more disease resistance, more macronutriments (golden rice, anyone?)."

"Aside from prestige, what is the benefit? Sure, China is making huge strides in AI. But they're also making strides in all kinds of other areas, such as their recently developed "bone glue" and advances in EVs. We should take their cue and focus more broadly on scientific progress rather than narrowing focus to AI. Looking for promising research across the sciences is more likely to create business opportunities than trying to get in on one sector that everyone is trying to muscle in on at the same time. It's like..... if your kid is good enough to go pro at basketball, but you really want them to go pro in hockey. So you force them to play hockey all the time, even though they have a shot at playing for the Raptors. We need to look at our actual aptitude instead of trying to force the situation."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive
40.4%
876
neutral
12.6%
274
negative
46.9%
1,017

Question 12

What changes to Canada’s landscape of business incentives would accelerate sustainable scaling of AI ventures?

Total Responses

2,025

Unique Intents

7

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Incentive modernization for AI scaling (SR&ED, compute, data, liability, and governance) Modernizing Canada’s incentive toolkit to better support scaling AI, including compute and data costs, safety and governance, IP ownership, and easier transitions between programs. 770 38.0%

"Canada should modernize SR&ED to support commercialization, add an IP Box to reward Canadian-held IP, and expand AI-First procurement to create anchor customers. Launch AI scale-up funds with BDC, pensions, and EDC tied to HQ/IP retention, and incentivize green compute/data infrastructure. Reform stock options and talent credits to attract top talent, and streamline federal-provincial programs to cut red tape."

"I think Canada’s incentive landscape still favors early-stage firms too heavily and doesn’t do enough to help companies that are scaling. We should align tax credits, grants, and procurement policies so that firms with proven traction get real advantages for growing at home. That could mean scaling-specific R&D credits, export financing, and government-backed anchor contracts. Without those, the best AI ventures will either sell early or scale abroad where the incentives are stronger."

"Modernize SR&ED to cover training, provenance and safety; make credits refundable.. Build AI sandboxes with capped liability and audit logs. Tie incentives to Consent, Compensation & Control and open model cards. Use growth loans, BDC/pension co-investment and data portability rules to prevent lock-in. Align with California AI rules so Canadian firms can compete abroad with compliance built in."
Skepticism and calls to regulate/ban AI A broad set of responses arguing AI is unsustainable or harmful and should be regulated, limited, or not subsidized, including outright bans in some cases. 745 36.8%

"Enact legislation to prevent AI from using any material without consent. Do not allow companies to replace people’s jobs with AI. Do not allow AI companies to pollute clean water and drain the power grid. People will not trust AI until they have reason to."

"Do not incentivize commercialization of generative ai. Do not fund it. Do not support it. Do not spend my taxpayer dollars on it. Create and enforce ethics and regulations around ai development and use. Update them regularly to avoid loopholing. Restrict generative AI use and prevent the construction of data centers for generative AI in Canada."

"Do research against AI. Make laws against AI; Create plagiarism laws against AI; Prevent AI scraping information; Make technology that is able to detect AI imaging, video, and audio; Protect people’s rights and privacy; Invest in proper research against climate change instead."
Workforce and social impact considerations in AI scaling Incentives should address workforce transition, inclusion, skills development, and protections for workers and communities affected by AI adoption. 330 16.3%

"To accelerate sustainable scaling of AI ventures, Canada must align business incentives with community impact and workforce readiness. Beyond traditional R&D and export incentives, programs should include funding for AI solutions in community services—such as employment, settlement, health, and social supports—where innovation directly benefits people. Incentives could reward collaborations between AI ventures, employers, and community-based organizations that advance inclusion and accessibility. Tax credits, innovation vouchers, and procurement pilots should prioritize ventures that integrate skills training and workforce development for newcomers, women, and underrepresented groups. Embedding social impact criteria into scaling programs ensures that Canada grows globally competitive AI companies while also strengthening its social and economic fabric."

"Give training money to companies that invest in AI so that they can train employees that are currently doing jobs that will be done by AI. This way they can continue to employ their current workforce but skill them up to do tasks that cannot be done by AI."

"Canada needs to work with unions to have a real plan for the labour fallout. Canada needs to be people first and not AI first. I am a big proponent of AI use but chasing after this without thinking about the people that will be displaced will cause political instability. There needs to be a plan as to what will happen to workers. A real plan with measurable outcomes that needs to be enforced, not neoliberal lip service like we have seen in the past."
Environmental sustainability & energy considerations in AI scaling A focus on the environmental footprint of AI, especially data centers, energy and water use, and the need for green energy and sustainable infrastructure when scaling AI. 323 16.0%

"Business incentives should be broad in scope, allowing for real innovation to arise from a far greater field of talent. Improving and expanding renewable energy infrastructure to support tech integration would go a long way, as would self sustaining utilities, such as alternative cooling technology, etc. Passive energy production and intelligently designed environmentally sustainable infrastructure will allow for a much smoother transition to mass adoption than traditional non renewal infrastructure does. Build with the public good in mind, and you’ll spend far less time and money in court, fighting to overrule the people this technology is supposed to benefit. Make the public shareholders- if the industry benefits, the public benefits. People are more willing to back business expansion if they see a direct benefit to themselves. Note: in regard to the above question- “accelerating” and “sustainable” are usually at odds. When in doubt, bet on sustainable! Slow growth that doesn’t need to saddle future generations with damage mitigation, is better business anyway. “Move fast and break things” just ends up, well…breaking things. And those can be very important things that will cost far more to repair."

"Incentivize the development of renewable energy resources, enabling cheap and scalable data centre development."

"AI from my understanding needs tremendous amounts of water and energy. Canada has both and no one else has both. Some have one or the other; but not both. Stop negotiating on the Columbia River agreement and the St Lawrence River agreement and any other international fresh water agreements. Water has never been part of the NAFTA or CUSMA. If AI centres need water, establish threshold of exit water quality they need to establish and maintain to do business here. No one else has the water in these drought ridden times. Their assurance to their water needs should cement and accelerate sustainable scaling of AI ventures. This parameter should also weigh heavily in the selection of data centre locations. Put the data centres on the Canadian side of an international waterway and use our water instead of letting the US buy water licences from us and sell it to US AI centres."
Domestic IP retention & patient capital for scaling Incentives and programs designed to keep intellectual property (IP), headquarters, and ownership in Canada, coupled with patient capital and sovereign compute to anchor AI scale-ups domestically. 294 14.5%

"Canada must pivot its incentives from simple R&D support to a strategy focused on scaling and sovereignty. Key changes include: Replace SR&ED with a larger, refundable AI-specific tax credit for scaling firms. Launch a "Pension Fund Anchor Program" using government co-investment to de-risk domestic capital for Series B+ rounds, preventing premature foreign takeovers. Implement "Golden Share" clauses in major grants, ensuring core IP and decision-making for strategic AI ventures stay Canadian."

"Canada should align business incentives to support scaling AI ventures by expanding late-stage funding programs, offering tax breaks tied to growth milestones, and streamlining access to federal support. Program improvements should prioritize retention of high-potential Canadian companies, including incentives for keeping IP and major operations in Canada. This will accelerate sustainable scaling and strengthen our AI leadership."

"Canada must establish a sovereign wealth fund with a dedicated VC arm to accelerate sustainable scaling of AI ventures. This fund should provide patient, growth-stage capital tied to Canadian ownership, IP retention, and job creation. Incentives must shift from broad grants to performance-based support rewarding export growth and global competitiveness. Streamlined coordination between federal and provincial programs will ensure seamless scaling pathways. The fund can also champion “AI Champions”"
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 279 13.8%

"Build an AI tool with semantic relationships to pair companies with tools that best fit their needs. The respondent highlights the challenge that many firms don’t know what AI solutions exist and suggests a platform that removes biases (like “Favorites”) and democratizes the evaluation process. This idea directly addresses the information gap and could drive sustainable AI scaling by ensuring that businesses access the right technology tailored to their needs."

"Find the few industries that actually have a use for AI at scale, and focus your efforts on those. Do not try to force large-scale AI into businesses where it would not be of use, or where the uses could be handled just as effectively by small-scale adoption. This response offers a strategic perspective: instead of spreading incentives uniformly, isolate sectors with genuine potential for AI transformation to create more effective, sustainable results in scaling."

"Align with OCAP (Ownership, Control, Access, and Possession) principles because all these initiatives are fundamentally about data and information. Embedding these principles into the way business is done in Canada could foster a sustainable, unique ecosystem, ensuring that data is treated as a core asset in AI ventures. This approach could differentiate Canada on the global stage and drive both innovation and responsible growth."
Procurement-driven domestic scaling & anchor customers Using government procurement and domestic demand as a primary market pull to validate, anchor, and scale Canadian AI solutions with domestic ownership and ongoing government engagement. 167 8.2%

"To accelerate the sustainable scaling of AI ventures, Canada must realign its entire landscape of business incentives to a single, unified purpose: forging and retaining sovereign champions. This is achieved by creating a "Sovereign Growth Ladder," a three-rung system that replaces fragmented programs with a clear, performance-based path to the podium. 1. The First Rung: The "Crucible Contract." Instead of grants, the primary incentive for early-stage companies is a government contract to build solutions for national challenges within the "National Crucible." This provides non-dilutive capital, real-world validation, and direct mentorship. It is a direct investment in solving Canada's own problems. 2. The Second Rung: The "Sovereign Scale-Up" Conversion. Upon successful delivery of a Crucible Contract, a company becomes eligible to convert to a "Sovereign Scale-Up." This unlocks a new tier of powerful incentives, including streamlined access to global capital and significant tax advantages, in exchange for the government receiving a non-dilutable "Sovereign Share." This incentive is not a handout; it is a co-investment in a proven national asset. 3. The Final Rung: The "Global Podium" Procurement Mandate. To champion our scaled firms, the government must enact a "Sovereign Procurement Mandate." This gives certified "Sovereign Scale-Ups" preferential status for all major public sector AI contracts. This creates an unassailable domestic market, providing the stable revenue base required for aggressive global expansion. This is the ultimate incentive: the promise that if you build world-class, sovereign AI in Canada, your nation will be your first and best customer."

"Incentives should align to adoption and procurement of Canadian-built solutions - even if some uncertainty exists. There is currently an aversion to adoption of solutions from small companies and it’s widely recognized that this needs to change, across sectors, but the public sector should lead the way. This allows early stage companies to iterate on product-market fit which must be achieved before capital can accelerate growth."

"In instances where both Canadian and foreign vendors are determined to have comparable AI products or services for a given application or requirement, the Government of Canada should give preference to Canadian vendors unless the cost of the domestic AI solution is 25% or greater than the cost of the comparable foreign solution. Similar business incentives are already common in the procurement requirements of the U.S. Government. Amongst Canadian vendors, the Government of Canada should give preference to SMEs unless the cost of the SME’s AI product or service is 15% or greater than the cost of the comparable solution from a large-scale enterprise. Furthermore, the Government of Canada should introduce contractual mechanisms — such as incentives and penalties — to provide the government with programmatic recourse if a prime contractor makes claims of partnering with SMEs as subcontractors at the proposal stage but then subsequently reneges during the execution phase. The introduction of contractual mechanisms to ensure delivered work matches the proposed plan in terms of work scope and SME teaming commitments would benefit the entire Canadian AI sector."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive
34.6%
701
neutral
14.6%
296
negative
50.8%
1,030

Question 13

How can we best support AI companies to remain rooted in Canada while growing strength in global markets?

Total Responses

2,081

Unique Intents

8

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Anchor Canadian ownership and retention (HQ/IP/talent) with sovereignty Strategies that keep the core leadership, intellectual property, data, and key talent of AI firms headquartered in Canada, supported by sovereign compute, data residency, and policy levers that incentivize staying. 755 36.3%

"Anchor with Domestic Capital: Create a fund that co-invests with Canadian pension funds in later-stage rounds, providing the capital to scale without ceding control. Tie Incentives to Sovereignty: Link major grants and tax credits to "golden share" provisions that keep core IP and global HQs in Canada, even with foreign investment. Become the Lead Customer: Government must proactively procure from Canadian AI firms, providing vital revenue and a powerful global reference case."

"Support AI companies by providing patient capital, home-market procurement, talent retention, sovereign IP/data, and global market programs—keeping firms domestically rooted while scaling internationally."

"Stratégie de fidélisation à long terme : accès préférentiel et prévisible au calcul souverain, plus des “tracks” d’achats publics multi-annuels; cela ancre HQ/PI au Canada. Avantage compétitif par la culture : soutenir des corpus culturels nationaux pour entraîner des modèles différenciés (fr, en, autochtones) — clé de la découvrabilité et de l’export des industries créatives. Écosystème circulaire : reconnaître le rôle des artistes comme “système d’alerte” (biais, acceptabilité) qui sécurise l’adoption mondiale des offres canadiennes; financer la documentation et le transfert. Règles d’investissement à double clé : ouverture aux capitaux étrangers mais avec garde-fous (données/modèles hébergés au Canada, gouvernance par les pairs sur jeux de données culturels)."
Skepticism, ethics, environment, and opposition to AI Voices calling for limits, bans, or intense regulation of AI, highlighting environmental, social, privacy, and ethical concerns, and opposing government support or leadership in AI. 687 33.0%

"Generative AI steals from rights holders and has a terrible environmental impact. Studies also show that AI users lose the ability to think critically. Also, it is dangerous to put the sensitive data in Canadians into the hands of companies that would claim perpetual ownership over said data. I think the Canadian government should avoid investing or using AI."

"AI as it currently is deployed is dangerous, wildly unreliable and unregulated. If we must engage with it we should first exhaust the already evident negative impacts on the environment, copyright, education, and mental health."

"I don't want a thousand data centers in Canada boiling our fresh water to cool themselves cheaply. Stop burning the planet for this garbage"
Innovation and Economic Growth Viewing AI as a potential driver of economic development, technological advancement, and global competitiveness 499 24.0%

"It all comes down to having the best foundation for growth. Focus on things businesses care about, aka money. Put money into research to find ways to make AI cost less for more production and it will attract businesses that want to exploit that."

"Incentivize VCs and angel investors to come here via tax credits and lower cost of business"

"Encourage mission-oriented investment: direct some federal investment toward health-AI “challenge funds” focused on pressing population health issues (inequities, aging, Indigenous health, rural/remote) rather than generic “AI scaling” funds. This aligns with evidence-informed decision-making and social justice orientation"
Global expansion with domestic sovereignty safeguards Policies that enable Canadian AI firms to compete in international markets while maintaining core assets (HQs, IP, data) in Canada, supported by scalable capital, partnerships, and export/market access mechanisms. 430 20.7%

"Canada can keep AI companies rooted in Canada while they scale globally by making it easier to grow at home and trade abroad without losing control of talent, IP, or data. The first step is to anchor domestic advantages: predictable public procurement, outcome-based contracts, and a clear first-customer pathway so startups can prove value in Canada before expanding. Next, ensure capital continuity through patient growth funds, export financing, and SR&ED reforms that cover scaling costs like evaluation, compliance, and localization. Protect IP and data sovereignty by requiring Canadian registration of core patents, portable model formats, and transparent data-sharing agreements, while offering flexible IP licensing to attract global partners. Strengthen talent retention by fixing stock-option taxation, easing senior visas, and creating rotational fellowships that let experts work abroad temporarily but stay tied to Canadian employers. Build trade infrastructure around reciprocal AI certifications, privacy-compatible data corridors, and international sandboxes so companies can test and sell across borders without duplicating compliance. Finally, reinforce place-based identity: cluster policies that link universities, compute hubs, and anchor clients in key cities; shared evaluation labs and governance standards that raise trust globally; and branding programs that position “Made-in-Canada AI” as safe, ethical, and world-class. Rooting strength at home while opening coordinated global lanes makes scaling a continuous bridge, not an exit."

"Support AI companies to remain rooted in Canada by providing export assistance, international expansion guidance, and guaranteeing IP protection for scaling ventures. Government should showcase Canadian AI success stories and connect global investors with local firms, balancing global expansion with retention through strategic incentives."

"Canada can strengthen its AI base by turning domestic deployment into a global differentiator. Instead of focusing only on where firms are headquartered, policy should focus on where capability is demonstrated and governed. Companies like Cohere show that global competitiveness comes from local credibility. Canada can build on this by offering secure deployment environments, shared compute infrastructure, and open evaluation frameworks that make staying rooted in Canada an advantage."
Government as champion and procurement-friendly promoter Leveraging government demand, visibility, and international diplomacy to showcase and anchor Canadian AI champions, while creating favorable conditions for growth and export success. 399 19.2%

"Pair global competitiveness with domestic anchors by tying funding to commitments around Canadian jobs, IP, and governance. Government should act as a global champion by showcasing Canadian AI success stories internationally while providing stable demand at home through public-sector adoption. Stronger review of foreign takeovers of strategic firms is also essential. Media and gov should do more to highlight Canadian AI leaders."

"Make it easier for them to tell success stories about work for / with Canadian government agencies by streamlining release requests, having clearly laid out government branding guidelines for organizations wishing to write / draft success stories, and expanding communications staff at federal agencies to assist company storytellers and marketers with the creation of these kinds of stories."

"Recommandation 5 : Que la stratégie nationale positionne le Canada comme leadeur mondial en matière d’IA dans la francophonie internationale et favorise la diplomatie scientifique francophone. Leadeurship du Canada dans la francophonie internationale – Pour faire du Canada un leadeur mondial en matière d’IA, il doit se positionner comme chef de file dans la francophonie internationale. La recherche francophone en matière d’IA favoriserait la normalisation de modèles bilingues, inclusifs, et adaptés aux réalités locales. Le Canada pourra alors contribuer au développement de stratégies et de normes linguistiques. De plus, les chercheuses et chercheurs francophones sont des acteurs clés à la coopération internationale, à la recherche en français, et à la commercialisation dans la francophonie. Ils représentent les meilleurs talents pour favoriser la diplomatie scientifique francophone. La recherche en matière d’IA requerra une collaboration mondiale pour établir des stratégies, des normes linguistiques, et développer des modèles d’IA inclusifs. À l’international, les marchés francophones sont les lieux propices à la coopération et à la commercialisation de modèles canadiens. Les enjeux et biais linguistiques sont multiples dans la conception et la mise en œuvre de modèles. La stratégie nationale permettra d’assurer la normalisation de modèles bilingues, accessibles et abordables. Les chercheuses et chercheurs francophones pourront favoriser la recherche conjointe en français, la diplomatie scientifique, et assurer le rôle crucial du Canada en matière d’IA."
Ethical and Responsible AI Development Prioritizing AI development with strong ethical guidelines, privacy protections, and societal considerations 387 18.6%

"What keeps companies rooted: ethics infrastructure, governance frameworks, trusted reputation. Not just capital. Global markets require responsible AI (EU AI Act). "Canadian AI you can trust" beats "moved fastest." Where's the worker voice in balancing growth with domestic impact?"

"Regulation and prosecution so that the industry follows a minimum of ethical and legal responsibility. We cannot allow an industry which parasites on society to drain the value from creative workers, and labour generally, while promising unrealistic productivity gains. Canada would be better off encouraging legitimate industries and technology, which admittedly includes some amount of applied computer science to large data sets - within ethical and legal bounds."

"By creating truly localized AI that is relevant to our own problems, that collects intentional data about things we care about, and builds machines that analyze it towards our goals. We should turn away from the generalized ANN model, which contains fundamental technical, environmental, and social problems, and instead build non-generalized AI, that is rooted in Canadian communities' concerns."
Talent development, immigration, and education for AI Focusing on building domestic AI capacity through education, workforce development, and immigration policies to ensure a talented, available workforce that can support anchor firms and global growth. 310 14.9%

"Canada should make it easier for talented individuals to apply their skills and experience in the workforce. (For example, a skilled construction professional with a temporary work permit submitted over 200 job applications and received only a few responses — mainly because employers prefer permanent residents. Similarly, another applicant was not selected for a university position despite strong support from the selection committee, as preference was given to candidates with PR status. This limits opportunities for highly skilled temporary residents who could otherwise contribute to the economy right away. Canada should introduce direct permanent residency or fast-track citizenship pathways for professionals in high-demand sectors to ensure their expertise benefits the country immediately. (In another case, a space physicist and a civil engineer couple have been living in Canada since 2021 and are still waiting for a PR invitation, with only one year left on their temporary work permits. There are likely thousands of similar cases — doctors driving Uber, engineers delivering for DoorDash — just to survive instead of working in their professions. This is unacceptable for a country that aims for a bright and innovative future.)"

"Investing in education, upskilling, and reskilling programs (such as workforce AI literacy initiatives) so Canadian firms can access a workforce ready to take on global challenges."

"Talent immigration is a nightmare.We had even automatic a.i. refusal of qualified candidates for immigration. A.i. talent could have an immigration fast track."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 181 8.7%

"This is small minded. Think of sports teams with star players. They get traded and sold to different teams and all over the world constantly. Don’t try to own a creator, support them and hope they stay. If they don’t then fine you have the foundation to support the next one."

"I strongly believe a grassroots approach to be more valuable. By helping Canadians find housing and live healthier lives, we can create the conditions needed to forge robust groups from the ground up."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive
44.3%
922
neutral
11.7%
243
negative
44.0%
917

Question 14

What lessons can we learn from countries that are successful at investment attraction in AI and tech, both from domestic sources and from foreign capital?

Total Responses

2,177

Unique Intents

7

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
AI Investment Skepticism and Risk Cautions about the profitability, sustainability, and societal risks of AI investment; views AI as a possible ‘bubble,’ with calls to avoid or slow down engagement until clear benefits and safeguards exist. 995 45.7%

"Right now, no country has been successful with AI. What we can learn from this is that AI needs to improve significantly before anyone will continue to buy into it. There is strong financial and technical forecasting that the AI bubble is about to burst because it's currently unsustainable in its current form, and because of significant distrust that AI companies have sown with the public. AI companies are simply not proving their value, and not proving they're ethical. That needs to change."

"It’s a bubble, and if we start pouring money into it, it will all blow up and Canadian taxpayers will be left holding in the bag. It should be done thoughtfully with a knowledge that AI is the big buzz word right now and we’ve seen these blowup in our faces before."

"We can learn to avoid overinvesting in AI to the point that it becomes a "resource curse." We can learn that these countries' AI investments present national security risks in the form of degradation to the information environment our citizens operate in, threatening the integrity of our democracy. We can learn that "moving fast and breaking things" comes with severe harms to privacy, copyright and information security, and act accordingly to keep our industry moving briskly WITHOUT breaking anything."
Ethics, Governance, and Social Impact Emphasis on ethical AI development, protection of creators’ rights, privacy, data governance, and environmental sustainability; safeguards against misuse and societal harm. 755 34.7%

"EU built trust through regulation - now attractive for responsible AI investment. Successful countries involve multiple stakeholders, have ethics infrastructure and accountability frameworks. That attracts sustainable investment, not just lowest regulatory burden. Racing without safeguards creates backlash and costly retrofitting."

"My firm is actively involved with Middle East AI stakeholders (Governments regulators, Private Organizations, Technology). It is remarkable to see that AI is not managed as a silo.. A strong focus is put on the collaboration between the players that enables the success of AI. Governance and trust are the core elements (not techno). For example, it means considering how privacy must be managed to enable the success of AI."

"1) Develop AI that doesn't require polluting ANY finite potable water, and everyone will want your AI. 2) Develop AI without infringing ANY copyright, you won't have to worry about lawsuits and save money on development. 3) Pass legislation to protect Canadian drinking water and Canadian copyrights to convince your constituents that you will develop AI responsibly. 4) Facilitate the enforcement and protection of Canadian copyrights already infringed upon by existing AI developers to convince your constituents that you will develop AI responsibly. 5) Have qualified relevant experts conduct thorough studies regarding the environmental consequences of AI and the threat posed to copyright holders by AI. Most importantly, act upon their findings. 6) Communities in the vicinity of a potential AI data center must be thoroughly consulted before building said data centers. Any misinformation or incomplete findings should be penalized. If affected communities reject the construction of a data center, the construction will be terminated."
Canada-Centric Sovereignty, Policy Design, and Anchor Customers Calls to design Canada-specific AI policy and investment programs that preserve sovereignty (data, IP, governance) while using government procurement and anchor customers to de-risk and scale domestic AI champions. 502 23.1%

"Peer jurisdictions succeed because they combine three things Canada often separates: abundant domestic or allied compute; aggressive, one-stop investment and permitting services; and clear, stable AI rules that give investors confidence. Countries like the UK, Singapore, and some EU members attract global AI players by offering access to national or regional data resources, fast-track visas for AI talent, and predictable, risk-tiered regulation—investors know what is in-scope and what is not. Many also pair foreign capital with domestic-control conditions: local data-storage requirements, local boards, or golden-share provisions for strategically sensitive tech. For Canada, the lesson is not to close the door to foreign capital, but to “shape” it—through co-investment with Canadian pensions and the Canada Growth Fund, through IP-location requirements for publicly supported R&D, and through promotion of Canadian AI at G7, OECD and GPAI tables. The jurisdictions that win make it easy to build and scale, but hard to extract core technology; Canada can and should do the same."

"Emulate Israel’s startup supports and Singapore’s infrastructure strategy. Attract global capital with strong IP protections while ensuring Canadian control over strategic assets."

"You should look at Switzerland - they just developed an open source LLM. You should look at Singapore who is paying to upskill anyone over 40. But, focus on your own talent and incentivize tax dollars to be used wisely. Colleges and Universities who do sovereign research. Take a critical look on what you define as Canadian-owned. Much of our big research is foreign owned, on Canadian soil. Also while it’s great you are partnering with UAE, know that you need to build internally first. Otherwise you will always have foreign investors who will have control over companies within Canada. There is always a price to pay."
Talent, Education, Immigration and Ecosystem Building Strategies around education, talent pipelines, immigration policies, and national branding to attract and retain AI expertise; focus on building a distinct, trustworthy Canadian ecosystem. 406 18.6%

"Israel's model shows the power of mandatory military tech service creating a pipeline of AI-trained entrepreneurs, suggesting Canada should expand co-op programs between universities, government labs, and industry. Singapore's sovereign wealth fund co-invests alongside private capital in strategic AI companies, a model Canada could replicate through CPPIB or CDPQ with explicit AI mandates. The UK's "Patient Capital Review" led to pension fund reforms allowing 5% allocation to venture capital - Canada's larger pension funds could unlock $10B+ for domestic AI with similar regulatory changes. France's "AI for Humanity" strategy includes relocation packages covering family visa fast-tracking, housing assistance, and children's education - comprehensive support Canada lacks for attracting global AI talent and their companies."

"Build strong AI infrastructure and balancing environmental protection. Create clear, supportive policies that reduce regulatory friction and give investors confidence. Public funding, targeted tax incentives, and national AI strategies that align research with commercial goals. Another big factor is talent, investing in education, immigration pathways for skilled workers, and partnerships between academia and industry. Finally, foster responsible innovation, with ethical AI frameworks."

"We can learn from countries such as Singapore that place AI literacy on par with basic literacy. Every citizen is required to learn basic AI, and that culturally ensures people are thinking with an AI lens from early on."
Compute Infrastructure & Energy Considerations Focus on sovereign compute, secure data infrastructure, data residency, data trusts, and the environmental implications of data centers and AI compute. 228 10.5%

"Investment in and support of massive domestic infrastructure (data centers/compute, power generation) is foundational. China will surpass other nations in the AI race for a variety of reasons not the least of which is their national wide investment in power and compute. Stable, green energy infrastructure would be a Canadian super power with benefits across the rest of the (non AI) economy."

"Lesson 1: AI is extremely power hungry. Suitably scaled, dedicated power feeds with environmental rules would be a help. Think special zones with SMR utilization plus business majority funding and government minority funding to ensure suitable compliance and environmental oversight. See earlier questions with write-offs, IP rights leasing and retention. The greater the $ multiplier and return the more attractive an energy rich location will be."

"#1. Power- Canada's competative advantage - USE IT. Incorporate low cost cold lake water. Carbon Neutral. A 2024 report by the Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory on energy use in American data centres found that they consumed 4.4 per cent of all total U.S. electricity in 2023, up from 1.9 per cent in 2018. By 2028, the lab said, that consumption could increase to between 6.7 per cent and 12 per cent. For the sake of argument, let’s call it 10 per cent of the total U.S. electricity grid, or 128 gigawatts, which is roughly equivalent to average annual production of Russia or Japan. 2. Study recent creation of US program: Y Combinator is offering Summer Fellows Grants for undergraduate computer science or engineering students, including those from outside the U.S. The grants provide $20,000 in cash and $90,000 in compute credits from Amazon AWS, Microsoft Azure, and Google Cloud Platform. Additionally, selected fellows will receive access to co-working spaces at YC's office, invitations to special events, and an opportunity to present their projects at a Demo Day. The program aims to support students in developing innovative AI applications during the summer."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 225 10.3%

"Learn from their mistakes - what pushed investment away (see the US), and what kept growth from blossoming. You need to reach out to the failed companies and learn what stopped their growth, not the countries who simply are doing what you want to do - get out of the echo chamber built by you trying to emulate a successful nation."

"We can study and collaborate with other countries to determine what works and what doesn't when it comes to growing AI and foreign investments. The Canadian strategy should be based on existing knowledge and a broad look into real scenarios that have already played out around the world."
Targeted Technological Innovation Focusing AI development on specific sectors where Canada can create unique value and solve real-world problems 78 3.6%

"Israel provides a superb example. They have chosen areas where they want to succeed, they have targeted programs to make those areas succeed, they have investment opportunities, and they have a countrywide health system that can be used to help achieve this in the health sector."

"It's all about money and power. Canada can't possibly keep up with the larger countries in this respect. That being said, Canada needs to find its niche i.e. what areas (like the Avro Arrow) could Canada lead the world in? Let's determine this early on and support it so that we become the world leaders in these niche areas."

"Dubai’s government has established institutions and funding channels to support AI ventures. The Dubai Future Foundation (DFF) leads many innovation programs (e.g. Dubai Future Accelerators matching startups with government challenges, and One Million Arab Coders to grow tech talent). A dedicated Dubai Future District Fund (AED 1 billion) provides venture funding, and as of late 2024 it helped attract over $1.65 billion in capital commitments supporting nearly 200 startups. Just as importantly, Dubai offers economic incentives to draw AI companies: free zones like Dubai Internet City and Dubai International Financial Centre (DIFC) grant 100% foreign ownership, zero corporate tax, and easy licensing – creating a pro-business environment. A centerpiece is Sandbox Dubai, a regulatory sandbox launched in 2024 under the Dubai Economic Agenda (D33). It provides a controlled environment where companies can test new AI-powered products and services with flexible regulatory oversight, speeding their path to market. The goal is to develop “future-ready” laws in parallel with technological advances, rather than letting rules lag behind. Through Sandbox Dubai, authorities can grant temporary relaxations or fast-track approvals for pilots, then update regulations based on real-world data, an approach that encourages experimentation while managing risk. This model has already drawn international interest: in 2025 DFF signed a partnership with the AI Center Hamburg to invite European AI startups to test innovations in Dubai’s sandbox as a gateway to Middle East markets. AI in Canadian Healthcare would be a significant risk and challenge for early stage startups."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive
31.2%
680
neutral
14.2%
310
negative
54.6%
1,189

Building safe AI systems and public trust in AI - Pillar Overview

This view aggregates intents across all questions in this pillar, providing a higher-level perspective on the themes.

Questions in Pillar

3

Main Pillar Themes Across Question Intents

7

Total Responses

7,728

Public Survey Analysis

Comprehensive analysis of ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar

Key Themes
View example

Across the responses, prominent themes include the importance of robust regulation and governance, the necessity for transparency and public accountability, and the critical role of public education in demystifying AI. Respondents emphasize that public trust hinges on government-led initiatives, such as clear, risk-based certification standards and transparent disclosures about AI use. There is also a strong focus on ensuring that AI is developed and deployed with considerations for fairness, safety, and inclusivity, with many calls for ethical guidelines and oversight to protect individual rights and promote social good.

Example Response:

"Canada can build public confidence in AI by pairing clear public-sector leadership with transparency and visible public benefit. The federal government should lead by example: advance a proportionate, risk-based law for high-impact AI (alongside the Treasury Board’s Directive on Automated Decision-Making), enforce transparency, fairness and accountability in federal uses, and resource independent oversight. In parallel, deliver the $2B Sovereign AI Compute Strategy so sensitive workloads can run on Canadian-controlled infrastructure. Trust must also be designed into products and services. Organizations should plainly disclose when AI is used, what risks exist, and why a system reached a result; high-impact systems must be explainable. People need practical remedies—clear notices, easy escalation to human review, and avenues to contest decisions—so harms and bias can be addressed quickly. Privacy-by-design, safety testing and post-deployment monitoring should be routine, with results summarized in accessible, bilingual reports. Finally, confidence grows when Canadians see AI improving daily life under strict safeguards."

Main Concerns
View example

The primary concerns raised by respondents revolve around the potential risks of AI: from unchecked technological innovation resulting in bias and discriminatory practices to significant privacy issues and the environmental impact of AI infrastructure. Many respondents worry about the lack of effective regulatory oversight, citing the need for pre-deployment testing, post-market monitoring, and independent auditing to mitigate harms. Additionally, there is considerable apprehension about the socio-economic consequences—such as job displacement, misuse of AI in decision-making, and even the broader societal implications of AI replacing human judgment—demonstrating a deep-seated skepticism about the industry's self-regulation.

Example Response:

"The risks of generative ai are too great both in regards to personal rights and in terms of environmental damage. It should not be invested in or supported. Any ai development must be constrained by broadly, evenly, and heavily enforced ethics regulations and overseen by people with enough funding to monitor and enforce the regulations. Thx industry must not be permitted to regulate itself. Create and enforce ethics and regulations around ai development and use. Update them regularly to avoid loopholing. Restrict generative AI use and prevent the construction of data centers for generative AI in Canada."

Notable Patterns
View example

A notable pattern is the convergence between calls for strong governmental leadership and the insistence on industry accountability, indicating that neither entity alone is seen as capable of establishing the necessary trust. For instance, while some responses (e.g., from the 'Regulation, Safety, and Governance' intent) focus on systemic transparency and enforceable standards, others (such as 'Ban, moratorium, or extreme restrictions on AI') outright reject AI based on its inherent risks. This juxtaposition reveals a polarized outlook where a segment of the public sees structured regulation as the solution, whereas another segment is fundamentally opposed to AI development. Furthermore, the repeated mention of public literacy and inclusion—like in the 'Public education and AI literacy' intent—underscores a pervasive belief that informed citizenry is essential in the governance debate, yet this perspective is noticeably less pronounced when addressing technical safeguards and industry practices.

Example Response:

"I think Canada needs a tiered risk framework with escalating obligations: low-risk apps register basic disclosures; high-risk systems face pre-deployment testing, independent red-teaming, audit trails, and post-market monitoring. Set national baselines for data governance, safety evals, and human-in-the-loop requirements in sectors like health, finance, energy, and public safety. Certification should be earned, not self-declared—think accredited auditors, reproducible safety reports, and penalti"

Public Survey Analysis - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Analyze and synthesize patterns across all survey intent categories for this pillar

About This Analysis

This section provides a comprehensive analysis of ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar. The analysis synthesizes patterns, themes, and concerns across all survey responses that were classified into various intent categories.

Analysis Components

  • Key Themes: Main topics and patterns that emerge across survey responses in this pillar
  • Main Concerns: Primary worries, challenges, or issues raised by respondents
  • Notable Patterns: Interesting trends, unique perspectives, or significant patterns observed in the responses

LLM Query Used

Your task is to analyze the survey responses and provide a comprehensive summary across three dimensions:

1. KEY THEMES: Identify the 3-5 most prominent themes or topics that emerge across all survey responses in this pillar. What are respondents most focused on? What patterns appear across multiple questions? (1-2 paragraphs)

2. MAIN CONCERNS: What are the primary concerns, challenges, or issues raised by respondents? What problems or risks do they highlight? What are they worried about or critical of? (1-2 paragraphs)

3. NOTABLE PATTERNS: Identify any interesting patterns, relationships, or insights that emerge from the data. Are there surprising connections between different intents? Do certain themes appear more frequently than expected? Are there any notable gaps or underrepresented perspectives? (1-2 paragraphs)

IMPORTANT:
- Be specific and cite examples where possible
- Reference specific intent categories by name when relevant
- Focus on substantive insights, not superficial observations
- Maintain the tone and sentiment of the responses (don't sanitize negative feedback)
- Keep each section to 1-2 paragraphs

Additionally, for each dimension, identify ONE intent category and its example response that best illustrates that dimension. Provide the intent name exactly as it appears above.

Respond in JSON format:
{
  "key_themes": "Your analysis here...",
  "main_concerns": "Your analysis here...",
  "notable_patterns": "Your analysis here...",
  "example_key_themes_intent": "Intent Name Here",
  "example_main_concerns_intent": "Intent Name Here",
  "example_notable_patterns_intent": "Intent Name Here"
}

Data Source

This analysis is based on survey responses that were classified into intent categories using an LLM-based classification system. The summary synthesizes insights across all classified responses within this pillar.

Pillar-Level Theme Distribution

These high-level themes capture the main topics across all questions by grouping all intents in this pillar.

Pillar Intent Details

Pillar Intent Description Count Percentage Question Intents
