Question 19

How can we enhance AI literacy in Canada, including awareness of AI’s limitations and biases?

Total Responses

2,439

Unique Intents

7

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Public literacy and awareness campaigns about AI Public-focused education about AI basics, limitations, biases, misinformation, media literacy, and responsible use through campaigns, PSAs, and library/community initiatives. 1,410 57.8%

"Enhance AI literacy by public education campaigns, school & post-secondary curricula, industry workshops, and accessible online courses that cover AI basics, limitations, and biases. Outcome: a population that is informed, critical, and responsible in using AI."

"Canada can boost AI literacy through school curricula, workplace training, and micro-credentials that highlight both AI’s potential and its limits, including bias and misuse. Public awareness campaigns and accessible explainers should demystify AI in daily life. Partnering with industry, academia, and civil society can deliver targeted programs, while adopting international best practices ensures Canadians build informed, critical confidence in using and governing AI."

"Créer des modules accessibles sur les biais et limites de l’IA, intégrés dans les milieux scolaires et professionnels. Lancer des campagnes publiques avec des exemples concrets et collaborer avec les médias pour vulgariser les enjeux éthiques. Il faudrait surtout que ces initiatives soient ciblées en fonction des populations cibles (par ex., initiatives principalement en langue des signes pour la communauté sourde)."
Encourage Practical & Critical Engagement with AI Tools Responses focusing on developing practical skills, such as prompt engineering, critical evaluation of AI outputs, source verification, and hands-on experimentation. This category aims to empower individuals to actively interact with AI tools, understand their mechanisms, and identify their flaws through direct experience. 641 26.3%

"I think literacy has to be practical and skeptical: teach how these systems work at a high level, but spend equal time on failure modes—hallucinations, bias, privacy leakage, over-reliance. Offer workplace micro-credentials (e.g., “AI for finance ops,” “AI for health admin”) co-designed with regulators so compliance and safety are built in. For the public, run open courses and town-hall demos that show both benefits and breakdowns, and publish simple “use/abuse” checklists. Borrow what works fro"

"Core focus: literacy as both confidence and caution AI literacy must go beyond “how AI works” to include how it fails: bias, drift, security risks, and limits of automation. Canadians need to know what AI can and cannot do, how to question its outputs, and when to escalate to human judgment."

"To enhance AI literacy, Canada must abandon passive awareness campaigns and forge a national, experiential learning ecosystem. Literacy is not achieved by telling citizens AI is biased; it is achieved by giving them the tools to see the bias for themselves. This requires a three-pillar strategy: 1. The National Crucible: A Digital Flight Simulator for the Mind. The government must build a public, interactive digital environment where citizens can safely engage with real-world AI failure modes. In this "flight simulator," they can learn to spot deepfakes, interact with biased algorithms, and identify AI-generated propaganda. This is not a course; it is an inoculation. It builds a national "epistemic immune system" by training citizens to recognize manipulation through direct, hands-on experience. 2. "Glass Box" Certification: A Nutrition Label for AI. The government must mandate a "Glass Box" certification for all public-facing AI. This is a simple, clear "nutrition label" that discloses an AI's training data, known limitations, and potential biases. This empowers consumers to make informed choices and holds developers accountable for the integrity of their products. The Steward's Mandate: Forging Internal Guardians. For the workplace, Canada must support the development of a new professional credential: the 3. "Sovereign AI Steward." These are not data scientists, but internal auditors trained to be the ethical and operational guardians of AI within their organizations. They are the human-on-the-loop, ensuring that AI is deployed responsibly from the inside out."
Education system integration (K-12, postsecondary, teacher training) Integrating AI literacy into formal education, from K-12 to postsecondary, with teacher training and curriculum development. 610 25.0%

"AI literacy should start early and continue throughout careers. Canada can integrate AI concepts, including limitations, ethics, and bias, into high school, college, and university programs, not just computer science but business, healthcare, and trades. In the workforce, micro-credentials and short training programs can make AI skills accessible to all job types, from technical to operational roles."

"Enhancing AI literacy in Canada means ensuring citizens, students, and workers understand both the opportunities and the limitations of AI, including risks of bias and misuse. This requires national curricula, public campaigns, and training programs that combine technical know-how with ethics and critical thinking. For AI Future Leaders, embedding AI literacy and safety in K–12 and educator training widens the pipeline and builds a generation ready to engage with AI responsibly."

"AI literacy should not be treated as a technical skill but as a form of critical consciousness. Children must grow up understanding not just how to use AI tools, but how to think alongside them—how to question, interpret, and guide them. In schools, AI education should begin with teaching cognitive biases and how they shape both human judgment and algorithmic outputs. Students should learn that AI can “hallucinate,” that digital spaces often mirror personal interests rather than objective reality, and that truth online requires triangulation from multiple sources. Equally important is cultivating imagination and agency. Young people should see AI as an extension of their creative and analytical mind, not a substitute for it. They should learn to lead creation rather than be led by algorithms, to design with intention instead of passively consuming. When students learn to analyze abundant information, detect bias, cross-check perspectives, and create with awareness, AI becomes a tool of empowerment rather than manipulation. Teaching these principles early would produce a generation that sees AI not as a mystery, but as a partner in thought—one they can guide with wisdom, imagination, and integrity."
AI skepticism / opposition to AI Responses that express distrust, call for banning or halting AI, or emphasize perceived harms and dangers without endorsing its use. 551 22.6%

"I am against AI in principle and in practice. "AI" usage has been shown to affect the way people use their brain. https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ Data centers use an inordinate amount of energy and water and other necessary natural resources. https://andthewest.stanford.edu/2025/thirsty-for-power-and-water-ai-crunching-data-centers-sprout-across-the-west/ I also object vehemently the fact that training "AI" requires the theft of text, visual, and audio art, as well as people's identity and personhood. "AI" is currently used for observation and extraction of personal information, encroaching in the basic right to individual privacy. I cannot in good conscience support anything related to the current iteration of "AI.""

"No to AI. As technology cannot be held accountable for its decisions, it should never be in a position to make decisions that impact real people. No to AI."

"The phrasing of this survey's questions make me intensely anxious that its developers are the right people to enhance GENUINE literacy about AI in this country. In other words, I'm not convinced that these questions are themselves the product of AI literacy. Until the "we" implied in this question ("How can we enhance AI literacy in Canada") has a clear grasp on AI's manifold limitations and biases, including the mostly US-centric objectives of the largest AI companies and the shockingly authoritarian impulses of the current American administration, then the "we" shouldn't be responsible for enhancing AI literacy."
Workplace training, micro-credentials and workforce upskilling Structured training for workers and organizations, including micro-credentials, certifications, and on-the-job AI literacy initiatives. 537 22.0%

"Goal: not hype, but critical understanding of capabilities + limits. - Workplace training: national AI literacy certificate (entry, intermediate, domain-specific), co-delivered by colleges + institutes. - Professional standards: integrate AI ethics, bias awareness, and model limits into continuing ed (law, medicine, finance, engineering). - Public literacy: plain-language campaigns explaining AI’s strengths, blind spots, and risks; mandatory disclosures for gov AI use."

"Basic AI literacy should not involve extensive, long training - it should be applied to the workplace context, be practical/applied, and accessible 24/7 through online education. Public post secondary should not be tasked with delivering AI literacy, but could provide more advanced learning - certificate, for credit education and beyond; but this shorter industry-specific training should be led by industry who address awareness, limitations and bias suited to their context."

"My literacy checklist (teach this, not buzzwords): What the system does, 2) where it fails, 3) how to check it, 4) how to roll back, 5) how to report issues. Workplace programs: 15-Minute Drills: “spot a prompt-injection,” “bias check,” “write a model card in plain English.” Red-team Fridays (monthly): teams try to break their own tool; log lessons; fix by Monday. Facts Labels on every tool: purpose, data, limits, human contact. Manager kits: how to set guardrails, measure value, and avoid magical thinking. Public awareness (simple + trusted): Library & clinic sessions: live demos with failure cases; Q&A. Short video PSAs: “AI can be wrong—here’s how to check.” School pack (K–12): five lessons: what it is, where it fails, bias basics, privacy basics, when to ask a human. International best moves to copy (without the cosplay): Short contracts and 30-day payments for pilots. Independent audits and public incident logs. Apprenticeships with pay, not just courses."
Regulation, transparency, governance and labeling Policies and mechanisms to regulate AI, ensure transparency, require disclosure and accountability, labeling and warning systems. 416 17.1%

"Increase transparency and accountability In the absence of transparency, Canadians' trust in AI diminishes. People must be able to understand when and how AI is used, and who is responsible for its outcomes. Mandate disclosure of high-impact AI systems: Require both public and private sector organizations to clearly disclose when they are using high-impact AI systems that affect people's lives. This applies to areas like screening for jobs, evaluating credit applications, or making decisions in healthcare. Ensure human oversight: A human-in-the-loop approach for high-impact decisions should be a standard. Studies show public comfort with AI-driven decisions increases significantly when human supervision is guaranteed."

"Regulate the claims that AI products make about themselves to ensure truthfulness. Require labeling of AI generated content. Publicly hold AI companies to account for their failures."

"The Danish government's recent clamp down on the creation and dissemination of AI-generated deepfakes, by changing copyright law to make it so that their citizens "own their face, voice, and other likeness" as a copyright, is a model we should look to."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 104 4.3%

"Notre secteur compte plus de 3 300 bibliothèques publiques réparties dans les zones urbaines, suburbaines, rurales et éloignées, et dispose d’un réseau collaboratif solide qui nous permet d’avoir une portée nationale efficace tout en maintenant une présence locale. Les bibliothèques publiques sont des centres communautaires essentiels dans chaque quartier du Canada. Les bibliothèques publiques sont connectées à des centaines de fournisseurs de services et institutions clés dans les contextes locaux, ce qui permet d’étendre encore leur portée. Notre succursale Russell a de très beaux partenariat avec La maison de la famille d'Embrun et le Centre-On-Y-Va de Casselman. La Bibliothèque publique du canton de Russell collabore avec la municipalité de Russell afin d'optimiser les ressources et offrir un service ouvert 7 jours sur 7 (succursale Russell) et 6/7 à Embrun pour le moment."

"Basic comprehension literacy is already heavily impaired and we're here talking about new form of literacy? Fix basic literacy first."

"Invest in art programs and follow Valentine Goddard's proposed best curatorial practices based on narrative ethics and well-researched art-based pedagogies."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive

1,126
neutral
22.9%

negative
31.0%
757

Question 20

What can Canada do to ensure equitable access to AI literacy across regions, demographics and socioeconomic groups?

Total Responses

2,162

Unique Intents

5

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Universal Access Infrastructure Promotes building universal AI literacy access through public infrastructure and services (libraries, schools, community centres), including offline/low-bandwidth materials, device lending, and multilingual resources to reach rural, remote, and underserved communities. 919 42.5%

"Equity starts with access. The federal government should pair universal, affordable connectivity and devices with locally delivered learning. Broadband build-outs and low-cost plans must be matched by device programs and secure public access points in schools, libraries, Friendship Centres and community hubs, so rural, remote and low-income learners can actually participate. Materials should be bilingual and, where appropriate, available in Indigenous languages and accessible formats (captioned video, screen-reader friendly, plain-language summaries). Delivery must be community-led. Provinces, territories, municipalities and Indigenous governments should co-design curricula and workshops that reflect local needs, with funding that enables trusted partners—schools, colleges, libraries, settlement agencies, disability organizations and youth groups—to host free, recurring sessions. Programs should remove practical barriers through stipends for childcare and travel, paid micro-internships, and loaner laptops and hotspots. Content must cover both “how to use AI” and “how to question it,” including bias, privacy, security, provenance and routes to human review. Employers and the public sector can widen the funnel by recognizing stackable micro-credentials in hiring and procurement, and by offering paid release time for workers to upskill. Crown corporations and major departments should model best practice by publishing plain-language notices and evaluations in public services, turning real deployments into learning opportunities. Finally, a national equity dashboard—co-managed with provinces and Indigenous partners—should track participation, completion, job placement and regional coverage, so funding moves to where gaps persist and programs evolve with community feedback. This approach treats AI literacy as essential public infrastructure—delivered locally, inclusive by design, and backed by measurable accountability."

"Canada can ensure equitable access to AI literacy by making programs available both virtually and physically across the country. Virtual workshops allow people in remote or rural areas to participate, while in-person workshops make it accessible for those without strong internet or digital tools. These programs should provide certificates on AI knowledge so participants can show practical skills to employers. Industry and government should collaborate to fund and deliver these workshops, ensurin"

"We should have a national frontier model that competes with the best out there and every citizen has access to it. It needs to be treated like a universal utility like electricity."
Skepticism & Ethical Considerations Captures skepticism, caution, and calls for restraint or regulation: concerns about environmental impact, data privacy, misinformation, dependence on AI, or outright opposition to AI; emphasizes need for ethics, guardrails, and public deliberation. 891 41.2%

"Generative AI steals from rights holders and has a terrible environmental impact. Studies also show that AI users lose the ability to think critically. Also, it is dangerous to put the sensitive data in Canadians into the hands of companies that would claim perpetual ownership over said data. I think the Canadian government should avoid investing or using AI."

"Require disclaimers on any AI-generated output that it requires additional analysis and cannot be relied on as a sole source of information. We need to understand that AI Literacy doesn't mean 'people scared to use AI' - The far bigger concern right now is people becoming reliant on AI tools, and its impacts on the reliability of information and the degradation of critical analysis."

"If you truly believe that equitable access to AI literacy is more important than funding real, impactful measures to our society like funding social programs, public transit, food accessibility and education, you disgust me. Accessing a machine that can inaccurately read a google search result is not something Canadians need. Canadians need programs from the government to address the issues that are destroying the middle and lower class. It is deeply insulting that the government is even considering AI as the answer to these issues instead of actually funding and educating the people."
Localized, Community-Centered Delivery Shifts emphasis to delivery through trusted local actors and tailored content: schools, libraries, Indigenous organizations, settlement services, and community groups, with community ambassadors and co-design to fit local needs and languages. 556 25.7%

"Canada can ensure equitable AI literacy by applying subsidiarity: empower local schools, libraries, and Indigenous education authorities to lead delivery, while federal and provincial governments fund infrastructure and set standards. Industry partners co-develop inclusive training and credentials. Public campaigns, mobile labs, and culturally relevant content foster informed confidence across regions, demographics, and socioeconomic groups."

"Last-mile enablement: fund community training through libraries, settlement agencies, Indigenous institutes, Friendship Centres; deliver in English/French and local/Indigenous languages. Rural & remote access: connectivity + device lending + traveling “AI labs on wheels.” Targeted supports: stipends/childcare for low-income learners; accessible design for disabilities. Industry role: compute credits, volunteer instructors, and paid micro-internships for under-represented groups."

"As an officially bilingual nation, with many other languages also calling our country home, Canada can be a leader in helping to push AI beyond its current English-dominated systems. Languages throughout the world are being lost due to a lack of use, and that is also the case in Canada. AI can be an opportunity not only to save our indigenous languages but also to expand them. One must recall that it's not just the words we're saving, but also the meaning and context behind them. For often the way of speaking is the way of thinking, and to deny our vast multitude of other languages and cultures is to deny ourselves. For this, Government need not to be - and should not be - the solution providor, but can be the one that sets the initiatives and benchmars that must be met. The government, meanwhile, should focus on solidifying all the datasets and expanding them to be multilingual. Where government financial support can be beneficial is through language lab funding, as seen in Finland. Those, though, would have the dual advantages of not only being sources of action but also serving as think tank knowledge hubs that provide benefits back to the local community."
Affordability & Barriers Removal Emphasizes removing practical barriers to participation: free or low-cost training, subsidies for internet and devices, stipends, and job-bridging supports to enable participation for low-income and underrepresented groups. 550 25.4%

"Ensure equitable AI literacy by subsidizing digital education, expanding online learning, funding community programs, and integrating AI into schools nationwide, with targeted support for underserved regions and groups."

"Provide access to free training and incentives to do so for all levels of income (i.e. Pay-What-You-Can), well-paid starting jobs in AI or AI-adjacent fields and government-subsidized online or community-based hands-on workshops. Don't think top-down, put literacy in existing structures, which will build trust by showing you have a desire to learn about your own customers/citizens at their level."

"Excellent question, and a very essential topic to invest in. As AI tools contnue to be deployed into all varieties of industries and sectors, the need for compettive free-access alternatives has never been greater. Subscription models, or complex learning curves restrict equitable access among Canadians, creating disparity and further risk of bias, racism, and socio-economic detriments. A Federally pioneered free-to-use model of many LLM's and AI tools could level the playing field and provide more opportunities for citizens, sectors, and organizations to enhance their position and elevate their participation - these tools would require at least a base level of guidance and training."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 224 10.4%

"As above. With a critical addition. Canadian post secondary institutions CANNOT keep up. There are too many provincial regulations and too few government regulators to vet and approve new curricula. This can often result in literally two years of delay between an institution's efforts to add AI to their curricula and when that curricula is finally approved by (the extremely limited number) of provincial staff tasked with these approvals. This bureaucratic bottleneck has to be solved."

"Outside of the production of some fun, generative toys, the vast majority of AI development is hyperfocused on B2B applications and automating business processes in order to reduce labour costs. Canadians across regions, demographics and socioeconomic groups are already struggling to find a productive use-case for AI apart from fun toys. The focus of this survey appears to be focused on B2B applications as well. This question strikes me as performative."

"Update mandatory reading to include books like The Chaos Machine by Max Fisher. No one NEEDS to read a lot of mandatory reading that was decided decades ago. One of my parents and I both had to read the Chrysalids in high school—we both thought it was dumb and had no impact on our lives or education. Meanwhile, had The Chaos Machine by Max Fisher been available at the time as mandatory reading, it could have had a profound impact on understanding social media and AI. Also, create a mandatory digital literacy course every student must take. Too many mandated courses never prove practical. Instead, a course taught by true digital literacy experts—focusing on relevant, real-world skills and understanding online safety—would better prepare students for today's digital environment."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Infrastructure - Pillar Overview

This view aggregates intents across all questions in this pillar, providing a higher-level perspective on the themes.

Questions in Pillar

3

Main Pillar Themes Across Question Intents

5

Total Responses

5,403

Public Survey Analysis

Comprehensive analysis of ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar

Key Themes
View example

Across the responses, a few prominent themes emerge. Many respondents focus on identifying gaps in Canada’s AI infrastructure, particularly citing limitations in high-performance compute, data accessibility, and connectivity. They emphasize how these gaps, such as those noted in the 'Compute and data infrastructure gaps' intent (e.g., missing AI-ready cloud and HPC resources), hinder Canada’s ability to compete globally. Additionally, there is a strong call for a sovereign approach to AI infrastructure, with several responses advocating for Canadian-controlled compute facilities, robust governance frameworks, and public–private models to ensure that investments benefit domestic capabilities.

Example Response:

"Infrastructure gaps holding back AI in Canada: Compute – limited high-performance, AI-ready cloud and HPC resources. Data – fragmented, siloed, or inaccessible datasets for research and training. Connectivity – uneven broadband and low-latency networks, especially in remote regions. Barriers to building sovereign infrastructure include high capital costs, long ROI timelines, talent shortages, complex data governance, and regulatory uncertainty."

Main Concerns
View example

The primary concerns revolve around the financial, technical, and sustainability challenges associated with developing AI infrastructure in Canada. Respondents worry about the high capital costs and long return-on-investment periods, as well as dependency on foreign hyperscalers, which could undermine national sovereignty. Environmental impacts also feature prominently; for instance, the 'Environmental, ethical, and societal concerns about AI and infrastructure' intent details issues such as enormous energy consumption, water usage of data centers, and potential negative impacts on local communities and ecosystems. These challenges highlight a deeper anxiety about balancing technological advancement with environmental and sovereignty risks.

Example Response:

"136. The energy and water required to run data centres is astronomical and at a time when extreme climate events are becoming more frequent and amid concerns about drought and access to fresh water. The immense amounts of electricity data centres require to operate isn’t just a problem for the large companies sinking hundreds of billions into AI. It’s a threat to our national economy as well. It causes huge increases in electricity costs and frequently results in power outages and water use ordinances for nearby residents. The environmental devastation is unacceptable. Even “advanced” closed-loop cooling systems that reportedly have the potential to reduce water usage by upwards of 50 to 70 percent, still use too much water. In its latest sustainability report, Microsoft itself said that it consumed more than 125 million litres of water per year per data centre. In 2024, one data centre in Iowa consumed 1 billion gallons of water that year. Even a reduction of 70 percent of that conservative Microsoft 125 million figure would still mean the data centre would be consuming more than 37 million litres of water per year. Also, moving from evaporative systems to mechanical closed-loop cooling increases data centre power usage, increasing the amount of air pollution generated. While closed loop cooling systems are an improvement on the open loop systems that consume monstrous amounts of fresh water, they still result in waste water called "blowdown," which is regularly released to prevent the buildup of toxic contaminants. If released (or even “accidentally leaked”) into the surrounding environment, this concentrated blowdown would have a devastating environmental impact on area residents and wildlife."

Notable Patterns
View example

A notable pattern is the interplay between technological shortcomings and broader policy issues. While several respondents offer technical critiques—such as gaps in compute capacity and regional connectivity—others push for comprehensive governance models to manage these deficiencies, exemplified by responses in the 'Public/Sovereign AI Infrastructure and Governance' intent. This duality shows that while there is recognition of the need to upgrade and expand infrastructure, there is also an insistence on ensuring that such advancements remain under Canadian control and are developed sustainably. Furthermore, a bifurcation is observed where some voices advocate strongly for AI, proposing hybrid public–private solutions, while others remain skeptical of AI altogether, concerned about its broader societal implications.

Example Response:

"Equitable access means any researcher, start-up, SME, or public body can obtain secure compute, data, and tooling without relocating or overpaying. Canada should offer a tiered, Canadian-controlled infrastructure fabric: national HPC for training and safety research; regional GPU clusters for fine-tuning and high-throughput inference; and local/edge capacity for latency-sensitive uses in health, agriculture, energy, and Northern communities. Access should be brokered through a single portal with transparent queues, credits, and service-level targets, reserving capacity for SMEs and public-interest projects. Hyperscalers remain part of the mix, but must operate within Canadian data-residency, privacy, and security requirements. Where hyperscaler regions meet those standards, governments can negotiate volume pricing and standardized “sovereign landing zones” so smaller users benefit from scale without surrendering control. For critical workloads, default to Canadian-owned facilities; for burst capacity, use certified clouds with contractual residency, audit, and exit provisions. Open-source models and tools are essential to affordability and inclusion. Public funding should maintain Canadian OSS model checkpoints, evaluation suites, and MLOps tooling so users can run “good-enough” AI on modest hardware. Paired with edge computing—on-prem servers, 5G/MEC sites, community micro-data centres—this reduces bandwidth costs and keeps sensitive data local. Finally, wrap access with supports: compute and storage credits for SMEs and researchers; secure data clean rooms and sector data trusts (incl. OCAP/CARE where relevant); technical concierge services; and interprovincial reuse of validated architectures. Publish a bilingual dashboard on capacity, regional uptake, and wait times. This blended approach—public HPC, certified cloud, OSS, and edge—keeps access fair, costs predictable, and control in Canadian hands."

Public Survey Analysis - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Analyze and synthesize patterns across all survey intent categories for this pillar

About This Analysis

This section provides a comprehensive analysis of ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar. The analysis synthesizes patterns, themes, and concerns across all survey responses that were classified into various intent categories.

Analysis Components

  • Key Themes: Main topics and patterns that emerge across survey responses in this pillar
  • Main Concerns: Primary worries, challenges, or issues raised by respondents
  • Notable Patterns: Interesting trends, unique perspectives, or significant patterns observed in the responses

LLM Query Used

Your task is to analyze the survey responses and provide a comprehensive summary across three dimensions:

1. KEY THEMES: Identify the 3-5 most prominent themes or topics that emerge across all survey responses in this pillar. What are respondents most focused on? What patterns appear across multiple questions? (1-2 paragraphs)

2. MAIN CONCERNS: What are the primary concerns, challenges, or issues raised by respondents? What problems or risks do they highlight? What are they worried about or critical of? (1-2 paragraphs)

3. NOTABLE PATTERNS: Identify any interesting patterns, relationships, or insights that emerge from the data. Are there surprising connections between different intents? Do certain themes appear more frequently than expected? Are there any notable gaps or underrepresented perspectives? (1-2 paragraphs)

IMPORTANT:
- Be specific and cite examples where possible
- Reference specific intent categories by name when relevant
- Focus on substantive insights, not superficial observations
- Maintain the tone and sentiment of the responses (don't sanitize negative feedback)
- Keep each section to 1-2 paragraphs

Additionally, for each dimension, identify ONE intent category and its example response that best illustrates that dimension. Provide the intent name exactly as it appears above.

Respond in JSON format:
{
  "key_themes": "Your analysis here...",
  "main_concerns": "Your analysis here...",
  "notable_patterns": "Your analysis here...",
  "example_key_themes_intent": "Intent Name Here",
  "example_main_concerns_intent": "Intent Name Here",
  "example_notable_patterns_intent": "Intent Name Here"
}

Data Source

This analysis is based on survey responses that were classified into intent categories using an LLM-based classification system. The summary synthesizes insights across all classified responses within this pillar.

These high-level themes capture the main topics across all questions by grouping all intents in this pillar.

Pillar-Level Theme Distribution - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Group question-level intents into higher-level pillar themes

About Pillar-Level Themes

Pillar-level themes are created by grouping similar question-level intents across all questions in a pillar. This provides a higher-level view of the main topics being discussed across the pillar.

The LLM analyzes all question-level intents and their descriptions, then creates broader thematic categories that capture the essence of multiple related intents.

LLM Query Used

Please analyze these intents and create 4-6 pillar-level intent categories that:
- Capture the overarching themes across all questions in this pillar
- Are distinct and meaningful
- Cover the breadth of topics in the question-level intents
- Are named clearly and concisely
- **Each pillar intent MUST map to at least 2 different question-level intents** (if a theme only appears in one question, it's too specific for a pillar-level category)
- **PRESERVE THE TONE AND SENTIMENT** of the question-level intents:
  * If question intents express skepticism, opposition, or concerns → pillar intent should reflect that negative/cautious tone
  * If question intents are supportive or positive → pillar intent should reflect that positive tone
  * If question intents are neutral/descriptive → pillar intent should be neutral
  * Do NOT sanitize or neutralize negative sentiments - keep them explicit

Respond in JSON format:
{{
    "pillar_intents": [
        {{
            "name": "Pillar Intent Name",
            "description": "Clear description of what this pillar-level intent represents"
        }},
        ...
    ],
    "mapping": {{
        "Pillar Intent Name": ["Question Intent 1 name only", "Question Intent 2 name only", ...],
        ...
    }}
}}

IMPORTANT: 
- Each question-level intent should map to at least one pillar-level intent
- A question-level intent can map to multiple pillar-level intents if appropriate
- Ensure all question-level intents are included in the mapping
- **Each pillar intent must map to at least 2 question-level intents** - if you find a theme that only appears in one question, either:
  1. Broaden the category to include related intents from other questions, OR
  2. Map that single intent to a broader existing category, OR
  3. If it truly doesn't fit anywhere, it will be automatically added to "Other"
- CRITICAL: Match the tone/sentiment of grouped intents - don't make negative intents sound positive or vice versa!

Question 21

Which infrastructure gaps (compute, data, connectivity) are holding back AI innovation in Canada, and what is stopping Canadian firms from building sovereign infrastructure to address them?

Total Responses

1,981

Unique Intents

6

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Investment, risk derisking, and governance for sovereign infrastructure Barriers to financing and deploying sovereign AI infrastructure, including high capital costs, uncertain demand, regulatory barriers, and the need for public-private investment models and anchor customers. 691 34.9%

"Canada’s AI infrastructure gap spans compute, data, and connectivity. National high-performance compute remains far below peer nations, pushing researchers and firms to foreign clouds and raising sovereignty, cost, and continuity risks. Sensitive and high-value datasets are fragmented across provinces and institutions, with uneven standards and limited secure “clean-room” access to train and evaluate models. Connectivity is still inconsistent in rural, remote, and Northern communities, limiting participation in data-intensive work and cloud services. Canadian firms aren’t simply “building our own” because the economics are hard: hyperscale data centres and GPU clusters require billions in upfront capital, long lead times for power, transformers, and chips, specialized talent to operate safely, and predictable multi-year demand. Without anchor offtake from governments and Crown agencies, investors price projects as high risk. Permitting, interconnection, and siting add delay; reliance on foreign chip supply constrains timelines; and privacy/sector rules complicate lawful data access for training and evaluation. Government’s role is to de-risk and crowd in capital while preserving Canadian control. Priority actions include long-term procurement and compute offtake agreements (research, health, utilities, defence) tied to Canadian-controlled facilities; accelerated permitting and interconnection for AI-class data centres; targeted tax credits and accelerated depreciation for domestic GPU/AI hardware; clean-power PPAs and waste-heat reuse; and public–private partnerships that welcome allied investment but keep data residency, model weights, and operational control in Canada. In parallel, build sector data trusts and secure research environments with harmonized standards (incl. OCAP/CARE) so firms can train on Canadian data lawfully. Together with the Sovereign AI Compute Strategy, these steps convert today’s gaps into bankable projects and durable, sovereign capacity."

"Canada faces gaps in large-scale compute power, diverse high-quality data, and nationwide high-speed connectivity, limiting AI innovation. Building sovereign infrastructure is stalled by high upfront costs, uncertain ROI, and fragmented incentives. To derisk investment, government should co-fund infrastructure projects via public-private partnerships and a sovereign wealth fund, ensuring strategic alignment and data sovereignty."

"The Canadian government will need sovereign AI compute resources, and can de-risk development by committing to purchase capacity if industry builds it. Canada desperately needs an east-west backbone project, a digital railroad for Canada. Far too much of our fibre plant runs north-south, which makes sovereign network connectivity impossible. For example, there are Canadian public cloud regions, but they are often many hops away, with no effective way to avoid routing through the US, which exposes the infrastructure to security and policy risks. This perspective highlights not just the capital challenge but also the critical, overlooked need for coherent connectivity as part of the sovereign infrastructure strategy."
Sovereign infrastructure governance and policy framework Calls for a national, Canadian-controlled governance framework for AI infrastructure, including data sovereignty, data trusts, procurement rules, and limits on foreign-capital dominance. 647 32.7%

"I think that we need a national strategy for both AI and non-AI digital infrastructure in Canada. We need to have datacenters with power, cooling, and workers nearby to be able to deploy both AI models, but also the supporting infrastructure. This needs to be actually located in Canada, and controlled by a Canadian company that is not subject to the whims of foreign courts and powers, so that we are in control of our own destiny. If this does not exist, the government should provide LoIs or other terms to allow local companies to actually build such infrastructure. There also needs to be enforcement "teeth" to prevent foreign capital (private equity, etc.) from buying up such infrastructure in Canada, once it is built and profitable."

"It's all in the States, and most of the stuff that claims to be in Canada still runs on top of US cloud providers (AWS, Azure, DigitalOcean etc.) so is effectively hosted in the States. Stop that. Build (or enable, or support, or fund, or whatever) truly sovereign Canadian infrastructure that we can trust to use securely. That would have more impact than burning money to derisk a commercial pipeline."

"The Sturgeon Lake Cree Nation in Northern Alberta have raised concerns about a massive, 58-building, gas-powered data centre development proposed by Kevin O’Leary on their traditional lands. Both the municipal and provincial governments support the project, which is advancing without the First Nation having consented to nor been consulted about it. I would suggest that Indigenous governments could help stop Canadian firms from building environmentally destructive "sovereign infrastructure" but evidently they can just be ignored."
Compute and data infrastructure gaps Gaps in domestic compute capacity (HPC/GPUs), secure data environments, and interoperable data access; sovereignty and governance considerations for building in-country infrastructure. 545 27.5%

"Infrastructure gaps holding back AI in Canada: Compute – limited high-performance, AI-ready cloud and HPC resources. Data – fragmented, siloed, or inaccessible datasets for research and training. Connectivity – uneven broadband and low-latency networks, especially in remote regions. Barriers to building sovereign infrastructure include high capital costs, long ROI timelines, talent shortages, complex data governance, and regulatory uncertainty."

"The biggest gaps are access to affordable compute and high-quality Canadian datasets. Canadian researchers and start-ups rely heavily on U.S. hyperscalers, which limits sovereignty. The cost of sovereign infrastructure is too high for individual firms, so government must derisk through large-scale funding, public–private partnerships, and predictable long-term support."

"We don’t have a strong chip industry anymore, as we had in the past. That is a hard one, but we should explore even if it takes decades. As an example, as soon as Nvidia can be avoided we should due to their shady business practices. Other than that, we should be smart and even expand our investment into figuring out more efficient and environmentally friendly ways of running the infrastructure. Micro nuclear power plants and more efficient thermal solutions for data centres are definitely a way."
Environmental, ethical, and societal concerns about AI and infrastructure Concerns about energy/water usage, environmental impact, sustainability, ethical considerations, and broader societal harms of AI and large data-center deployments. 485 24.5%

"The energy and water required to run data centres is astronomical and at a time when extreme climate events are becoming more frequent and amid concerns about drought and access to fresh water. The immense amounts of electricity data centres require to operate isn’t just a problem for the large companies sinking hundreds of billions into AI. It’s a threat to our national economy as well. It causes huge increases in electricity costs and frequently results in power outages and water use ordinances for nearby residents. The environmental devastation is unacceptable. Even “advanced” closed-loop cooling systems that reportedly have the potential to reduce water usage by upwards of 50 to 70 percent, still use too much water. In its latest sustainability report, Microsoft itself said that it consumed more than 125 million litres of water per year per data centre. In 2024, one data centre in Iowa consumed 1 billion gallons of water that year. Even a reduction of 70 percent of that conservative Microsoft 125 million figure would still mean the data centre would be consuming more than 37 million litres of water per year. Also, moving from evaporative systems to mechanical closed-loop cooling increases data centre power usage, increasing the amount of air pollution generated. While closed loop cooling systems are an improvement on the open loop systems that consume monstrous amounts of fresh water, they still result in waste water called "blowdown," which is regularly released to prevent the buildup of toxic contaminants. If released (or even “accidentally leaked”) into the surrounding environment, this concentrated blowdown would have a devastating environmental impact on area residents and wildlife."

"I do not want AI. I want a liveable planet, and AI is an enormous, pointless use of resources."

"We have so many wonderful natural resources here. It would be horrible to destroy them to build a data centre so that Todd can skip having to write a birthday message to his sister."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 471 23.8%

"When I hear "which infrastructure gaps" I immediately think of things like - clean drinking water to all Canadians, high speed rail from coast to coast, commuter rail in Nova Scotia, resilient power supplies, resilient renewable power production, urban green infrastructure, cheap affordable housing supply. These are holding back Canadians big time. Should AI be at the front of this queue? no. Wait in turn please."

"None. Maybe you could focus on ensuring all indigenous communities have access to fresh water, like this government promised over a decade ago."

"'AI' is a solution in search of problems. The first thing to do is to identify problems where machine-learning might actually help. Then, fund research and development in those areas."
Connectivity and regional digital access Gaps in reliable, affordable high-speed internet and backhaul, especially in rural, remote, and northern regions; impediments to edge AI and distributed data/workloads. 354 17.9%

"Affordable (or free) high-speed internet should be available to all Canadians, regardless of where they live."

"Connectivity. Need to have fiber in more cities, and better cellular connections in different regions. Half of the country needs better internet."

"Canada should put up a soverign Starlink internet system now. Canadian soverign infrastructure is held back by a lack of willingness to make stragetic investments in infrastructure that matters to Canadians - leaving us to be undercut and hamstrug by the USA. We should look to middle powers like Sweden, Finland, Norway, Poland, Switzerland, Ukraine, South Korea for examples on how to go it alone. We need to learn how to handle dissenting voices in Canada. A democracy does not mean that everyone agrees - just the majority."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive
13.1%
260
neutral
22.9%
455
negative
63.9%
1,268

Question 22

How can we ensure equitable access to AI infrastructure across regions, sectors and users (researchers, start-ups, SMEs)?

Total Responses

1,745

Unique Intents

6

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Public/Sovereign AI Infrastructure and Governance Advocates for public ownership or government-led governance of AI infrastructure, regional public compute hubs, data sovereignty, transparent governance, and publicly funded access for all regions. 650 37.2%

"Equitable access means any researcher, start-up, SME, or public body can obtain secure compute, data, and tooling without relocating or overpaying. Canada should offer a tiered, Canadian-controlled infrastructure fabric: national HPC for training and safety research; regional GPU clusters for fine-tuning and high-throughput inference; and local/edge capacity for latency-sensitive uses in health, agriculture, energy, and Northern communities. Access should be brokered through a single portal with transparent queues, credits, and service-level targets, reserving capacity for SMEs and public-interest projects. Hyperscalers remain part of the mix, but must operate within Canadian data-residency, privacy, and security requirements. Where hyperscaler regions meet those standards, governments can negotiate volume pricing and standardized “sovereign landing zones” so smaller users benefit from scale without surrendering control. For critical workloads, default to Canadian-owned facilities; for burst capacity, use certified clouds with contractual residency, audit, and exit provisions. Open-source models and tools are essential to affordability and inclusion. Public funding should maintain Canadian OSS model checkpoints, evaluation suites, and MLOps tooling so users can run “good-enough” AI on modest hardware. Paired with edge computing—on-prem servers, 5G/MEC sites, community micro-data centres—this reduces bandwidth costs and keeps sensitive data local. Finally, wrap access with supports: compute and storage credits for SMEs and researchers; secure data clean rooms and sector data trusts (incl. OCAP/CARE where relevant); technical concierge services; and interprovincial reuse of validated architectures. Publish a bilingual dashboard on capacity, regional uptake, and wait times. This blended approach—public HPC, certified cloud, OSS, and edge—keeps access fair, costs predictable, and control in Canadian hands."

"Equitable access means sovereign infrastructure that serves all. We must be sovereign: provide regional compute hubs, open-source model support, and SME credits. Require hyperscalers to interoperate with Canadian systems and uphold Consent, Compensation & Control. Ensure rural and underserved communities get priority access through universities, colleges, and union-led training sites."

"Equitable access spans compute, connectivity, & investment. This response focuses on the data & metadata layer enabling participation across sectors. Equitable AI access isn’t about giving everyone GPUs—it’s about giving everyone authority over verified data. The infrastructure that matters most is the knowledge layer, not the compute layer. The Principle — Federated, Not Centralized Canada should treat AI infrastructure as a federated public utility: regional compute, storage, & data nodes linked by shared metadata standards. Universities, libraries, & nonprofits host local nodes that interoperate through national frameworks. Regional Equity Connectivity enables participation. Rural & northern regions need broadband & local compute hubs so communities can contribute verified data & run models. Edge computing supports privacy-sensitive, real-time uses—vital for health, agriculture, & remote areas. Sectoral & User Equity - Researchers access verified datasets & public-interest compute. - Startups build on open-source models trained on verified Canadian data. - SMEs use free tools to contribute structured information. Equity means a pottery studio in rural Quebec has the same digital authority as a Toronto AI lab when both publish to the same verified layer. Role of Hyperscalers Use hyperscaler compute for generic workloads; keep sovereign data & public models in Canada. Procurement must require data residency, provenance, & portability so workloads can move to sovereign infrastructure. Government’s Role - Fund regional compute nodes as civic infrastructure. - Provide connectivity grants for rural & northern access. - Tie public R&D to open-data and interoperability standards. Set provenance rules for any AI system receiving public funds. Close: Equitable access doesn’t mean equal hardware—it means equal power to participate. When AI infrastructure is federated, verifiable, and open by design, Canada moves from access as subsidy to access as sovereignty."
Skepticism, Regulation or Prohibition of AI Encompasses calls for strict regulation or outright bans on AI, concerns about environment, governance, ethics, and societal impact. 598 34.3%

"No to AI. As technology cannot be held accountable for its decisions, it should never be in a position to make decisions that impact real people. No to AI."

"AI should be strictly regulated, if not banned outright"

"AI LLMs are destructive forces that harm Canada and Canadians, environmentally, psychologically, and culturally. We can ensure equitable access by shutting it down beyond very rare useful scientific endeavours. No one needs AI in their search engine, their fridge, or their remote control."
Open Source & Community Access Emphasizes open-source models, datasets, and tools; community-driven and publicly auditable infrastructure to lower barriers and avoid vendor lock-in. 372 21.3%

"Open source models are vital to help avoid biases and make AI-reliant or derived decision-making transparent and fair. They also ensure that any investments or efforts by the government can be compounded by future work that leverages and evolves the open source models. Frequently open source licensing precludes commercial activity = the standard licensing should allow commercial use and reuse, so Apache 2 and similar permissive licenses are a must to ensure equitable access to all."

"I have no idea, frankly. But I think equitable access would mean ensuring small businesses and creators can use AI tools, not just big tech. Canada should support open-source models so innovation is fair across all regions of Canada."

"Equitable access to AI infrastructure is not achieved through government-run allocation committees or complex subsidy programs. These centralized models are inherently slow, biased, and create artificial scarcity. True equity is a byproduct of massive abundance and a fiercely competitive market. The path to equitable access has two pillars: 1. Create Massive, Domestic Abundance: The government's single most important role is to execute the "Grand Bargain." By leveraging our national energy advantage to attract multiple, competing hyperscalers (both foreign and domestic) to build massive data centers on our soil, we create a domestic surplus of compute power. This intense competition is the most powerful force for driving down costs and democratizing access for everyone—from a researcher in a university to a startup in a rural town. Abundance is the ultimate equalizer. 2. Radically Lower the Barrier to Entry: We must embrace the technologies that make infrastructure more accessible by default. -Open-Source Models as a Public Good: Canada should champion and contribute to the open-source model ecosystem. These models, which can be run on commodity hardware, are a powerful check on the power of proprietary systems and provide a baseline of access for all. -AI as the Great Simplifier: The most profound force for equitable access will be AI itself. AI-powered development tools are abstracting away the need for deep infrastructure expertise. A small business owner will soon be able to deploy a sophisticated AI system with a simple plain-language prompt. The government's role is to ensure a competitive market for these simplifying tools, not to try to build them itself. Equity is not about fairly dividing a small, government-controlled pie. It is about creating an environment so abundant and competitive that everyone has access to the ingredients to bake their own."
Regional & Rural Edge Computing and Local Hubs Focus on bringing compute closer to users via regional hubs and edge computing to reduce latency, improve access in rural/northern areas, and support localized AI applications. 299 17.1%

"To make AI infrastructure more accessible across Canada, we need a mix of public investment, open tools, and strong partnerships. Governments can work with big cloud providers to offer affordable access for startups, researchers, and small businesses while also funding regional compute hubs so innovation isn’t limited to big cities. Expanding broadband and edge computing in rural areas will help level the field, and promoting open-source models and shared datasets lets smaller players compete."

"Build regional AI hubs with shared compute clusters. Offer open-source model libraries and cloud credits to startups and researchers. Include edge compute access for remote communities and nonprofits."

"If an ethical, specific-purpose, LLM-like AI model is small enough to be downloaded or shipped in a thumbdrive, use by SMEs should soon follow. If the goal is simply exposure across regions, kiosks in railroad stations and post offices could be a good start, but bear in mind that this should not be done until we can be sure we have developed our own, actually-ethical actually-controlled actually-speific-purpose AIs, otherwise the backfire will be immeasurable."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 298 17.1%

"It's unlikely we can. There are stiff barriers of entry to building a fully new AI system from the ground up, with minimal benefit at this point. Building on an existing framework loses IP independence, and puts investors at the whims of flashy lying marketers. Instead of investing in big businesses, we should make more substantial fundamental investments in people and establishing a baseline quality-of-life. If people have more freedom to live and pursue education and have a safety net when experimenting with ideas, we will get fresh creative results instead of just chasing trends."

"You can't ensure that and you shouldn't. You need to stop shooting for equality of outcome and start considering equality of opportunity. You can't hope to create some monolith for a centrally-planned economy, you need to trust that these regions and sectors and users can take care of themselves, provided you support them. You're doing top-down, this survey is an indication of that. You need to do it bottom-up. The fact this survey exists tells me you won't do that. Honestly, you probably can't."

"Better funding for schools and universities in general, not just compete and data science. If you want ethical implementation like the previous question suggested, then there needs to be good consistent funding for humanities, and science students need the money and time to take broad, diverse classes outside of their field."
Hybrid Public-Private Model with Guardrails Proposes a mix of public infrastructure and private cloud capacity (hyperscalers) with guardrails such as data residency, pricing caps, portability, and tiered access for researchers, SMEs and startups. 277 15.9%

"Create a federated national fabric: regional sovereign clouds + shared GPUs, with reserved tiers for researchers, startups, and SMEs. Use open-source models where viable; support edge computing for remote/industrial sites. Require fair-use pricing and portability across providers. Hyperscalers can participate, but data residency, auditability, and exit rights must be mandatory. Reference platforms like TPTN can expose secure APIs to lower access barriers."

"Set up a two-tier system that combines a Canadian HPC backbone with pooled cloud credits, both wrapped in a single access portal. Researchers get queue-based access with fair scheduling, while startups and SMEs receive predictable credits tied to milestones like prototyping, evaluation, and commercialization. Hyperscalers can co-invest and colocate with Canadian partners, but pricing and data residency must be transparent. Open-source models and edge inference should be first-class options so teams in remote regions can run useful workloads without constant backhaul. If access includes hands-on engineering support, templated MLOps stacks, and legal templates for data sharing, smaller players will actually use the infrastructure rather than watch it from the sidelines."

"Tiered access model: reserved pools for research/public interest; SMB credits for evaluation and fine‑tuning; pay‑as‑you‑go for burst inference. Regional hubs: colocate compute + data clean rooms at colleges/polytechnics; attach connectivity upgrades and on‑site support. Hyperscaler partnerships with conditions: discounted credits convertible to sovereign capacity; portability of artifacts (models, eval reports, datasets). Open‑source first: fund Canadian‑tuned open models, toolchains, and eval suites; ensure weights and artifacts can run on sovereign hardware. Edge computing: grants for on‑prem edge boxes in hospitals, municipalities, and plants; managed updates and remote attestation for security. Fair queuing and quotas: transparent schedulers, regional carve‑outs, and anti‑hoarding rules; publish utilization dashboards. Hands‑on enablement: “Implementation clinics” and a national help‑desk for data readiness, secure MLOps, and evaluation. 90‑day action: Launch an SMB Infrastructure Passport providing credits, training, and priority queues at two regional hubs and one hyper-scaler partner."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

728

Question 23

How much sovereign AI compute capacity will we need for our security and growth, and in what formats?

Total Responses

1,674

Unique Intents

5

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
AI Skepticism / Opposition Strong anti-AI sentiment; concerns about harms, economic risks, environmental impact, and social disruption. Calls to refrain from investment, ban AI, or view AI as a harmful bubble. 685 40.9%

"I am against AI in principle and in practice. "AI" usage has been shown to affect the way people use their brain. https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ Data centers use an inordinate amount of energy and water and other necessary natural resources. https://andthewest.stanford.edu/2025/thirsty-for-power-and-water-ai-crunching-data-centers-sprout-across-the-west/ I also object vehemently the fact that training "AI" requires the theft of text, visual, and audio art, as well as people's identity and personhood. "AI" is currently used for observation and extraction of personal information, encroaching in the basic right to individual privacy. I cannot in good conscience support anything related to the current iteration of "AI.""

"AI, especially LLM AI, is a security nightmare and shouldn’t have anything to do with security at all. It’s the opposite of security and growth. It’s a bubble about to burst."

"The mere fact that you are asking this question is depressing. Please don't build massive data centres in Canada. We're already seeing the devastating impacts these data centres are having on communities in the US: https://www.techpolicy.press/data-center-boom-risks-health-of-already-vulnerable-communities/, https://www.canarymedia.com/articles/fossil-fuels/how-the-data-center-boom-could-harm-black-communities, https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2025/apr/24/elon-musk-xai-memphis. Let's not go down this road. Please."
Strategic, Balanced, & Context-Specific Sovereign AI Responses that support sovereign AI compute but emphasize a pragmatic, tiered, phased, or limited approach. They often suggest prioritizing specific critical sectors, balancing public/private roles, focusing on efficiency, or leveraging partnerships while maintaining control over sensitive areas. 520 31.1%

"Canada needs scalable, secure AI compute tailored for research, industry, and national security. Hybrid formats—cloud, edge, and regional supercomputing—balance flexibility and sovereignty. Forecasting models should integrate public and private demand, ensuring capacity meets growth while safeguarding ethical, equitable, and sustainable use, reflecting responsible stewardship and societal benefit."

"Canada needs a balanced AI compute capacity strategy where a core sovereign compute infrastructure supports national security, data sovereignty, and critical research, while the majority of demand is met through partnerships with hyperscalers. Economic models forecast growing total compute needs driven by both public sector (security, research, regulation) and private sector (startups, SMEs, large enterprises) growth, with hyperscalers providing scalable, cost-effective resources at volume. Sovereign capacity should focus on specialized high-trust workloads, secure data environments, and foundational R&D, delivered via on-premises data centers and government clouds. The broader compute demand is best addressed through hybrid models combining domestic infrastructure with cloud services from global partners, optimizing cost, scale, and agility."

"Plan in tranches tied to demand: training-capable clusters for top labs/missions; large-scale inference for public services and SMEs; and secure enclaves for sensitive data. AI Compute Access fund is a great start, but the process has been slow so far comparing to the speed at which market moves these days. Mix of public and private capacity under common standards; maintain the ability to surge for national priorities. Keep costs predictable via long-term offtake and energy deals, and evaluate annually."
Sovereign AI Compute for Security and Growth Strong preference for building and maintaining onshore Canadian AI compute capacity—national hubs, edge nodes, distributed and Canadian-owned, with public-private funding. Formats include centralized national clusters, regional hubs, edge infrastructure, and air-gapped, secure environments to preserve sovereignty and resilience. 510 30.5%

"Canada will need a large base of sovereign AI compute if we want both security and growth. Right now we are far behind the US, Europe, and Asia, and renting from foreign hyperscalers leaves us exposed. The format should be national data centers with subsidized access for startups, SMEs, and researchers, combined with public sector capacity for health care, defence, and critical infrastructure. For growth, free or low-cost compute should be available for early-stage companies for a number of year"

"Canada will need significant sovereign AI compute to secure both growth and national security. Demand will rise across public services, defence, healthcare, and private sectors. A mix of national high-performance compute hubs, secure cloud, and regional edge facilities is required. Economic forecasting models should guide capacity planning, balancing public-sector resilience with private-sector scale, while ensuring trusted, sovereign access to critical AI infrastructure."

"Asking "how much" sovereign AI compute Canada needs is a strategic error. In an exponential era, any fixed number is obsolete upon arrival. The correct measure is not a static quantity, but a dynamic, national commitment expressed as a "Sovereign Compute Ratio." Canada should not aim for a specific number of GPUs, but to ensure that no less than 70% of its critical AI workload—across public and private sectors—runs on Canadian-owned, sovereign infrastructure. This ratio is the ultimate metric for both security and growth. It is a declaration of digital independence. Formats must follow a federated, "Sun-Stars-Embers" model to ensure equitable access and resilience: • A national "Sun" cluster for forging foundational models and for national security applications. • Regional "Star" nodes to power academic research and industrial collaboration. • Local "Embers" at the edge to empower SMEs with data privacy and agility. Traditional economic forecasting is irrelevant here. We cannot predict the demand of an exponential curve. Instead, our national strategy must be to build sovereign capacity at a rate that consistently outpaces the growth of our reliance on foreign-controlled platforms. The goal is not to meet a forecast; it is to own the future of our own forge."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 246 14.7%

"I believe that, in time, the large compute capacity demand will diminish. Experts will discover a way to achieve more productivity, using less energy and in smaller applications (Stanford students published an article about powering their model using the equivalent energy to light a lightbulb). There will be new ways of computing (quantum and the next generation beyond) and solving problems and new hardware and software. Daniella Rus, MIT, studies robotics and is working on creating smaller AI brains that will be stand alone and not rely on connection to foundational models in the cloud."

"This is an ever growing demand. We also need to consider the impact of growing quantities of e-waste. Find ways we can mine e-waste in Canada without environmental impact and access the rare materials without having to increase destructive mining practices."
Market-Driven / Private-Sector-Led Compute with Standards Arguments that private sector demand should drive compute capacity, with the government providing standards, incentives, and demand guarantees rather than building and owning capacity. Emphasizes hybrid models, competition, and leveraging private capital. 115 6.9%

"You don’t size sovereign compute by guessing a number; you make Canada the easiest place to build, and supply shows up. It’s basic supply and demand. Government’s job isn’t to pick a petaflop target. It’s to create demand certainty and remove friction so private providers over-deliver. Use simple tools that move the market: portable compute credits redeemable with Canadian or allied clouds, 90-day pilot procurements that auto-scale on success, and a reinvestment tax regime that keeps win money cycling into new builds. Providers will add racks wherever those signals exist. For security, keep a minimal sovereign reserve under Canadian control for classified workloads and critical incidents. Make it small, hardened, and surgeable via pre-negotiated contracts with multiple Canadian-operated data centres. Everything else should ride on competitive cloud and colo markets with clear SLAs, data-residency covenants, and exit ramps if a vendor underperforms."

"Any compute must be domestic, and regulations need to be in place to ensure it, but the government should have no part of building out this infrastructure. This is the job of private industry."

"ChatGPT said: Canada’s long-term security and economic growth depend on building strong, privately driven AI compute capacity that serves both business and public needs. The focus should be on creating a competitive, self-sustaining market for compute rather than relying on government to build or operate it. Private investment will lead if the environment is predictable, profitable, and supported by clear national standards for data protection, reliability, and access. Canada should aim for enough domestic compute to meet research, commercial, and national security needs without depending on foreign control. That means establishing multiple private data and compute centres across provinces, powered by renewable energy and connected through secure, high-speed networks. The federal government’s role is to set standards, offer limited early-stage incentives, and guarantee demand through long-term procurement in key sectors like health care, energy, and defence. Private demand will grow faster than public needs. Industry sectors such as advanced manufacturing, health technology, and resource management will require large-scale compute for real-time data analysis, automation, and AI-driven design. Economic models suggest demand could double every 18 to 24 months, so flexible investment and rapid scaling are critical. To stay secure and competitive, Canada should support hybrid formats: private hyperscale facilities, regional data centres, and smaller edge systems that keep data close to use. Public agencies can purchase compute from Canadian-owned providers instead of building new infrastructure. This approach leverages private innovation to strengthen public capability. A thriving private AI infrastructure sector will anchor Canada’s economic growth, attract global capital, and protect national sovereignty by ensuring our most critical compute resources remain in Canadian hands."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

26.0%

neutral
26.9%

47.1%
