33.3%
624
neutral
26.2%
491
negative
40.5%
759

Question 26

Where can AI better position Canada’s protection and defence? What will be required to have a strong AI defensive posture?

Total Responses

1,739

Unique Intents

7

All Matching Intents Distribution

This chart shows all intents that matched each response, not just the primary intent. A single response may include multiple intents.

FILTERS

Intent Details

Note: Response examples are only available when respondent type is set to 'All'
Intent Category Description Count Percentage Response examples
Anti-AI in defense Responses arguing that AI should not be used in Canada’s protection and defence, including calls for bans or avoidance of AI in defence-related contexts. 613 35.3%

"Again, AI must not be introduced into any area so critical as defence. Funding must go to humans in these areas, so they can recognize vulnerabilities, quantify threats and respond appropriately given the circumstances -- something that modern AI is simply incapable of doing."

"Canada does not need to use AI for defense, and it would be more suitable to have its citizens understand how AI can be easily exploited by others to prevent a reliance on AI from making the country vulnerable."

"I am against AI in principle and in practice. "AI" usage has been shown to affect the way people use their brain. https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ Data centers use an inordinate amount of energy and water and other necessary natural resources. https://andthewest.stanford.edu/2025/thirsty-for-power-and-water-ai-crunching-data-centers-sprout-across-the-west/ I also object vehemently to the fact that training "AI" requires the theft of text, visual, and audio art, as well as people's identity and personhood. "AI" is currently used for observation and extraction of personal information, encroaching on the basic right to individual privacy. I cannot in good conscience support anything related to the current iteration of "AI.""
Ethics, privacy, civil society concerns Concerns about ethics, privacy, civil liberties, misinformation, environmental impact, and societal consequences; calls for safeguards and responsible use. 557 32.0%

"Generative AI steals from rights holders and has a terrible environmental impact. Studies also show that AI users lose the ability to think critically. Also, it is dangerous to put the sensitive data in Canadians into the hands of companies that would claim perpetual ownership over said data. I think the Canadian government should avoid investing or using AI."

"Enact legislation to prevent AI from using any material without consent. Do not allow companies to replace people’s jobs with AI. Do not allow AI companies to pollute clean water and drain the power grid. People will not trust AI until they have reason to."

"Protection of Canadians to me means protecting our housing, protecting our health. If Canada dismantled it's systems of oppression the world over, we wouldn't have anyone we need defending from. Stop exploiting other countries for their resources and every aspect of Canadian society will be safer. Another big threat to our sovereignty and livelihoods as Canadians is mass disinformation campaigns that utilize AI to target individuals and manipulate them through subtle means to radicalize them towards hateful and oppressive viewpoints. The rise of fascism in Canada can be directly traced to this sort of thing. Election campaigns that utilize AI powered disinformation campaigns for the benefit of the politicians in it for themselves and their corporate profits should be illegal. All corporate interest is a threat to Canadians. Capitalism itself is the greatest threat to our lives and livelihoods as it deprioritizes the health and well being of the people and rewards those who seek profit over all else."
AI in defense use-cases and capabilities Illustrative defense use-cases and capability enhancements enabled by AI (ISR, cyber, logistics, autonomous systems, threat detection, etc.). 455 26.2%

"Artificial intelligence can be a force multiplier for Canada’s security and defence. AI systems excel at analyzing vast data to spot threats (like cyber intrusions or foreign influence) faster and more accurately than human analysts. In cybersecurity, AI can monitor networks in real time to detect anomalies and block attacks. On the battlefield, AI-enhanced decision support improves situational awareness and reaction speed – enabling Canadian commanders to outpace adversaries. From intelligence analysis to autonomous surveillance drones and predictive logistics, AI can boost efficiency, precision, and early warning across defence domains. Building a strong AI defensive posture will require coordinated effort and foresight. Canada’s Department of National Defence plans to be AI-enabled by 2030 to keep pace with allies, which demands major investments in technology and talent. Experts note that overcoming AI challenges needs sustained collaboration across government, industry and academia. Key requirements include cultivating AI-skilled personnel (leveraging Canada’s top-tier AI research base), ensuring AI systems are secure and used ethically (with humans in the loop for critical decisions), and deepening partnerships with allies on AI capabilities and norms. By setting clear security standards and investing in domestic AI innovation (to uphold digital sovereignty), Canada can maintain a defensive edge. Ongoing R&D, strategic foresight, and international cooperation will ensure Canada’s protection and defence remain strong in an AI-driven future."

"AI can strengthen Canada’s defence in intelligence, cybersecurity, autonomous systems, and decision support. To be strong: sovereign compute, skilled AI-cyber talent, clear standards, cross-sector collaboration, and continuous R&D."

"Canada’s defensive posture must evolve from system protection to system adaptation. AI is already reshaping how command, sensing, and decision cycles interact, and Canada risks being locked out of future coordination networks if it treats AI as a tool rather than an actor in its security ecosystem. The real advantage lies in building an adaptive command layer that fuses foresight, simulation, and live AI testing into defence planning. The next alliances will form around shared machine logic."
Governed and human-in-the-loop AI for defense Support for using AI to strengthen defense, but with strict governance, ethical frameworks, transparency, and human oversight. 417 24.0%

"AI can strengthen defence by detecting cyber intrusions, exposing disinformation campaigns, and enabling faster responses to threats. A strong posture requires coordination across government, industry, and civil society, with standards that ensure transparency and human oversight. Canada should also create a social-media equivalent of the Amber Alert system to quickly warn citizens about verified disinfo or AI-driven attacks, supported by skilled analysts and resilient sovereign infrastructure."

"I don't think the need for human oversight and monitoring will ever be 'not needed'. It may aid in making suggestions, but final decisions related to security and defense will always need the watchful oversight of a human being . I think AI integration should be moving at a snail pace as opposed to a race to see who can be first to the finish line adopting this new technology."

"Imagine a national security blockchain—an integrated digital spine connecting every Canadian institution, business, and citizen in a shared defense ecosystem. Instead of cybersecurity being limited to a few agencies or experts, this system would treat every participant as a node in a living network of trust and protection. Each node, from a local business to a major research lab, would contribute data verification, threat detection, and ethical reporting, secured through transparent blockchain protocols. Such a model would transform Canada’s approach to digital defense from reactive to collective. It would create a continuously authenticated layer of truth across communications, transactions, and information sharing. Deepfakes, data tampering, or cyber intrusions could be traced instantly through cryptographic validation. The system would not only defend against attacks but also reinforce ethical AI behavior, ensuring that the same technology used to deceive can instead be used to verify. This civic-cyber framework would represent a new kind of national security—one that merges technology, ethics, and civic responsibility. By turning digital defense into a shared mission, Canada could pioneer a model where cybersecurity is not an elite function, but a democratic act of protection, powered by everyone connected to the national digital fabric."
Public policy coordination & international norms Calls for cross-sector governance, coordination, and alignment with allies, standards, and international norms. 307 17.7%

"Collaboration with countries that support strong AI regulation (like EU) can help Canada to retain its sovereignty while also having allies that will support it. It would be hypocritical to use AI against other countries, but perhaps Canada could use AI to identify possible threats more efficiently."

"Coordination between public and private sector, standards in security, data governance and AI governance."

"Superintelligence is a global issue, and it requires a global solution. Canada is well-positioned to lead an effort to ban the creation of superintelligent AI via international treaty. Canada needs to signal that it would sign a treaty, and facilitate dialogues between US and Chinese officials, the two key players in the AI race. Please. The lives of all our children are at stake. The book "If Anyone Builds It, Everyone Dies" by Yudkowsky and Soares is the best resource for learning more."
Sovereign AI infrastructure and data sovereignty Advocacy for Canadian-owned compute/data and architecture to avoid dependence on foreign tech. 251 14.4%

"It is imperative that Canadian physical AI infrastructure (data centres, power generation & fibre optic connectivity) be as sovereign as possible and to the greatest extent ensure that data leaving Canada passes through as few counties as possible before reaching the end destination. We must proactively start taking steps to limit the amount of our data that passes through the United States."

"AI can strengthen Canada’s protection and defence by enabling faster threat detection, cyber resilience, intelligence fusion, and autonomous support for surveillance, logistics, and decision-making. A strong defensive posture will require sovereign compute and data control, rigorous AI red-teaming and evaluation hubs, trusted procurement standards, and a workforce trained in both AI operations and cyber defence."

"A strong AI defense posture requires secure, sovereign infrastructure to develop and test technologies. Located in proximity to Canadian military bases, a data centre campus at Genesee could provide a Tier IV-capable environment for Canadian-controlled compute, supporting defense-related AI applications in a secure, resilient framework. This would ensure national autonomy, reduce exposure to foreign infrastructure risks, and enables Canada to lead in defense innovation."
Other Responses that do not fit the main intents, do not directly answer the question, or are nonsensical or off-topic anecdotes. 219 12.6%

"Building Canadian AI Industrial Champions The barriers (why scale stalls) Customers: slow enterprise/public procurement; few “lighthouse” wins Capital: thin late-stage financing; IP/compute seen as intangible risk Talent: senior operator gap; immigration frictions; retention costs Go-to-market: compliance/assurance burdens; global sales muscle Infrastructure: costly GPUs/data access; security & privacy hurdles The support stack (own the podium) 1) Customers on day 1 Mission lighthouse pr"

"It’s time to stop shoveling millions of taxpayer dollars into the bottomless pit of pseudo‑excellence programs like CERC—schemes that masquerade as innovation drivers while functioning as prestige‑laundering machines for bureaucrats and over‑credentialed careerists. These initiatives, once framed as engines of discovery, have devolved into bloated showcases of mediocrity: glossy press releases, ceremonial appointments, and vanity metrics substituting for actual scientific work. If research funding were serious about excellence, it would invest in those who build, experiment, and publish transparently. It would back multidisciplinary teams that deliver reproducible results instead of rewarding institutional pageantry. Science is not a branding exercise—it’s a discipline of proof. Until funding systems redirect resources toward demonstrated skill and impact, these “excellence” programs will remain monuments to publicly subsidized complacency."

"A strong AI defensive posture is simply a strong society. We need to increase funding to libraries, schools, healthcare, social assistance, we need to implement UBI and $10/day childcare and free university."

Note: Percentages do not necessarily add up to 100% due to some responses having more than one intent.

Sentiment Analysis
positive
27.9%
485
neutral
24.0%
417
negative
48.2%
839

Sentiment Analysis - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-5-nano (or selected model)

Purpose: Classify survey responses into intent categories and analyze sentiment

Sentiment Classification

Each response is analyzed for sentiment as part of the classification process. The LLM determines whether the response expresses:

  • Positive: Optimistic, supportive, or constructive tone
  • Neutral: Objective, informational, or balanced perspective
  • Negative: Critical, concerned, or highlighting challenges

Prompt Extract (Sentiment Component)

Please analyze this response and provide:
3. The sentiment of the response (positive, negative, or neutral)

Respond in JSON format:
{
    "sentiment": "positive" or "negative" or "neutral",
}

Processing Details

The sentiment analysis is performed simultaneously with intent classification:

  • Each response is analyzed individually by the LLM
  • Sentiment is determined based on the overall tone and language used
  • The analysis considers context and nuance in the responses

Note: Sentiment reflects the tone of the response, not necessarily agreement or disagreement with AI policy.

Multiple Intent Classification - LLM Query Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-5-Nano (or selected model)

Purpose: Classify survey responses into intent categories based on validated taxonomy

Validation Models: Google Gemini-Flash-2.5, Anthropic Claude-Haiku-4.5, Cohere Command-R-Plus

Multiple Intent Classification

Each response is analyzed to identify all relevant intent categories that significantly overlap with the response content. Survey responses often address multiple themes simultaneously, and the LLM evaluates:

  • Primary intent: The dominant category that best captures the response's main focus
  • All matching intents: All categories where the response has significant overlap with the intent definition
  • Self-Confidence level: How certain the primary intent classification is (high, medium, or low)
  • Context awareness: Understanding of both English and French responses

Prompt Extract (Classification Component)

Please analyze this response and provide:
1. The PRIMARY intent category that best fits this response
2. ALL intent categories that this response significantly overlaps with
3. The sentiment of the response (positive, negative, or neutral)
4. Your self-confidence level in the primary intent classification

Respond in JSON format:
{
    "primary_category_name": "The name of the best-fit category",
    "primary_category_number": The number (1-N) of the primary intent category,
    "all_matching_intents": ["List", "of", "all", "category", "names", "that", "significantly", "overlap"],
    "sentiment": "positive" or "negative" or "neutral",
    "self_confidence": "high" or "medium" or "low"
}

IMPORTANT: 
- Responses may be in both English and French
- For all_matching_intents, include ALL categories where the response 
  has SIGNIFICANT overlap with the intent definition
- The primary_category_name should always be included in all_matching_intents
- A response can match multiple intents simultaneously

Processing Details

The classification process involves:

  • Each response is analyzed individually by the LLM
  • The model compares the response against all available intent categories from the validated taxonomy
  • Categories are provided with both names and descriptions to ensure accurate matching
  • The LLM identifies ALL categories where significant overlap exists, not just the primary intent
  • The LLM considers the full context and nuance of each response
  • Bilingual responses (English/French) are handled appropriately

Note: Responses commonly address multiple themes. The primary intent represents the dominant focus, while "All Matching Intents" captures every category with significant overlap. This multi-label approach provides a more complete understanding of response content.

"Other" Category - Example Selection Information

Model Information

Model: Azure OpenAI GPT-4o-mini

Purpose: Identify insightful "Other" category responses that provide valuable perspectives outside main intent categories

About the "Other" Category

The "Other" category captures survey responses that did not fit into the main intent categories defined in the taxonomy. Though many of these responses are off-topic or incomplete, others may represent unique perspectives, edge cases, or themes that fall outside the primary classification structure.

Example Response Selection Process

For the "Other" category specifically, the example responses displayed were selected using a different approach from the other categories:

  • Selection Method: Examples were chosen by identifying insightful and meaningful comments from the "Other" category
  • LLM Involvement: The LLM analyzes all "Other" responses to identify those that are particularly insightful, well-articulated, and representative of unique viewpoints
  • Purpose: To showcase the diversity and depth of responses that fall outside standard categorization
  • Criteria: Examples were selected based on their insight value, clarity, representativeness of unique viewpoints, and potential to inform policy considerations

Prompt Extract (Example Selection)

You are analyzing survey responses for Canada's National AI Strategy consultation, 
specifically looking at responses that were classified as "Other" because they didn't 
fit into the main categories.

QUESTION: {question_text}

EXISTING CATEGORIES:
{list of existing category names}

RESPONSES CLASSIFIED AS "OTHER" (Total: {count}, Showing: {sample_count}):
{numbered list of responses}

Your task is to identify up to 3 "diamond in the rough" responses - insightful, 
thought-provoking answers that:
1. Do NOT fit into any of the existing categories above
2. Are NOT garbage (trolling, profanity, blank, irrelevant, or nonsensical)
3. Provide unique, valuable perspectives or insights about Canada's AI strategy
4. Are substantive and meaningful (concrete suggestions, novel ideas, deep reflections, etc.)

If there are fewer than 3 truly insightful responses, only return those that genuinely 
meet the criteria. Quality over quantity.

Respond in JSON format:
{
    "examples": [
        {
            "type": "diamond",
            "response": "the actual response text"
        }
    ]
}

Return an empty array if no responses meet the criteria.

Why This Approach Matters

Unlike other intent categories where examples are randomly sampled or systematically selected, "Other" category examples are curated to highlight:

  • Novel perspectives: Viewpoints not captured by existing categories that may represent emerging themes
  • Edge cases: Responses that may inform future taxonomy refinement or reveal gaps in current categorization
  • Thoughtful contributions: Well-reasoned responses that deserve attention despite not fitting standard classifications
  • Policy relevance: Insights that could inform policy considerations even if they fall outside mainstream themes

Note: This curation approach ensures that valuable insights in the "Other" category are not overlooked, even though they may represent a smaller portion of responses. The goal is to surface meaningful contributions that might otherwise be lost in aggregate statistics.

Combined Analysis

Integrated analysis of expert reports and public consultation by pillar.

Research & Talent

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories

Common Ground
View examples

Both the expert reports and public survey responses underscore the importance of developing and retaining top-tier AI talent while maintaining ethical research and practical pathways to commercialization. Experts such as James Neufeld and Patrick Pichette emphasize the need for strong domestic talent pipelines, robust funding for research institutions, and streamlined immigration processes; similarly, public respondents in categories like 'Talent, immigration & workforce' and 'Economic Growth, Talent & Commercialization' stress that Canada must foster training, competitive compensation, and career opportunities to attract global expertise. Both groups broadly agree that a flourishing AI ecosystem demands a combination of sustained investment, strategic recruitment, and the integration of ethical and practical considerations to ensure Canada’s global competitiveness.

Example Responses:

"Talent: Retaining top researchers and attracting international leaders requires career pathways that allow fluid movement between academia, startups, and industry. Fellowships, joint appointments, and sabbaticals ensure ideas move from lab to real-world application while fostering innovation without forcing trade-offs between scholarship and commercialization. Infrastructure: Accessible, world-class compute and curated datasets are table stakes. Federated data platforms, secure compute networks, and standardized benchmarking allow Canadian teams to experiment at scale while protecting privacy and intellectual property. Green, energy-efficient infrastructure reinforces global leadership while aligning with Canada’s ethical and environmental values. Governance & Policy: Clear, enforceable standards around privacy, fairness, accountability, and transparency are essential. Oversight bodies, ethics boards, and reproducibility requirements ensure research outputs are trustworthy, defensible, and exportable. Public and private funding mechanisms must tie to both technical milestones and ethical guardrails, so innovation doesn’t outpace responsibility. Culture & Collaboration: Ethical grounding comes from embedding human-centric values into research design. Collaborative networks across universities, industry, government, and defence can align incentives while protecting academic independence. Encouraging cross-disciplinary teams — bringing in social scientists, ethicists, and domain experts — ensures solutions are technically brilliant and socially responsible. Commercialization Pathways: Talent and ideas are insufficient without scalable impact. Supporting startups and spinouts with risk-tolerant funding, mentorship, and early adopter partnerships ensures Canadian innovations reach the world while remaining accountable to Canadian values. In short, Canada’s AI competitiveness depends on a balanced ecosystem: brilliant people, world-class tools, and practical pathways"

"Talent. Canada needs to make it easier for AI talent to call Canada home. There are graduate students in Quebec from leading institutions who are unable to get permanent residence due to language and immigration politics. It shouldn't be this difficult of these researchers have a desire to stay in Quebec and Canada as a whole. I strongly encourage the administration to consider a Global Talent Visa like those in the UK where researchers who have graduated from the top 50 institutions in the world, get a fast-tracked visa to settle in Canada. And especially for those who have spent years in graduate school in Canada, could easily have a clear path towards permanent residency."

"To remain globally competitive and ethically grounded, Canada must rethink how it prepares talent and fosters innovation. This begins with revamping post-secondary education to reflect the realities of an AI-driven world. Urgent conditions to address: - Modernize academic programs across disciplines, recognizing that AI is reshaping nearly every career path. Universities must evolve from traditional knowledge transmission to experiential, adaptive learning models. - Design inclusive learning environments that support neurodivergent students, who often bring exceptional creativity and nonlinear thinking. These individuals are uniquely positioned to drive innovation, yet current systems often fail to support their success. - Destigmatize alternative pathways to expertise. A four-year degree should not be the sole marker of credibility, especially in fields like marketing, design, and digital strategy where hands-on experience and adaptability often outweigh formal credentials. - Invest in lifelong learning ecosystems that include micro-credentials, apprenticeships, and AI literacy programs accessible to all Canadians, regardless of background or age. - Embed ethics and equity into AI education from the start, ensuring that future researchers and developers understand the societal impact of their work. Canada’s competitive edge can come not just from technical breakthroughs, but from cultivating a diverse, ethically aware, and practically skilled talent pool."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public survey intents add layers of detail that expand upon the expert recommendations by emphasizing quality-of-life factors and early educational initiatives, aspects that experts touched on less explicitly. For example, while expert reports tend to focus on high-level strategies such as reforming immigration policies and head‐hunting initiatives, public responses in intents like 'Domestic talent development and education' and 'Global talent mobility and international collaboration' highlight practical challenges including housing affordability, interdisciplinary training starting from primary education, and developing micro-credentials and lifelong learning programs. This richer detail on the broader social and infrastructural support needed for a vibrant AI talent ecosystem complements the expert focus on funding and institutional reforms.

Example Responses:

"1. Competitive Compensation and Benefits: Offer competitive salaries and benefits packages that reflect the demand for AI talent. 2. Strong Educational Pathways: Develop and enhance educational programs in AI at universities and colleges. 3. Scholarships and Grants: Provide scholarships, fellowships, and research grants for students and early-career researchers in AI. 4. Industry Partnerships: Foster partnerships between academic institutions and industry to create internship and co-op opportunities. 5. Mentorship Programs: Establish mentorship initiatives that connect students and early-career professionals with experienced mentors in the field. 6. Promoting a Diverse and Inclusive Environment: Create initiatives that promote diversity and inclusion within AI programs and workplaces. 7. Research and Development Opportunities: Support cutting-edge research initiatives that allow AI professionals to work on impactful projects. 8. Lifelong Learning and Professional Development:"

"Introducing AI in our educational system should start in secondary school with key harmonized standards for universities, and certification(standards) for the public and private workplace."

"Courses for students of all ages should be developed on machine learning as a priority, starting from a young age. Kids need to learn how it works, what it does, how to use it responsibly and what careers are available to them if they choose to pursue it. Ethical machine learning courses should be immediately developed for universities to start making talent here at home, with Grant programs available for anyone who has talent but doesn't come from money. These grants could also be offered to promising international students so we can start poaching talent early. As I mentioned before we should be greedily snapping up American researchers who are now at loose ends due to funding cuts, don't make them jump through 12 layers of hoops made of red tape. We might only have 3 years to take advantage of the situation."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

There are notable differences between the expert views and the public survey responses, particularly where public voices express significant skepticism and concerns over the pace and potential harms of AI development. While experts generally assume that rapidly enhancing AI research capacity is inherently beneficial if coupled with ethical safeguards, public respondents in the 'AI skepticism and anti-AI' intent raise issues about the environmental impact, potential job displacement, and even the ethical legitimacy of accelerating AI research without fully addressing social risks. This divergent perspective calls into question whether immediate expansion of AI capabilities is desirable, reflecting a broader concern that is less pronounced in the expert reports.

Example Responses:

"I am extremely skeptical about the weight that is being given to AI. Its flaws and costs do not seem to be accounted for in any of this work. Until we have a clearer mental and ethical picture of how AI fits within the rest of the work ongoing in Canada, I don't see attracting top AI talent as a priority. I also think that without a clear-eyed assessment of AI's flaws and costs as well as its potential uses, we will be unable to discern who is in fact a top AI researcher."

"I have no idea why attracting talent would be a priority in an endeavor that seeks to remove the need for "talent" from every industry. Please put zero effort into inviting 'experts' into this field."

"**** l’IA. Il n’y a pas d’avantages à une technologie qui est en train de consommer des montants inédits d’énergie, juste pour que les billionaires puisse faire d’autre argent qu’ils n’ont pas de besoin tout en continuant d’appauvrin les travailleurs canadiens. Est-ce vraiment la sorte de réputation que l’on veut avoir comme pays? Q’on s’en fiche de la planète et de nos citoyens, et qu’on préfère alimenter une machine qui continue à voler des resources de nos peuples? Non merci."

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and many public responses acknowledge that Canada’s long‐term competitiveness in AI depends on maintaining a strong research base that effectively bridges fundamental inquiry and practical applications. Experts emphasize the need to upgrade funding, facilitate research-to-market pathways, and balance academic excellence with commercial innovation, while several public responses similarly call for a balance between fundamental and applied research and increased support for academic investigations (for example, promoting rigor in academic research and acknowledging existing strengths in certain domains). This shared perspective reflects a consensus on the importance of sustaining quality research to nurture talent and leverage Canada’s AI strengths.

Example Other Responses:

"I believe there should be a balance between fundamental and applied research."

"Fund academic research in AI to explore new approaches since the current approaches are only showing marginal gains."

"La recherche fondamentale en IA, pas seulement dans le domaine de l'IA connexionniste, mais dans tous les domaines de l'IA, dont l'IA symbolique."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public responses add practical and sector-specific nuances that expand on expert recommendations. Some respondents highlight specific application areas such as dual-use and defence (e.g., for drones and cybersecurity), suggesting that targeted investments in these niches could further solidify Canada’s competitive edge. Others urge caution in focusing exclusively on generative AI, instead urging a broader investigation into alternative models and custom-purpose AI systems. These insights complement experts’ more general calls for talent retention and funding by introducing concrete, application‐oriented ideas and by questioning current market hype to ensure a more balanced research agenda.

Example Other Responses:

"AI for drones (both in dual use and defense), monitoring critical infrastructure and defense (C2 and communications) and lastly for cyber security, should be the key areas in which Canada devotes its resources. Collaboration with our FVEY's partners on AI for Command and Control (NGC2) and cyber defense would be where we would be able to meaningfully contribute to strengthening our own AI policy and implementation."

"The internet is so vast and navigating givernment websites and processes can be daunting and confusing. I think it is promising to have an AI tool that can help you navigate all that information through a Q&A format as that is more natural than constantly searching key words and phrases. Helping to sort info in an easy way."

"Do not focus solely on LLMs. They are never going to scale the way that we are being told. Look for other approaches, and consider custom-purpose AI systems rather than pursuing supposedly general purpose AI systems which don't do anything very well."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

A significant divergence arises in the public discourse where many respondents, unlike experts, voice strong opposition or scepticism towards further investments in AI research. While expert reports strongly advocate for strategies to attract, develop, and retain top AI talent to maintain global competitiveness, a number of public responses argue against the current emphasis on AI—some even calling for a rollback or cancellation of AI research entirely, citing concerns about wasteful spending, ethical risks, and potential societal harm. This counterview emphasizes a radical rethinking of priorities, with some calling for funds to be directed towards more traditional public services rather than continuing to chase the AI hype.

Example Other Responses:

"Don't develop AI. It's a waste of money, time and our environment. Once the bubble bursts, you'll be billions in debt with nothing to show for."

"Cancel all research into AI. It’s an abomination. Why are you asking for a “national spirit” of an idea and railroading all the questions like this?"

"the presence of humanity, a quality sorely lacking in this hellhole forcibly built on Indigenous peoples' stolen lands"

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar.

The analysis identifies areas of alignment, complementary insights, and divergent perspectives between expert recommendations and public consultation responses.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and public survey responses align in their perspectives and priorities
  • Complementary Insights: Aspects where expert reports and public responses offer different but complementary perspectives that enrich understanding
  • Divergent Perspectives: Areas where expert recommendations and public responses differ significantly in focus, priorities, or approach

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts submitted through the consultation process.

Public Survey: Responses from the public consultation survey, classified into intent categories using LLM-based classification.

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses for this pillar.

The "Other" category contains responses that didn't fit into the main intent categories, representing unique perspectives and edge cases that may offer valuable insights.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and "Other" responses align in perspectives not captured by main categories
  • Complementary Insights: Unique viewpoints from "Other" responses that complement expert recommendations
  • Divergent Perspectives: Novel approaches or concerns in "Other" responses that differ from expert recommendations

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts.

"Other" Category: Survey responses that fell outside standard intent categories, potentially representing emerging themes or unique perspectives not captured in the main taxonomy.

Adoption Across Industry & Governments

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and public survey responses emphasize the need for strong government leadership in catalyzing AI adoption in both industry and public services. Experts like Joelle Pineau and Diane Gutiw stress the importance of transparent procurement practices, public trust, and acting as a 'client zero' that can lead by example in deploying AI safely. Public responses under the 'Public sector & governance' intent similarly call for the government to take an active role, whether by modernizing digital services, enhancing transparency, or ensuring equitable access to AI-driven tools. This alignment underscores a shared belief that responsible government action is essential to drive broad-based AI adoption, build trust, and promote Canadian values.

Example Responses:

"Canada’s institutional strength gives it a major advantage in integrating AI across its public and private sectors. The country’s governance framework, regulatory reliability, and digital infrastructure make it easier than most nations to embed AI into daily operations—from public services to industry and research. But to truly capture this opportunity, Canadians must learn to use AI as an extension of their own intelligence, not as a replacement for it. The real potential lies in helping people understand how to harness AI to refine their thinking, process information critically, and apply insights across limitless fields. When citizens learn to leverage AI to amplify—not outsource—their expertise, productivity and creativity rise in tandem. Moreover, in a labor-intensive economy where efficiency challenges persist, AI adoption can alleviate the cost burden of routine or repetitive work, allowing human effort to focus on higher-order tasks. Canada’s future competitiveness depends on cultivating this human-AI synergy: strong institutions, informed citizens, and a workforce that uses technology as a tool for wisdom rather than substitution."

"The federal government needs to lead the way. It can start by analysing every single department, and role with AI and looking for ways to automate. Reduce headcount while improving service where possible and let the public know you're doing so. If people could get answers to questions using AI chatbots and AI powered knowledge bases 24/7 and if government service times for all departments that interface with the public were cut dramatically, meaning using AI to improve customer service became a priority, it would impact almost every Canadian positively."

"As the CEO of Milton Public Library, serving the Town of Milton I am responding to highlight the essential role of public libraries in Canada's AI strategy. Public libraries are trusted, democratic institutions, uniquely positioned to democratize AI literacy and ensure equitable AI adoption amongst all Canadians. We need to ensure all patrons understand AI and how to utilize the tools effectively. It is important that we bridge the digital divide and democratize access. Libraries are trusted institutions, that are committed to privacy protection, intellectual freedom, neutral spaces and are consistently ranked among most trusted institutions."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public survey responses add value to expert recommendations by expanding the discussion to include practical challenges and measurable outcomes. While expert reports often focus on policy reforms, infrastructure investments, and procurement strategies, public intents such as 'Adoption & Measurement' highlight the importance of establishing clear metrics for success, such as productivity gains and sector-specific benchmarks. Additionally, public responses emphasize the impact on everyday service delivery and the need for accessible, user-friendly AI solutions, thereby complementing expert insights with a more granular focus on the benefits and challenges experienced at the ground level in various sectors.

Example Responses:

"I think we’ll know Canada is truly engaging with AI when it goes beyond experiments and pilots and starts to show up in core workflows. Success should be measured by whether AI tools are integrated into how hospitals deliver care, how mid-sized businesses run their supply chains, and how governments provide services. The metrics I’d watch are adoption rates in high-value sectors, productivity improvements, and whether those gains are widely distributed across the economy. If AI becomes something only a handful of big firms leverage, we’ve missed the point."

"Success is measured by adoption depth: from pilot projects (experimentation) to enterprise-wide use (integration) to productivity and competitiveness gains (transformation). Indicators include AI-driven GDP growth, sector-specific benchmarks (e.g., reduced wait times in healthcare, yield gains in agriculture), SME adoption rates, talent retention, and global ranking in responsible AI research and commercialization."

"Use the TTHW metric: 'Time to Hello World'. The benefit of this metric is it is verifiable but also flexible, and aligned to real user adoption. In each sector, have industry associations set a series of 'baseline use cases' incorporating common business processes or tasks with related test and verification data sets. Ensure that AI/LLM tools are incorporated in the business processes or tasks. Next, perform monitored tests with sample users to see how quickly they can successfully accomplish each baseline use case to the verified standard. This is called 'getting to Hello World'. If the time it takes is 15 minutes or less, the test passes. If it hovers around 6 or 7 minutes, it's probably excellent adoption. You will have proven, in a verifiable industry-specific way, that motivated users are a few minutes away from performing their tasks, using AI. But if users are unable to get a TTHW of < 15 minutes, the industry association needs to figure out how to improve the results/adoption."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

A notable divergence between expert reports and public responses lies in the skepticism and caution expressed by portions of the public that are not as prominent in expert recommendations. While experts generally advocate for accelerated adoption through coordinated procurement reforms and industrial policies, several public respondents in intents such as 'Skepticism and Opposition to AI Adoption' voice strong concerns over potential job losses, ethical risks, and even call for a moratorium on AI implementation. This contrast highlights a gap in priorities: experts focus on leveraging AI for economic and operational gains, whereas segments of the public are more apprehensive about the societal and employment disruptions that rapid AI integration might cause.

Example Responses:

"AI adoption is not a net good, it's essentially a scam being pushed on Canadians by people who are over-leveraged in tech. There is no value to Canadians from widespread adoption of AI."

"AI is a huge bubble, and the government should not take steps to accelerate uptake of AI. AI is a funny little tool to use for personal use, but has very limited needs-based usages for the average Canadian. While it can be used in positive ways (ie making things more accessible for those living with disabilities), any steps the government takes to encourage its uptake at the enterprise level will almost exclusively be used to drive unemployment (via automation) to the benefit of shareholders and detriment of Canadians. This is not something the country needs more of. If AI starts replacing working people in the economy, they should be taxed like a working person in the economy. The copyright act should also be updated to specifically speak to IP rights in AI systems. An AI should not be available for commercial purchase unless it has been certified by a regulatory body that the AI itself, and 100% of its training data was acquired by either license, or was already in the public domain. In other words, no for-profit entity operating in Canada should be able to sell access to a system that was built using stolen intellectual property."

"AI is a dead-end technology at best, and the world's greatest technology hoax at worst. Generative models and their creators have repeatedly shown that they have no regard for the rules of law, copyright, ethics, creativity, or the environment. AI researchers have mostly all agreed that the current approach to large language models has reached its limit. Without a significant lateral breakthrough, this technology will not improve beyond confidently lying whenever asked a question. Banks and economists worldwide are quickly coming to the realization that the AI industry as a whole is a bubble. It has not delivered on any of its promises, and only grows as a consequence of circular investment between the leading AI companies. The US especially has heavily bet on AI, with 40% of their GDP being tied up in AI companies who, so far, have shown no benefit to society and generated no return on investment. When the bubble bursts, Canada should be economically self-sufficient to weather that storm, not tie us further to the sinking ship."

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and several public responses emphasize the importance of fostering domestic AI innovation and the need for government leadership in reforming procurement practices to support Canadian solutions. Experts repeatedly call for initiatives such as 'Buy Canadian First' mandates and updated government procurement pathways (e.g., Expert Reports 2, 12 and 21), while public responses similarly stress the need to fund local startups and build a competitive domestic base (e.g., response 2's call to fund AI startups and response 84’s focus on empowering innovation-driven SMEs). These commonalities suggest an agreement that boosting homegrown AI capacity and ensuring governmental support are critical to accelerating AI adoption across both industry and the public sector.

Example Other Responses:

"Fund AI startups. You see how US helps them and they become billion dollar companies. Some have left Canada for this reason."

"The greatest potential for impactful AI adoption in Canada lies in sectors where innovation driven SMEs can thrive and compete globally. These include software development, entertainment (film, television, and gaming), creative industries, digital media, clean technology, biotechnology, and professional services. These sectors naturally foster entrepreneurial ecosystems, have lower barriers to entry, and reward rapid innovation over established market power, making them ideal for AI enabled transformation and growth."

"Focusing on innovation and understanding the KNOWLEDGE ECONOMY more broadly. It is not just about AI. It's about innovation and knowledge transference in a competive industry. In order for Canada to be competitive, we actually have to foster competition here and move away from the being a Monopoly or Oligopoly driven economy. Be attractive to companies by being willing to invest money and help them sustain a base in Canada. Take the subsidies out of fossil fuels and the energy sector and invest in knowledge, move away from being a resource-focused nation only and focus on the next sector. Extraction is a dying dinosaur industry."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Several public responses offer additional perspectives that expand on expert recommendations by highlighting nuanced, sector-specific opportunities and barriers not fully detailed in the expert reports. For instance, public response 3 underscores the transformative potential of AI in sectors like algorithmic trading—a fast-paced market that could generate unprecedented wealth—while response 64 proposes a shift in focus towards exporting AI services to overcome the limitations of a small domestic market. Additionally, response 114 brings attention to the need for education and public literacy on AI, thereby complementing the experts’ emphasis on procurement and regulatory reforms with a call to improve foundational public understanding and skills.

Example Other Responses:

"One of the greatest uses for Ai is going to be algorithmic trading. This enables people to trade assets faster then any human could by doing prediction models and scraping social media sites. The Ai models look at the data and make trades based on the best possible outcome. This industry is going to create more wealth then any before it due to the speed Ai can create profit. Canada should attract talent in house to create solutions for Canadians to trade assets at fractions of a second like others doing high frequency trading internationally."

"I think we should think less about adoption in Canada, and more about exporting AI services. The market in Canada is small by definition."

"Knowledge is a key barrier. I think it needs be incorporated into the educational system from K-University. Also offer free educational programs for adults."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

While expert reports predominantly focus on government-led initiatives, procurement reforms, and structured pilot deployments as pathways for broad AI adoption, some public responses diverge by questioning the framing of the issue or by emphasizing different priorities. For example, response 12 dismisses the survey’s approach as reflecting only the interests of its respondents rather than addressing systemic issues, and response 90 challenges the definition and scope of 'AI' itself as used in the survey. Furthermore, response 17 places special emphasis on creative industries like music creation, which contrasts with the experts’ focus on sectors such as healthcare, defense, and IT infrastructure. These divergent perspectives highlight skepticism regarding the survey's framing and a desire to consider a wider array of sectors and underlying assumptions.

Example Other Responses:

"What a silly question. Of course your responses are going to reflect the inerests of the people who respond. What are you going to do with that??? Embrad Cda's AI strategy around the respopnses? Who thought of these questiuons????"

"Creative Industries, particularly music creation."

"Depends on what this survey means when it says "AI". That term and this question are too broad. It depends on the sector, their painpoints, their opportunities for growth. Who needs "it" and what is "it" should be up to the sector and then with that information a decision can be made."

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar.

The analysis identifies areas of alignment, complementary insights, and divergent perspectives between expert recommendations and public consultation responses.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and public survey responses align in their perspectives and priorities
  • Complementary Insights: Aspects where expert reports and public responses offer different but complementary perspectives that enrich understanding
  • Divergent Perspectives: Areas where expert recommendations and public responses differ significantly in focus, priorities, or approach

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts submitted through the consultation process.

Public Survey: Responses from the public consultation survey, classified into intent categories using LLM-based classification.

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses for this pillar.

The "Other" category contains responses that didn't fit into the main intent categories, representing unique perspectives and edge cases that may offer valuable insights.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and "Other" responses align in perspectives not captured by main categories
  • Complementary Insights: Unique viewpoints from "Other" responses that complement expert recommendations
  • Divergent Perspectives: Novel approaches or concerns in "Other" responses that differ from expert recommendations

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts.

"Other" Category: Survey responses that fell outside standard intent categories, potentially representing emerging themes or unique perspectives not captured in the main taxonomy.

Commercialization of AI

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and public survey responses recognize the critical need to bridge the gap between AI research and its commercialization, emphasizing the importance of domestic growth, retention of intellectual property, and economic sovereignty. For instance, multiple expert reports call for enhanced tax incentives, national champions, and modernized SR&ED policies to ensure Canadian companies scale domestically and globally, while public respondents in the 'Public Funding, Capital and Domestic Growth' and 'Sovereignty, IP and Data Retention' intents similarly stress the need to keep funding, IP, and job creation onshore through measures such as government procurement and IP retention strategies.

Example Responses:

"Canada must strengthen its IP retention strategies by providing funding incentives tied to domestic ownership and use of Canadian-made models and datasets. A national AI IP registry, similar to a patent office for algorithms and fine-tuned models, could help safeguard innovations. Foreign investment should be encouraged under frameworks that preserve Canadian board control and IP licensing rights. Strategic use of the Sovereign AI Compute Strategy can ensure Canadian companies have competitive infrastructure without depending on foreign cloud monopolies. Sovereignty should also include data residency and model transparency safeguards for high-risk AI applications."

"I think Canada needs to create conditions where AI companies can scale here without immediately selling out to foreign buyers. That means access to domestic growth capital, policies that help protect Canadian IP, and safeguards so we don’t hollow out our most promising firms. Foreign investment should still play a role, but I think we need clear structures where ownership and core intellectual property remain anchored in Canada. Otherwise, we’ll end up being the R&D lab for someone else’s economy."

"Pour bâtir des entreprises d’IA concurrentielles tout en préservant la souveraineté économique, le Canada doit reconnaître la culture comme pilier de sa stratégie industrielle. Le secteur culturel développe des corpus de données, outils et usages originaux — véritables actifs immatériels nationaux — qui assurent l’ancrage local de la propriété intellectuelle. L’accès à une infrastructure de calcul souveraine pour les créateurs, chercheurs et OBNL culturels permettrait de produire des modèles reflétant la diversité linguistique et culturelle canadienne, un avantage compétitif mondial. Investir dans des “communs numériques” culturels, gouvernés par les pairs et hébergés au Canada, favorise l’indépendance face aux géants du cloud et stimule l’innovation responsable. C’est une stratégie de croissance qui conjugue compétitivité économique et souveraineté culturelle."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public survey inputs provide additional operational details that complement the broader policy frameworks outlined in expert reports. Whereas experts focus on high-level strategies like establishing research‐to‐commercialization pipelines and national champions, public responses expand on these ideas by advocating for structured procurement processes, challenge-based funding, and clearer regulatory pathways. For example, the 'Demand-driven, sector-focused translational bridge (government as anchor customer)' intent details specific mechanisms such as sector-specific labs and streamlined contracting, thus enriching the expert proposals with actionable, market-driven initiatives.

Example Responses:

"12. Canada can bridge the AI research-commercialization gap through a mission-driven, strategically-intervening model. 1. Government as a Strategic Connector & Lead Customer: Shift from generic grants to "Challenge-Based" Funding. Government, with industry, should define specific, strategic problems in life sciences, energy, and defence (e.g., "Reduce Grid Emissions by 20% with AI"). Fund consortia of academics and companies to solve them, ensuring research is demand-driven. Act as a first customer for proven Canadian AI solutions through streamlined procurement, de-risking adoption and providing a crucial reference case. 2. Forge Deeper, Structured Partnerships: Mandate and fund "Industry Sabbaticals" for academics within strategic sectors and "Applied Scientist" roles for PhDs within Canadian companies. This builds lasting networks and translates knowledge directly. Create Sector-Specific AI Labs as joint ventures between national AI institutes and major industry players (e.g., a "Canadian AI for Cleantech Lab" with energy companies), co-locating teams on shared objectives. 3. Protect Sovereign IP with "Gold Share" Provisions: Attach clear IP conditions to major public grants. Recipients must retain core IP in Canada, with the government holding a non-exclusive license or a "golden share" for critical technologies. This prevents the fire-sale of strategic assets developed with public funds. This approach moves beyond simple networking to actively structuring the ecosystem around national priorities, ensuring commercialization meets strategic business needs and retains Canadian value."

"20. Canada can better connect AI research with commercialization by building structured pathways from lab to market. This starts with government-backed innovation hubs that co-locate researchers, start-ups, and industry partners, supported by shared data resources and advanced computing infrastructure. Prioritize sectors like life sciences, energy, and defence for targeted commercialization programs, including matching funds and procurement incentives. Clear IP frameworks that protect Canadian-developed innovations while enabling global partnerships are essential. Finally, embed commercialization metrics into research funding to ensure ideas move beyond pilots to scalable, market-ready solutions."

"11. I suspect some of the most promising use cases that fit Canada's comparative advantage are in heavily regulated industries so by consequence, some of the most important things the government Canada do are demonstrate the right course of action as a purchaser and adopter of AI itself. By immediate consequence, more procurement dollars needs to be ringfenced for Canadian SMEs and those ringfenced funds need to be allocated quickly. PSPC contracting needs to be banging out contracts to SMEs with a 30 day service standard or departments need to be able to contract out the due dilligence function it performs to more responsive and rapid firms who also can apply the supply manual. This is the speed of relevance for innocative AI companies. If the Government of Canada cannot adhere to contracting standards and timelines common in private industry then the GC cannot be a buyer/user of AI and we may as well save everyone a lot of time and just make a blanket tax credit giveaway like SRED. That being said, there is no fundamental reason why, for instance, the ISC program focused on innovative small businesses cannot award all contracts to eligable firms within 30 days of an application instead of the 8-18 months which is the current standard. Proposal evaluation and contractinf due dillogence combined is like 2 or 3 business days of work, but PSPC will milk this to fund almost a year of idleness, absenteeism and mismanagement. In short, if the Government of Canada wants to be a serious participant it needs to match the operating expections of AI companies (namelg speed) and recognize that its competitive advantage as a partner is not so much money (lots of people have money) but its special ability (as a government) to make thing legal and signal legal approval (and investibility) for new AI ventures, particularly in highly regulates areas that have been starved of productivity improvements."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

A noticeable divergence exists between expert views and certain public survey responses regarding the risks of AI commercialization. While experts largely emphasize growth, competitive advantage, and economic benefits, some public respondents express significant concerns over AI’s societal, environmental, and ethical impacts. Public intents like 'Skepticism, risk, and anti-AI stance' highlight fears about IP theft, environmental degradation, and overall negative social consequences of rapid commercialization—issues that are either minimized or absent in the expert reports focused on commercialization strategies.

Example Responses:

"I am against AI in principle and in practice. "AI" usage has been shown to affect the way people use their brain. https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ Data centers use an inordinate amount of energy and water and other necessary natural resources. https://andthewest.stanford.edu/2025/thirsty-for-power-and-water-ai-crunching-data-centers-sprout-across-the-west/ I also object vehemently the fact that training "AI" requires the theft of text, visual, and audio art, as well as people's identity and personhood. "AI" is currently used for observation and extraction of personal information, encroaching in the basic right to individual privacy. I cannot in good conscience support anything related to the current iteration of "AI.""

"Generative AI is not real AI. It does not think, it does not understand, and it has no concept of right and wrong. All it does is process real people's work and regurgitate inferior interpretations of it. This technology should be banned from all creative processes, as it is nothing more than a giant plagiarism machine."

"You realize this is all ****, right? The people pushing this **** on us are looking to make a quick buck off stolen work while poisoning marginalized communities with their disgusting data centres so we can fill the Internet with useless slop and get the wrong answers to questions like "what's two plus two?" and "what was George Washington's last name?" We did not need this garbage three years ago and now people are experiencing psychosis from talking to machines. This is nuts. What are we doing?"

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses

Common Ground
View examples

Both experts and a segment of public respondents agree that Canada needs to strengthen the link between AI research and its domestic commercialization in order to safeguard and boost national economic sovereignty. Expert reports call for measures such as integrated funding schemes, improved tax incentives, and even the creation of national champions to ensure Canadian AI innovations are scaled and retained domestically. Similarly, some public responses stress the importance of supporting local champions and keeping economic benefits within Canada, arguing that government support should ensure that the commercial benefits of AI contribute to solving local issues and protecting national interests.

Example Other Responses:

"USE IT TO FIX OUR OWN FINANCIAL STRUGGLES. VANCOUVER HOUSING MARKET. STOP LETTING FOREIGN BUYERS UP THE MARKET PRICES. CANADIANS WANT A HOME. CANADIANS WANT TO LIVE AND SURVIVE."

"Harley Finkelstein of Shopify has great ideas on this that I would endorse, link to a podcast interview: <URL> Shopify should be a case study and advisor on how to assure more successful organizations in Canada."

"I am not sure why this should be a focus. Canadian businesses are best placed to decide when and how to adopt a new technology."

Complementary Insights
View examples

While experts largely focus on the design of policies to improve commercialization—such as reforming SR&ED, establishing proof-of-concept funds, and reinforcing IP frameworks—several public responses add complementary perspectives by highlighting broader socio-economic and environmental dimensions. Some respondents call for using the commercialization process to address critical societal issues such as sustainable housing, universal basic income, and environmental impacts of data centers. This adds a nuance that goes beyond pure economic competitiveness, suggesting that commercialization efforts should also be evaluated on their broader benefits to Canadian society.

Example Other Responses:

"Basic income program"

"Keep Canada sustainable avoiding the environmental impact of data centres and their infinite power demand."

"Break down current monopolies and stop letting large companies buy out the smaller ones, causing innovation to stagnate due to a lack of need to improve services Raise taxes on large corporations"

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

There are notable differences in emphasis between expert reports and many public responses. Experts tend to focus on creating a favorable business environment through targeted policy and financial incentives to help scale Canadian AI globally, treating commercialization as a strategic lever for economic growth. In contrast, some public comments question the very premise of aggressively pursuing commercialization, with critics asking why AI needs to be commercialized at all or arguing that governmental intervention may unduly prioritize corporate profit over social well‐being. This divergence reflects a broader debate over whether the focus should be on market optimization or on safeguarding community and environmental interests.

Example Other Responses:

"I don’t know."

"Pourquoi favoriser la commercialisation de l'IA?"

"I think 'unlocking' AI sounds wrong. The term 'supporting' sounds more appropriate, provided that Canadians do not want AI "unleased" or "unlocked" or "unrestrained" - these are words that favour corporations that prioritize profits above human safety and privacy. I think with that said, the first step would be using the adequate words to not give the wrong impressions to any parties involved in AI commercialization, including the end-users or consumers of such products and services."

  • Divergent Perspectives: Areas where expert recommendations and public responses differ significantly in focus, priorities, or approach

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses for this pillar.

  • Complementary Insights: Unique viewpoints from "Other" responses that complement expert recommendations
  • Divergent Perspectives: Novel approaches or concerns in "Other" responses that differ from expert recommendations
