"Other" Category: Survey responses that fell outside standard intent categories, potentially representing emerging themes or unique perspectives not captured in the main taxonomy.

Scaling Champions & Investment

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and public survey responses emphasize the importance of building and scaling domestic AI champions as a key strategic priority. Experts, for instance, propose mechanisms like a Canadian Prosperity Fund, sovereign infrastructure investments, and streamlined procurement to support homegrown firms, while public respondents similarly call for a coherent national policy with staged supports, targeted funding, and government acting as a lead customer (e.g., transforming early pilots into scalable, commercially viable products). There is mutual recognition of the necessity to anchor innovations in Canada – experts stress sustained domestic investment and protecting core IP, and public voices (such as those in the 'AI Champions Policy & Growth Supports' intent) echo the need for continuous, stage-specific support and mentorship to grow truly competitive national champions.

Example Responses:

"I think Canada needs to deliberately grow a handful of AI companies into true industrial champions, not just a long tail of small startups. The supports that matter are mentorship, consistent federal program handoffs so firms don’t get stuck between funding stages, and tailored tools for early-, mid-, and late-stage growth. If we want companies to “own the podium,” we need to back them through the messy middle stage when scaling is hardest, not just seed and research phases."

"Canada can build stronger AI champions by addressing barriers at every growth stage. Early-stage startups need accessible seed funding, incubators, and mentorship networks linking founders with experienced scale-up leaders. Mid-stage firms require scale-up capital (BDC, pension funds, export financing) and help navigating global markets, alongside AI-First procurement to secure anchor domestic customers. Late-stage firms need patient capital, tailored trade support, and protections."

"Scaling is a red herring. What we need instead is a pluralistic network of smaller, decentralized projects/systems/R&D/solutions. It's the 21st century. 'Scaling' is the solution from the 20th century, which produces almost nothing but toxic results anymore."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public responses add complementary dimensions that expand on the expert recommendations by emphasizing broader societal and environmental considerations alongside scaling efforts. Whereas experts predominantly focus on mechanisms for financial and structural support (such as capital funds, procurement programs, and sovereign compute), public survey respondents also stress the significance of workforce development, inclusive innovation, and environmental sustainability. For example, responses such as those in the 'Workforce and social impact considerations in AI scaling' intent introduce the idea that scaling strategies should also include provisions for community impact, upskilling, and transitioning affected workers, thereby enriching the overall policy conversation with a more holistic view.

Example Responses:

"To accelerate sustainable scaling of AI ventures, Canada must align business incentives with community impact and workforce readiness. Beyond traditional R&D and export incentives, programs should include funding for AI solutions in community services—such as employment, settlement, health, and social supports—where innovation directly benefits people. Incentives could reward collaborations between AI ventures, employers, and community-based organizations that advance inclusion and accessibility. Tax credits, innovation vouchers, and procurement pilots should prioritize ventures that integrate skills training and workforce development for newcomers, women, and underrepresented groups. Embedding social impact criteria into scaling programs ensures that Canada grows globally competitive AI companies while also strengthening its social and economic fabric."

"Give training money to companies that invest in AI so that they can train employees that are currently doing jobs that will be done by AI. This way they can continue to employ their current workforce but skill them up to do tasks that cannot be done by AI."

"Canada needs to work with unions to have a real plan for the labour fallout. Canada needs to be people first and not AI first. I am a big proponent of AI use but chasing after this without thinking about the people that will be displaced will cause political instability. There needs to be a plan as to what will happen to workers. A real plan with measurable outcomes that needs to be enforced, not neoliberal lip service like we have seen in the past."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

A key divergence is observed where some public respondents oppose or are highly skeptical of scaling AI at all, calling for stricter regulation or even bans, in contrast to the expert focus on aggressive scaling and market capture. While experts concentrate on fostering competitive AI champions and leveraging government procurement to drive growth, several public intents like 'Skepticism and calls to regulate/ban AI' underline concerns regarding ethical risks, environmental impacts, and potential overinvestment in uncertain technologies. These voices question the fundamental premise of rapid commercial scaling and push for a more cautious, regulated approach that better safeguards societal interests.

Example Responses:

"Enact legislation to prevent AI from using any material without consent. Do not allow companies to replace people’s jobs with AI. Do not allow AI companies to pollute clean water and drain the power grid. People will not trust AI until they have reason to."

"Do not incentivize commercialization of generative ai. Do not fund it. Do not support it. Do not spend my taxpayer dollars on it. Create and enforce ethics and regulations around ai development and use. Update them regularly to avoid loopholing. Restrict generative AI use and prevent the construction of data centers for generative AI in Canada."

"Do research against AI. Make laws against AI; Create plagiarism laws against AI; Prevent AI scraping information; Make technology that is able to detect AI imaging, video, and audio; Protect people’s rights and privacy; Invest in proper research against climate change instead."

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and a subset of public responses converge on the importance of creating a more supportive environment for domestic AI champions. Experts stress designing structural and financial incentives to help scale AI companies—through measures like dedicated growth funds, streamlined procurement, and infrastructure investments—while some public responses also call attention to the need for building strong, competitive industrial players and regional AI hubs. For example, one public comment explicitly asks for a focus on producing "more and stronger industrial champions," aligning with expert recommendations to nurture homegrown leaders and attract investment.

Example Other Responses:

"How about asking this question about getting more and stronger industrial champions?"

"More hubs for AI development"

"Find the few industries that actually have a use for AI at scale, and focus your efforts on those. Do not try to force large-scale AI into businesses where it would not be of use, or where the uses could be handled just as effectively by small-scale adoption."

Complementary Insights
View examples

A number of public responses broaden the debate by bringing in additional societal and economic concerns that go beyond the narrow tech‐policy focus of the expert reports. While experts concentrate on reforming funding mechanisms and procurement processes, some public respondents emphasize a wider need for improvements in quality of life, fundamental research, and social infrastructure. These perspectives suggest that any strategy for scaling AI champions should also account for broader issues such as education, affordable living, and workplace conditions in order to ensure that the nation’s AI growth translates into general societal benefits.

Example Other Responses:

"Be a nice place to live with free healthcare, lower cost of living, and a fully funded Canada post."

"More fundamental research. If we want to make machine that think, we first need to understand how humans think. If we want to use AI/machines for diagnosis, we first first understand how diseases work, especially inside people who are not male, white, and cisgender. If we want to use AI/machines to find exoplanets, black holes, gravastars, neutrinos, exotic matter, or dark matter/dark energy, we need a deeper understanding of how physic works to understand the possibilities of what the Universe can show us. If we want to grow food better and faster with AI/machines, we need to understand how plants interact with the soil, the microorganisms in the soil, fungi, other plants, water, minerals, weather, how to modify plants (genetically or otherwise) for more yield, more pest resistance, more disease resistance, more macronutriments (golden rice, anyone?)."

"Investissez plutôt dans la santé, l’éducation, les programmes sociaux, l’écologie que vous avez oubliée, et le logement."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

Several public responses sharply question the underlying premise of investing heavily to scale new AI champions, highlighting skepticism about both the desirability and sustainability of such a strategy. While experts advocate for proactive measures like tax reforms and capital funds to prevent premature acquisitions and spur growth, some respondents dismiss or criticize these ideas—arguing that efforts to force the creation of industrial champions may distract from supporting already viable, real-world businesses or could lead to unsustainable bubbles. This divergence illustrates a fundamental disagreement about whether policy should focus on building new champions or trust market forces to select winners naturally.

Example Other Responses:

"We need to support REAL businesses and industries in Canada. Industries that provide actual services to people. "accelerate sustainable scaling of AI ventures" what the hell are you talking about??"

"Why? If it’s useful business will adopt. If it’s not they won’t."

"Smaller business opportunities"

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar.

The analysis identifies areas of alignment, complementary insights, and divergent perspectives between expert recommendations and public consultation responses.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and public survey responses align in their perspectives and priorities
  • Complementary Insights: Aspects where expert reports and public responses offer different but complementary perspectives that enrich understanding
  • Divergent Perspectives: Areas where expert recommendations and public responses differ significantly in focus, priorities, or approach

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses for this pillar.

The "Other" category contains responses that didn't fit into the main intent categories, representing unique perspectives and edge cases that may offer valuable insights.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and "Other" responses align in perspectives not captured by main categories
  • Complementary Insights: Unique viewpoints from "Other" responses that complement expert recommendations
  • Divergent Perspectives: Novel approaches or concerns in "Other" responses that differ from expert recommendations

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts.

"Other" Category: Survey responses that fell outside standard intent categories, potentially representing emerging themes or unique perspectives not captured in the main taxonomy.

Safe AI Systems & Public Trust

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and public survey responses converge on the need for strong regulatory frameworks, transparency, and accountability to build safe and trustworthy AI systems. Experts such as Joelle Pineau, Alex LaPlante, and Dan Debow emphasize the importance of evidence‐based risk measurement, transparency through standardized labels, and clear accountability mechanisms. Similarly, public survey intents like 'Regulation, Safety, and Governance' and 'Risk-based governance, oversight, and certification for trustworthy AI' call for mandatory regulations, independent oversight, and detailed risk assessments to ensure that AI applications are safe and benefit the public. This shared emphasis on establishing clear, risk-based regulatory standards and transparent practices is a key area of alignment between the two groups.

Example Responses:

"Canada can build public confidence in AI by pairing clear public-sector leadership with transparency and visible public benefit. The federal government should lead by example: advance a proportionate, risk-based law for high-impact AI (alongside the Treasury Board’s Directive on Automated Decision-Making), enforce transparency, fairness and accountability in federal uses, and resource independent oversight. In parallel, deliver the $2B Sovereign AI Compute Strategy so sensitive workloads can run on Canadian-controlled infrastructure. Trust must also be designed into products and services. Organizations should plainly disclose when AI is used, what risks exist, and why a system reached a result; high-impact systems must be explainable. People need practical remedies—clear notices, easy escalation to human review, and avenues to contest decisions—so harms and bias can be addressed quickly. Privacy-by-design, safety testing and post-deployment monitoring should be routine, with results summarized in accessible, bilingual reports. Finally, confidence grows when Canadians see AI improving daily life under strict safeguards."

"Public trust in AI comes from transparency, accountability, and showing real benefits. People lose confidence when they see hype, black box tools, or no clear safeguards. Canada should require companies to be clear about how AI is used, protect personal data, and set practical ethical standards that companies can actually follow. At the same time, we need to show Canadians the upside: AI reducing wait times in health care, making government more efficient, or helping small businesses grow."

"Ironically enough, I would employ a dedicated Governance AI to understand and promulgate safety regulations for AI in Canada with 'humans in the loop' again similar to the emergence of the Minds in Iain M. Banks Culture series. That model can be adopted by Canada, and our founding ethos will far exceed that achieved by the American experiment. One concern is Canadian timidity. Channel our hockey-playing lumberjack bush-pilot Vimy Ridge Crazy Canuck essence to succeed, where America failed."

Complementary Insights
View examples

While expert reports tend to focus on technical standards, risk measurement, and balanced, innovation-friendly regulation, public survey responses add further depth by stressing the importance of widespread AI literacy and the practical demonstration of benefits. Public responses emphasize initiatives such as comprehensive education campaigns, accessible disclosures, and citizen-facing dashboards – as seen in the 'Public Literacy, Transparency, and Education' and 'Public education and AI literacy' intents – to empower citizens and demystify AI. These complementary insights broaden the focus from technical and regulatory aspects to include public understanding and active engagement, thereby reinforcing the notion that trust is built not just through safety protocols, but also through transparent communication and inclusive public participation.

Example Responses:

"create a public information campaign on good and bad kinds of AI, risks, etc."

"First of all we need to change the language we use when talking about the different products currently under the AI bubble. Due to science fiction the public understands AI as an autonomous machine person. Then OpenAI comes along and co-opts the term for its chatbot and suddenly everyone thinks ChatGPT is going to evolve into Jarvis. We need to put a language framework into effect so companies can't just lie about their products capabilities for promotional reasons."

"Education technology to continuously empower Canadians and help them navigate the rapid changes that AI will introduce. Such technologies would benefit the entire world."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

There is a clear divergence in tone and priorities between some public survey responses and expert reports. While experts largely advocate for measured, balanced approaches to regulation that protect public interests without stifling innovation, certain public responses express a more radical stance. For example, the 'Anti-AI / Opposition to AI' and 'Ban/Reject AI' intents illustrate a significant level of skepticism and even outright opposition to AI deployment, driven by fears of privacy violations, environmental degradation, and loss of control. These public concerns, which sometimes call for severe restrictions or outright bans on AI, contrast with expert recommendations that typically stress proportionate, evidence‐driven measures and technological stewardship rather than extreme curtailment.

Example Responses:

"The risks of generative ai are too great both in regards to personal rights and in terms of environmental damage. It should not be invested in or supported. Any ai development must be constrained by broadly, evenly, and heavily enforced ethics regulations and overseen by people with enough funding to monitor and enforce the regulations. Thx industry must not be permitted to regulate itself. Create and enforce ethics and regulations around ai development and use. Update them regularly to avoid loopholing. Restrict generative AI use and prevent the construction of data centers for generative AI in Canada."

"This isn't going to happen. These technologies are widely thought to be invasive, unethical and highly annoying when embedded in software with no way to deactivate. If used to make policy or bureaucratic decisions, they would be a disaster. The Canadian taxpayer deserves to have these decisions made by real humans, not hallucinating AI."

"Stop using AI for warfare. Stop appropriating stolen Indigenous land to erect more data centres. Stop."

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses

Common Ground
View examples

Both experts and a subset of the public responses acknowledge that achieving safe and trustworthy AI systems is a critical issue that cannot be ignored. Experts consistently propose the need for transparency, robust data governance, ethical guidelines, and public engagement to foster trust (for instance, recommendations for independent audits, standardized labels, and clear reporting protocols appear in multiple expert reports). Similarly, some public respondents stress that trust must be earned rather than imposed and recognize the importance of involving Canadians in the development process as well as establishing accountability measures. Themes such as national capacity building and inclusion of diverse voices (for example, the call for inclusion of marginalized groups) are shared perspectives that underline a mutual concern about the current framework for AI safety and public trust.

Example Other Responses:

"Get Canadians to start developing and training. Stop subsidizing foreigners to take our jobs and dreams. You build capacity by training Canadians, not diploma mills filled with foreigners who are subsidized up the ying yang with LMIAs and other such programs. There is no opportunity for education and literacy strategies because most of that goes to diploma mills and foreigners. If you want support these things as non-profits or small businesses/communities you are out of luck."

"Inclusion of marginalized groups: persons with disabilities, children and families, language minorities, immigrants and newcomers in CO-design, planning and implementation of solutions at all stages"

"Build AI infrastructure and research and attract AI investment and companies"

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public responses provide additional nuance to expert recommendations by emphasizing the need for a distinct national capacity and talent strategy to support safe AI development. Several respondents uniquely call for measures that extend beyond prescriptive regulatory frameworks, such as prioritizing domestic expertise (e.g. awarding permanent residency to AI researchers), bolstering university-led initiatives, and ensuring that economic competitiveness is directly linked to local innovation. These insights add an economic and capacity‐building dimension to the technical and governance-focused recommendations advanced by experts, highlighting potential policy actions that are less visible in the expert reports.

Example Other Responses:

"Award permanent residency to AI researchers."

"Universities can lead. They do need funding, and they do need to compete."

"Just worry about the money. We're Capitalist."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

A significant divergence can be observed in the underlying assumptions about the inherent trustworthiness and viability of AI. While experts generally assume that with proper safeguards and transparent regulation AI systems can be made safe and trustworthy, many public responses are deeply skeptical—some even arguing that trustworthy and responsibly deployed AI are impossible by nature. Several respondents dismiss the very notion of government or industry being able to 'build trust' in AI through regulatory frameworks, instead characterizing AI as fundamentally untrustworthy and a potential threat to societal values. This disconnect underscores a rift between a future‐oriented, structured approach to AI governance proposed by experts and a public sentiment marked by cynicism regarding the feasibility and ethical implications of such initiatives.

Example Other Responses:

"There are no trustworthy or responsibly deployed AI products. Such a thing is impossible by the very nature of the product."

"Impossible, not with current technology."

"AI products are by design irresponsible and untrustworthy."

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar.

The analysis identifies areas of alignment, complementary insights, and divergent perspectives between expert recommendations and public consultation responses.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and public survey responses align in their perspectives and priorities
  • Complementary Insights: Aspects where expert reports and public responses offer different but complementary perspectives that enrich understanding
  • Divergent Perspectives: Areas where expert recommendations and public responses differ significantly in focus, priorities, or approach

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts submitted through the consultation process.

Public Survey: Responses from the public consultation survey, classified into intent categories using LLM-based classification.

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses for this pillar.

The "Other" category contains responses that didn't fit into the main intent categories, representing unique perspectives and edge cases that may offer valuable insights.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and "Other" responses align in perspectives not captured by main categories
  • Complementary Insights: Unique viewpoints from "Other" responses that complement expert recommendations
  • Divergent Perspectives: Novel approaches or concerns in "Other" responses that differ from expert recommendations

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts.

"Other" Category: Survey responses that fell outside standard intent categories, potentially representing emerging themes or unique perspectives not captured in the main taxonomy.

Education & Skills

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories

Common Ground
View examples

Both experts and public survey respondents emphasize the need to boost AI literacy and skills at every level of society. Several expert reports (for example, Alex LaPlante’s recommendation for a national K–12 AI education framework and Michael Serbinis’s call for expanding skills development from K–12 to mid‐career upskilling) align with public calls focused on creating robust AI literacy programs. Public respondents under intents like 'AI Skills & Workforce Readiness' and 'Education system integration (K-12, postsecondary, teacher training)' reiterate the necessity of integrated, lifelong education and practical training programs to prepare Canadians for the digital economy. This shared perspective on embedding AI-focused curricula across formal education and workplace training underscores a mutual recognition of education as the foundation for both workforce competitiveness and informed citizenship.

Example Responses:

"I think Canada needs two layers of skills: broad digital fluency for everyone (data literacy, promptcraft, basic automation, privacy/security hygiene) and deeper stacks for AI-focused careers (ML engineering, data engineering, model evaluation/safety, productization). The fastest way to build both is to fund short, stackable credentials tied to real employer demand, embed AI modules across college and trade programs (not just CS), and co-op more aggressively so learners ship in production during"

"A modern digital economy needs AI, data, coding, cybersecurity, and digital literacy, paired with human skills like problem-solving, ethics, and creativity. Canada should expand STEM and AI education, fund reskilling programs, and embed digital training across colleges, trades, and workplaces. Partnerships between academia, industry, and government can align skills with demand, while immigration and talent incentives fill urgent gaps and keep expertise rooted in Canada."

"The most important skill for a modern digital economy isn’t coding—it’s data stewardship: the ability to publish, verify, and govern structured information. AI is reshaping every sector, but the real divide won’t be between those who build AI and those who use it—it will be between those who can shape the knowledge layer AI depends on and those who can’t. Core skills: - Metadata literacy: describing information in ways machines can process—as basic as clear writing, not coding. - Data governance: verifying sources, maintaining provenance, correcting errors. - Verification and audit: checking AI outputs against authoritative data. - Infrastructure participation: contributing to and benefiting from shared systems rather than relying on proprietary platforms. How Canada supports development: - Embed data stewardship into existing workforce programs: small business support, nonprofit capacity building, and sector-specific training. - For AI-focused careers: expand applied research chairs in verifiable AI and metadata engineering, fund fellowships in data ethics, and create career pathways from research to infrastructure development. - Use public metadata infrastructure (like Artsdata.ca and Footlight CMS) as live training environments. - Offer micro-credentials and apprenticeships in data stewardship, verification, and infrastructure maintenance. Deployment: Partner with libraries, colleges, and regional nonprofits to deliver hands-on training. Create data-stewardship roles across sectors—maintaining verified data, coordinating regional partners, ensuring quality. Result: Workforce readiness becomes infrastructure readiness. When publishing verified information is as easy as posting online, every worker helps build the knowledge layer that keeps AI accurate. That’s not just literacy—it’s shared economic power."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public survey responses add a layer of detail around equitable access and localized delivery that complements expert recommendations. While experts focus on broad strategies to build technical proficiency and research capacity, several public intent categories such as 'Universal Access Infrastructure' and 'Localized, Community-Centered Delivery' stress the importance of adapting these training initiatives to local contexts. Public input highlights practical mechanisms—like community-led digital hubs, subsidized training, multilingual resources, and accessibility measures—to ensure that AI education reaches rural, remote, and underserved communities. This grassroots viewpoint enriches the expert perspective by revealing implementation challenges and the need for inclusiveness in deploying AI literacy initiatives.

Example Responses:

"Equity starts with access. The federal government should pair universal, affordable connectivity and devices with locally delivered learning. Broadband build-outs and low-cost plans must be matched by device programs and secure public access points in schools, libraries, Friendship Centres and community hubs, so rural, remote and low-income learners can actually participate. Materials should be bilingual and, where appropriate, available in Indigenous languages and accessible formats (captioned video, screen-reader friendly, plain-language summaries). Delivery must be community-led. Provinces, territories, municipalities and Indigenous governments should co-design curricula and workshops that reflect local needs, with funding that enables trusted partners—schools, colleges, libraries, settlement agencies, disability organizations and youth groups—to host free, recurring sessions. Programs should remove practical barriers through stipends for childcare and travel, paid micro-internships, and loaner laptops and hotspots. Content must cover both “how to use AI” and “how to question it,” including bias, privacy, security, provenance and routes to human review. Employers and the public sector can widen the funnel by recognizing stackable micro-credentials in hiring and procurement, and by offering paid release time for workers to upskill. Crown corporations and major departments should model best practice by publishing plain-language notices and evaluations in public services, turning real deployments into learning opportunities. Finally, a national equity dashboard—co-managed with provinces and Indigenous partners—should track participation, completion, job placement and regional coverage, so funding moves to where gaps persist and programs evolve with community feedback. This approach treats AI literacy as essential public infrastructure—delivered locally, inclusive by design, and backed by measurable accountability."

"Canada can ensure equitable access to AI literacy by making programs available both virtually and physically across the country. Virtual workshops allow people in remote or rural areas to participate, while in-person workshops make it accessible for those without strong internet or digital tools. These programs should provide certificates on AI knowledge so participants can show practical skills to employers. Industry and government should collaborate to fund and deliver these workshops, ensurin"

"We should have a national frontier model that competes with the best out there and every citizen has access to it. It needs to be treated like a universal utility like electricity."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

A significant divergence arises where public survey responses express deep-seated skepticism and broader social concerns that are under-emphasized in expert reports. For instance, while experts concentrate on building a skilled workforce through training and education, public intents like 'AI skepticism / opposition to AI' and 'Economic/Social Safety Nets & Labor Protections' call for caution in AI adoption, highlighting ethical risks, environmental impacts, and the need for comprehensive social protections (such as universal basic income and stronger labor safeguards). These divergent views reflect a public unease about the immediate impacts of AI and a desire for policies that extend beyond technical skills to address broader social and economic security issues.

Example Responses:

"51. I am against AI in principle and in practice. "AI" usage has been shown to affect the way people use their brain. https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ Data centers use an inordinate amount of energy and water and other necessary natural resources. https://andthewest.stanford.edu/2025/thirsty-for-power-and-water-ai-crunching-data-centers-sprout-across-the-west/ I also object vehemently the fact that training "AI" requires the theft of text, visual, and audio art, as well as people's identity and personhood. "AI" is currently used for observation and extraction of personal information, encroaching in the basic right to individual privacy. I cannot in good conscience support anything related to the current iteration of "AI.""

"15. No to AI. As technology cannot be held accountable for its decisions, it should never be in a position to make decisions that impact real people. No to AI."

"124. The phrasing of this survey's questions make me intensely anxious that its developers are the right people to enhance GENUINE literacy about AI in this country. In other words, I'm not convinced that these questions are themselves the product of AI literacy. Until the "we" implied in this question ("How can we enhance AI literacy in Canada") has a clear grasp on AI's manifold limitations and biases, including the mostly US-centric objectives of the largest AI companies and the shockingly authoritarian impulses of the current American administration, then the "we" shouldn't be responsible for enhancing AI literacy."

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and many public responses recognize the importance of education and skills development as key to enhancing Canada's competitive advantage in the AI era. Experts consistently recommend integrating AI literacy into K–12, higher education, and continuous workforce training, while public respondents similarly stress the need for robust education systems and nationwide standards. There is shared support for government investments that boost a well‐educated, adaptable workforce and for creating frameworks that ensure Canadians can keep pace with technological change.

Example Other Responses:

"Education is delivered provincially so the best Canada can do is provide nationwide regulation and expected standards of practice tied to education related transfer payments."

"Bring back public investment in education at every level. Fund public schools at a level that will let them hire teachers qualified to teach humanities and social sciences; fund universities with the insistence that the money actually be devoted to the academic mission, including programs that teach critical thinking, civics, and ethics; return to a view of education as growing citizens, not employees."

"Incentivise AI-enabled companies to contribute to AI literacy and education."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public responses sometimes broaden the discussion beyond the narrow focus on AI literacy to include fundamental competencies and broader social infrastructure. Several comments suggest that rather than focusing solely on AI or digital skills, Canada should also invest in overall critical thinking, basic reading, mathematics, and even the humanities as foundational for future innovation. This perspective enriches the expert agenda by arguing that effective AI adoption depends on a population with solid, general educational skills and by highlighting the importance of addressing systemic issues in basic education and social services to support these high-tech initiatives.

Example Other Responses:

"Canadians need equitable access to literacy and information literacy; not AI literacy. Focus on that."

"Again, this is an issue of general education, especially in the humanities. It cannot be achieved any way other than investing in robust education at all levels. Federal grants for provincial education systems that require meeting certain standards of education may be effective at this. Additional funds are needed to tackle the increasing educational needs of the population, and grants thread the needle of meeting this need without the federal government technically overstepping provincial freedom in administering education."

"Given that not everyone in Canada yet has access to things like good health care, public transportation, or drinkable water, I would think those should be a higher priority across regions, demographics and socioeconomic groups before AI."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

Some public responses diverge sharply from expert recommendations by questioning the emphasis on specialized AI literacy. A few respondents dismiss the term 'AI literacy' as meaningless or argue that resources should be directed toward more basic or traditional societal needs such as healthcare, housing, and general education reform. This divergence indicates a disconnect between policy‐focused expert proposals and a segment of the public that prefers prioritizing established social services and broader forms of literacy over narrowly defined AI training programs.

Example Other Responses:

""AI Literacy" is a nonsense term. Stop using it. It is meaningless. Talk about applications of ML/DL instead. Keep it real, keep it relevant."

"The skills that we need in our economy are teaching, medicine, and management of affordable housing. Not AI."

"How about instead you focus on making it so that every Canadian can actually have a family doctor and not have to wait an entire day in an emergency ward just to be seen by a doctor? How about if you support small business and reuse and recycling projects? How about if you make right to repair laws?"

The analysis identifies areas of alignment, complementary insights, and divergent perspectives between expert recommendations and public consultation responses.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and public survey responses align in their perspectives and priorities
  • Complementary Insights: Aspects where expert reports and public responses offer different but complementary perspectives that enrich understanding
  • Divergent Perspectives: Areas where expert recommendations and public responses differ significantly in focus, priorities, or approach

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses for this pillar.

The "Other" category contains responses that didn't fit into the main intent categories, representing unique perspectives and edge cases that may offer valuable insights.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and "Other" responses align in perspectives not captured by main categories
  • Complementary Insights: Unique viewpoints from "Other" responses that complement expert recommendations
  • Divergent Perspectives: Novel approaches or concerns in "Other" responses that differ from expert recommendations

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts.

"Other" Category: Survey responses that fell outside standard intent categories, potentially representing emerging themes or unique perspectives not captured in the main taxonomy.

Infrastructure

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and public survey responses agree on the need to expand Canada’s domestic AI infrastructure by boosting compute capacity, establishing secure data environments, and ensuring data sovereignty through public-private partnerships. Experts such as Alex LaPlante and Ben Bergen emphasize creating a sovereign, scalable compute ecosystem, while public respondents in intent categories like 'Compute and data infrastructure gaps' and 'Public/Sovereign AI Infrastructure and Governance' similarly stress that inadequate high-performance compute and fragmented data ecosystems hinder AI innovation and national security. There is a shared acknowledgment that overcoming these infrastructure gaps is critical to maintaining Canada’s competitive edge and safeguarding sensitive data.

Example Responses:

"Infrastructure gaps holding back AI in Canada: Compute – limited high-performance, AI-ready cloud and HPC resources. Data – fragmented, siloed, or inaccessible datasets for research and training. Connectivity – uneven broadband and low-latency networks, especially in remote regions. Barriers to building sovereign infrastructure include high capital costs, long ROI timelines, talent shortages, complex data governance, and regulatory uncertainty."

"The biggest gaps are access to affordable compute and high-quality Canadian datasets. Canadian researchers and start-ups rely heavily on U.S. hyperscalers, which limits sovereignty. The cost of sovereign infrastructure is too high for individual firms, so government must derisk through large-scale funding, public–private partnerships, and predictable long-term support."

"We don’t have a strong chip industry anymore, as we had in the past. That is a hard one, but we should explore even if it takes decades. As an example, as soon as Nvidia can be avoided we should due to their shady business practices. Other than that, we should be smart and even expand our investment into figuring out more efficient and environmentally friendly ways of running the infrastructure. Micro nuclear power plants and more efficient thermal solutions for data centres are definitely a way."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public survey responses add granularity and context to expert recommendations by highlighting implementation details and regional as well as environmental considerations that expand upon expert frameworks. For instance, while experts recommend sovereign compute hubs and standardized data protocols, public intents such as 'Hybrid Public-Private Model with Guardrails' illustrate the need for clear pricing caps, explicit data residency requirements, and support for regional and rural connectivity. These insights underscore a more nuanced vision of equitable access, including specifics such as reserved credits for SMEs and public-interest projects, which complement and enrich the broader strategic imperatives outlined by experts.

Example Responses:

"10. Create a federated national fabric: regional sovereign clouds + shared GPUs, with reserved tiers for researchers, startups, and SMEs. Use open-source models where viable; support edge computing for remote/industrial sites. Require fair-use pricing and portability across providers. Hyperscalers can participate, but data residency, auditability, and exit rights must be mandatory. Reference platforms like TPTN can expose secure APIs to lower access barriers."

"41. Set up a two-tier system that combines a Canadian HPC backbone with pooled cloud credits, both wrapped in a single access portal. Researchers get queue-based access with fair scheduling, while startups and SMEs receive predictable credits tied to milestones like prototyping, evaluation, and commercialization. Hyperscalers can co-invest and colocate with Canadian partners, but pricing and data residency must be transparent. Open-source models and edge inference should be first-class options so teams in remote regions can run useful workloads without constant backhaul. If access includes hands-on engineering support, templated MLOps stacks, and legal templates for data sharing, smaller players will actually use the infrastructure rather than watch it from the sidelines."

"51. Tiered access model: reserved pools for research/public interest; SMB credits for evaluation and fine‑tuning; pay‑as‑you‑go for burst inference. Regional hubs: colocate compute + data clean rooms at colleges/polytechnics; attach connectivity upgrades and on‑site support. Hyperscaler partnerships with conditions: discounted credits convertible to sovereign capacity; portability of artifacts (models, eval reports, datasets). Open‑source first: fund Canadian‑tuned open models, toolchains, and eval suites; ensure weights and artifacts can run on sovereign hardware. Edge computing: grants for on‑prem edge boxes in hospitals, municipalities, and plants; managed updates and remote attestation for security. Fair queuing and quotas: transparent schedulers, regional carve‑outs, and anti‑hoarding rules; publish utilization dashboards. Hands‑on enablement: “Implementation clinics” and a national help‑desk for data readiness, secure MLOps, and evaluation. 90‑day action: Launch an SMB Infrastructure Passport providing credits, training, and priority queues at two regional hubs and one hyper-scaler partner."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

There is a noticeable divergence where some public survey responses express skepticism towards further AI infrastructure investments, emphasizing environmental impacts, economic risks, and even calling for stricter regulation or opposition to AI. This contrasts with the expert view that sees robust investment in infrastructure as a cornerstone for economic growth and national security. Public responses within the 'AI Skepticism / Opposition' category, for example, caution against the unchecked expansion of data centers due to their high energy and water consumption, a concern that is minimally reflected in most expert reports which focus more on capacity building and sovereignty.

Example Responses:

"I am against AI in principle and in practice. "AI" usage has been shown to affect the way people use their brain. https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ Data centers use an inordinate amount of energy and water and other necessary natural resources. https://andthewest.stanford.edu/2025/thirsty-for-power-and-water-ai-crunching-data-centers-sprout-across-the-west/ I also object vehemently the fact that training "AI" requires the theft of text, visual, and audio art, as well as people's identity and personhood. "AI" is currently used for observation and extraction of personal information, encroaching in the basic right to individual privacy. I cannot in good conscience support anything related to the current iteration of "AI.""

"AI, especially LLM AI, is a security nightmare and shouldn’t have anything to do with security at all. It’s the opposite of security and growth. It’s a bubble about to burst."

"The mere fact that you are asking this question is depressing. Please don't build massive data centres in Canada. We're already seeing the devastating impacts these data centres are having on communities in the US: https://www.techpolicy.press/data-center-boom-risks-health-of-already-vulnerable-communities/, https://www.canarymedia.com/articles/fossil-fuels/how-the-data-center-boom-could-harm-black-communities, https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2025/apr/24/elon-musk-xai-memphis. Let's not go down this road. Please."

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses

Common Ground
View examples

Both experts and a subset of public respondents recognize that a strong foundation is needed to support AI development and adoption in Canada. Experts emphasize building robust, secure, and accessible compute and data infrastructure (through initiatives like national compute centres, subsidized SME access, and standardized data platforms) while a few public responses acknowledge that support for small businesses and investment in human capital—as well as the need for better training and education—are critical to ensuring Canada remains competitive. In essence, both groups see the value in improving digital infrastructure, although experts focus on technical and strategic specifics while some publics underscore the need for workforce development and broadened access.

Example Other Responses:

"AI adoption support for small businesses is a priority area."

"Human resources. We need to recruit and train many more."

"Knowledge and education surrounding data"

Complementary Insights
View examples

Several public responses add nuance to the expert recommendations by broadening the discussion beyond mere technical capacity. While experts detail specific infrastructure projects, some publics call for complementary measures that address the human and social dimensions of technology deployment. For instance, public contributors stress that investments should also support families, education, and worker training, highlighting that the benefits of enhanced AI infrastructure must trickle down to improve everyday life. This perspective enriches the discussion by suggesting that high-level infrastructure improvements need to be paired with efforts to upskill the workforce and mitigate socioeconomic challenges.

Example Other Responses:

"The cost of technology is hard on families. Provide some government grants to schools and families."

"More funding is needed for education both at the elementary, secondary, and post-secondary school levels as well as assistance for students to attend post-secondary schools and graduate without a heavy student loan burden. Also funding for public library computers and Internet is crucial."

"I want to see the same investment in workers."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

A significant divergence is evident where many public responses express skepticism about heavy investment in AI infrastructure. While expert reports consistently advocate for building sovereign and scalable compute capacity as integral to national competitiveness and innovation, numerous public comments reject the premise that AI innovation is beneficial. Some respondents argue that efforts and funds should not be directed towards AI at all, cautioning that such investments might exacerbate existing social inequalities or simply be a misallocation of resources that could be better spent on more immediate needs like housing, education, or basic services.

Example Other Responses:

"I don't believe that this infrastructure should be built. I do not believe that AI innovation is beneficial for Canadians."

"No one should be investing in AI in any way. Why would you want to encourage investing in a giant bubble?"

"NO AI. EVER."

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar.

The analysis identifies areas of alignment, complementary insights, and divergent perspectives between expert recommendations and public consultation responses.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and public survey responses align in their perspectives and priorities
  • Complementary Insights: Aspects where expert reports and public responses offer different but complementary perspectives that enrich understanding
  • Divergent Perspectives: Areas where expert recommendations and public responses differ significantly in focus, priorities, or approach

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts submitted through the consultation process.

Public Survey: Responses from the public consultation survey, classified into intent categories using LLM-based classification.

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses for this pillar.

The "Other" category contains responses that didn't fit into the main intent categories, representing unique perspectives and edge cases that may offer valuable insights.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and "Other" responses align in perspectives not captured by main categories
  • Complementary Insights: Unique viewpoints from "Other" responses that complement expert recommendations
  • Divergent Perspectives: Novel approaches or concerns in "Other" responses that differ from expert recommendations

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts.

"Other" Category: Survey responses that fell outside standard intent categories, potentially representing emerging themes or unique perspectives not captured in the main taxonomy.

Security

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and public survey responses emphasize the need for robust security measures to protect Canada’s critical infrastructure, data, and sovereignty in an AI-driven environment. For instance, multiple expert reports (e.g., Joelle Pineau, James Neufeld, and Adam Keating) stress the importance of secure, sovereign AI infrastructures, accountability mechanisms, and enhanced cybersecurity protocols. This aligns with public survey responses in Intent 1 of Question 24, which calls for AI security, governance, and national defense readiness by highlighting risks like AI‐powered cyberattacks, adversarial testing, and the need for domestic threat intelligence. Both groups agree on the importance of defensive measures, secure supply chains, and ensuring that AI systems remain under Canadian control to mitigate risks from external adversaries.

Example Responses:

"AI-powered cyberattacks can now adapt in real-time to defensive measures, automate vulnerability discovery, and generate sophisticated phishing campaigns that traditional security tools cannot detect. Adversarial nations are developing AI systems to manipulate Canadian social media, generate deepfake content of public figures, and target critical infrastructure with precision attacks on power grids and water systems. Model poisoning attacks where malicious actors corrupt training data or compromise AI systems pose risks to healthcare AI, autonomous vehicles, and financial systems that rely on AI decision-making. Canada needs an AI Security Center similar to the Canadian Centre for Cyber Security, focused specifically on AI threat intelligence, conducting red team exercises against critical AI systems, and developing defensive AI to counter emerging threats. Establish mandatory AI supply chain audits for critical systems, ensuring models, training data, and compute infrastructure aren't compromised by foreign adversaries."

"Emerging risks include deepfakes, cyberattacks, autonomous weapons, and data poisoning. Canada must invest in AI threat intelligence, defence R&D, regulation, and allied security partnerships."

"AI is exponentially faster than neurons, and we're going to have to have AI to fight AI. The BEST defence are points 1 and 2 below: 1. TAKE ALL CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE OFFLINE 2. TAKE ALL CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE OFFLINE 3. Stop being so blind to supremacist cultures who use their emigrants to Canada as siphons. 4. Encourage Canadians to reduce financial activity online...this is a tough one..."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Public survey responses add valuable layers to the discussion by addressing broader societal and governance issues that complement the technical and sector-specific focus of expert reports. While experts primarily recommend technical and structural measures (e.g., secure compute clusters, centralized incident reporting, and domestic development of critical AI capabilities), public intents such as 'Policy, governance, and international collaboration' (Intent 3 in Question 25) and 'Privacy, data sovereignty, and intellectual property governance' (Intent 6 in Question 24) expand on this by stressing ethical frameworks, international cooperation, misinformation challenges, and the protection of personal and intellectual property rights. These public insights underscore how technical security measures must be accompanied by strong regulatory oversight, ethical standards, and transparent governance to build overall public trust in AI.

Example Responses:

"Canada should champion multilateral standards for secure AI development while maintaining domestic oversight of foreign AI technologies deployed in critical systems. Investing in a national cyber emergency response capability specifically designed for AI-enabled threats will enable rapid coordination across sectors. Success requires bridging public and private sector expertise through incentivized information sharing and joint research initiatives that keep Canada ahead of evolving threats."

"Canada can strengthen cybersecurity by enforcing robust policies, securing sensitive data, and embedding resilience in AI systems. Public-private collaboration, international partnerships, and continuous threat monitoring ensure protection of critical infrastructure. Emphasizing transparency, accountability, and ethical practices fosters trust while safeguarding society, economy, and creation in the AI era."

"Comprehensive cybersecurity for AI systems—encryption, access control, adversarial robustness—requires specialized expertise beyond this response. But data integrity is a security posture often treated separately from traditional cybersecurity. The vulnerability: AI systems are only as secure as the data they depend on. Protecting models and infrastructure means nothing if the underlying data layer can be manipulated, poisoned, or degraded without detection. Strengthening through verified infrastructure: - Policy: Require provenance tracking and verification protocols for any AI system operating on critical infrastructure. - Programs: Fund sovereign verification systems to audit AI models, verify data integrity, and trace information sources. - Resilience: Build AI systems on verified, distributed data infrastructure so local failures don't cascade into systemic compromise. - Data protection: Classify metadata and verification infrastructure as critical national assets requiring sovereign control. International collaboration: Partner with democratic allies on: - Shared verification standards for cross-border AI systems - Coordinated response protocols for epistemic attacks - Joint development of adversarial data detection tools Leveraging partnerships: Canada's verified data infrastructure can serve as a trust anchor for allied AI systems—a sovereign source of truth in democratic information networks. This complements but doesn't replace traditional cybersecurity. Both layers—technical security and epistemic security—are essential."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

A notable divergence emerges between the expert recommendations and segments of the public input that are highly skeptical of AI’s role in critical functions. While experts generally advocate for integrating AI into defense and security with appropriate safeguards, some public respondents in intents such as 'Skepticism and calls to ban or avoid AI adoption' (Question 24, Intent 2) and 'Anti-AI in defense' (Question 26, Intent 6) argue for banning or severely limiting AI usage due to its inherent risks and unpredictable behavior. These public voices question the very premise of relying on AI for security, emphasizing potential hallmarks such as 'hallucinations' in AI responses and the risk of delegating critical security functions to technology perceived as insufficiently reliable.

Example Responses:

"Again, AI must not be introduced into any area so critical as defence. Funding must go to humans in these areas, so they can recognize vulnerabilities, quantify threats and respond appropriately given the circumstances -- something that modern AI is simply incapable of doing."

"Canada does not need to use AI for defense, and it would be more suitable to have its citizens understand how AI can be easily exploited by others to prevent a reliance on AI from making the country vulnerable."

"I am against AI in principle and in practice. "AI" usage has been shown to affect the way people use their brain. https://www.media.mit.edu/publications/your-brain-on-chatgpt/ Data centers use an inordinate amount of energy and water and other necessary natural resources. https://andthewest.stanford.edu/2025/thirsty-for-power-and-water-ai-crunching-data-centers-sprout-across-the-west/ I also object vehemently to the fact that training "AI" requires the theft of text, visual, and audio art, as well as people's identity and personhood. "AI" is currently used for observation and extraction of personal information, encroaching on the basic right to individual privacy. I cannot in good conscience support anything related to the current iteration of "AI.""

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis

Comparative analysis of expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses

Common Ground
View examples

Both expert reports and a subset of public responses share a concern for ensuring secure infrastructure and maintaining national sovereignty in the AI realm. Experts repeatedly emphasize the need for robust cybersecurity measures, secure and sovereign data systems, and reducing dependency on foreign-controlled infrastructure, as seen in recommendations for incident reporting, liability-safe practices, and domestic control of cloud services. Public responses echo these ideas by warning against reliance on foreign systems and stressing the importance of safeguarding critical assets, for example noting that unpredictable external influences (such as from the United States) compromise Canada’s security. This alignment indicates a shared perspective on building internal capability and rigorous protective measures for AI systems.

Example Other Responses:

"The biggest threat is the instability and unpredictability of the United States of America. Canada needs to stop trying to placate them (both directly by trying to negotiate with Trump and indirectly by emulating his anti-privacy and anti-worker policies) and instead fully disconnect."

"Well you money grubbing govt officials have too much Chinese corruption in this country! So let’s start with that."

"Don’t use StarLink. Renewable energy (solar and wind) powered data centres."

Complementary Insights
View examples

Some public responses add nuance and depth to the expert recommendations by highlighting angles that experts did not fully explore, such as the need for clear communication to build public trust and the environmental sustainability of AI-related infrastructure. These responses introduce the argument for designing data centres that not only are secure but also powered by renewable energy, and for ensuring that public messaging about security measures is transparent and comprehensive. They extend the discussion from the technical and procedural dimensions into cultural, environmental, and trust-building aspects that can influence how AI security is approached in Canada.

Example Other Responses:

"There’s no more important section than this one right here. And the communication of what has been put in place is essential for the public to buy in and not punish the liberals at the next election because people are now voting for their lives as they watch the world unfold. Aligning with companies who have already shown reason for the public to distrust them will make this dead in the water not to mention the actual real life risks it presents to Canadians."

"Require AI to be environmentally friendly and stop destroying the world. Ensure any data centres use electricity from renewable sources and only uses water in a low-impact way."

"Stop pretending other countries are our enemies. Fund human life rather than the pursuit of capital, I hear that helps with crime."

Divergent Perspectives
View examples

While experts focus on methodical, policy-oriented approaches for national AI security, some public responses present markedly divergent views that are either overly extreme or radically different in tone. For instance, certain responses advocate for drastic measures such as violence or eugenic policies, or they dismiss nuanced strategic planning in favor of reactive stances. This disconnect shows that not all public contributions align with the measured, systems-based approaches proposed by the experts; instead, some voices call for either hyperbolic or ideologically driven solutions that differ significantly from the policy frameworks recommended by the expert community.

Example Other Responses:

"the presence of even one individual with an understanding of what humanity is. we can mitigate this through campaigns of eugenics that identify compassion & empathy in children and decimate those ugly kids and their disgusting capacity for kindness."

"Start bombing foreign data centres. No casualties."

"Defence like military? I think we both know if someone wants to invade Canada they can and will. Get yourself nuclear weapons or get comfortable being very nice to everyone."

Expert Reports & Public Survey Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and ALL public survey intent categories for this pillar.

The analysis identifies areas of alignment, complementary insights, and divergent perspectives between expert recommendations and public consultation responses.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and public survey responses align in their perspectives and priorities
  • Complementary Insights: Aspects where expert reports and public responses offer different but complementary perspectives that enrich understanding
  • Divergent Perspectives: Areas where expert recommendations and public responses differ significantly in focus, priorities, or approach

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts submitted through the consultation process.

Public Survey: Responses from the public consultation survey, classified into intent categories using LLM-based classification.

Expert Reports & Public Consultation Analysis - Information

About This Analysis

This section provides a comparative analysis between expert report recommendations and public "Other" category responses for this pillar.

The "Other" category contains responses that didn't fit into the main intent categories, representing unique perspectives and edge cases that may offer valuable insights.

Analysis Components

  • Common Ground: Areas where expert reports and "Other" responses align in perspectives not captured by main categories
  • Complementary Insights: Unique viewpoints from "Other" responses that complement expert recommendations
  • Divergent Perspectives: Novel approaches or concerns in "Other" responses that differ from expert recommendations

Data Sources

Expert Reports: Professional analyses and recommendations from domain experts.

"Other" Category: Survey responses that fell outside standard intent categories, potentially representing emerging themes or unique perspectives not captured in the main taxonomy.

Analysis conducted by Communications Research Centre Canada - ISED (Version 4 - 2025-11-14)
